name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The first point is the Commission's statement on growth rates in the EU and spring 2015 economic forecasts (2015/2705(RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am speaking here in this plenary debate on growth rates in the EU and the spring 2015 economic forecast on behalf of my dear colleague Pierre Moscovici. The Commission published its spring 2015 European economic forecast on 5 May. Its main message is that the near-term outlook for the EU economy has improved. This was confirmed in the first quarter of this year, where real GDP increased by 0.4 % quarter-on-quarter in both the EU and the euro area. The economic recovery therefore continued in both regions and even strengthened somewhat in the euro area. The euro-area economy recorded its highest growth rate in nearly two years.  The economy is getting an extra boost in the short term from tailwinds such as low oil prices, a weaker euro and quantitative easing (QE) from the European Central Bank. The combined strength of these positive factors underpins a slight upward revision for GDP growth this year. According to our forecasts, real GDP growth in the EU is expected to increase from 1.4% last year to 1.8% in the current year, 2015, and 2.1% in 2016. In the euro area, it is now forecast to pick up from 0.9% last year to 1.5% in the current year, 2015 and 1.9% in 2016. However, underlying weaknesses and legacies from the crisis remain and weigh on the medium-term growth outlook. Unemployment remains intolerably high. The level of debt, in particular corporate and sovereign, remains very high. The share of non-performing bank loans is elevated and continues to rise in some Member States. The shortfall of investment over the past six years has reduced economic growth potential.  Across EU Member States, the recovery is expected to remain uneven. All countries are set to gain from the positive tailwinds, but the extent to which they will benefit will depend on several factors such as the varying responsiveness of individual economies to lower oil prices and the euro depreciation. The ECB’s QE is also likely to have a higher impact in countries with tight financing conditions.  The recovery of the labour market in the EU is progressing and is becoming fairly broad-based across sectors. The unemployment rate is projected to decline slowly, reflecting the persistence of high structural unemployment and the large unemployment gaps, as the rise in economic activity is not strong enough for a more marked improvement.  Inflation is bottoming out. Later this year, and more noticeably in 2016, inflation is expected to pick up. It will be underpinned by stronger domestic demand, fading effects of lower commodity prices and higher import prices triggered by the euro depreciation. Inflation expectations have recovered, and the risks of deflation have moderated as a result of the ECB’s QE and the stronger growth outlook. The fiscal outlook is improving and the aggregated fiscal policy stance is expected to be broadly neutral in the current year in the European Union. In many EU Member States, deficit ratios are projected to continue falling in 2015 and 2016, helped by stronger growth and lower interest payments on public debt.  Following the substantial fiscal adjustment achieved over the last few years, the aggregated fiscal policy stance in 2015 in the EU is expected to be broadly neutral and therefore more supportive to growth. Moreover, for the first time since the onset of the crisis, the debt burden is also expected to decrease as of this year. Uncertainty remains elevated but risks to our growth outlook are broadly balanced. Growth could surprise on the upside if monetary policy and low oil prices have bigger effects than anticipated. Also, the Investment Plan for Europe, for which a cautious approach has prevailed in our assessment, could have a stronger than expected impact.  Downside risks include geopolitical risks, as tensions related to the Russia-Ukraine conflict remain high. Also, if oil prices rebound faster than assumed, this could erase the windfall gains from lower energy prices. In financial markets, the risk of renewed financial market volatility could weigh on economic growth.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: We have made very important progress and we have very good forecasts. Of course, there are also signs that need to be addressed and problems that need to be addressed. I will now speak to the key words of the political groups.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, Europe is recovering from a very deep economic and social crisis. However, growth is slow and still unstable, and there are serious unknowns in the future. For example, some have been mentioned here: the risk of the relationship with Russia, the negotiation with Greece, the lack of reforms in some of the large countries. The truth is that the confrontation between growth and austerity turned out to be a false debate. Today it is clear that without austerity and reforms there can be no growth. My country, Spain, is a good example: four and a half years ago it lost 70 billion euros of revenue, it had 30 billion euros of hidden deficit, it lost three and a half million jobs in just four years, every two minutes three jobs were lost, we were in recession and the financial system lost 250,000 impossors. Today, four years later, of austerity and reforms, we met the deficit targets, those who charge less than 20,000 euros a year already pay less taxes, no hospitals have had to be closed, no school, no purchasing power has lost pensions, 500 000 jobs have been created in the last year. Eight jobs are now created every two minutes. A ransom was avoided, Spain did not have to be rescued. GDP has grown by 3.5% in the first quarter and the growth rate of the economy is the highest of the large countries of the European Union. We are idealists, but we must not be illusory and much remains to be done. You have to stop it from being believed in magic wands. They don't exist in economic policy, it's more like math. That is why we must ask everyone to fulfil their obligation, because Europe is a club in which we are all equal in rights, but also equal in obligations and what has been obligatory for the Countries of the Mediterranean must also be mandatory for others, whatever their size. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask my colleague whether he does not believe that, rather than with the reforms, Spain has been able to return to a path of growth thanks precisely to non-compliance with the rules. In fact, if you look at the deficit-to-GDP ratio of the Spanish State in recent years, you can see that Spain has never met the 3% limit, that is, Spain, the Spanish State, has been able to invest to recover growth, to return to a path of growth. Do you not think that is the real reason, rather than the reforms?

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: "blue card" response. – My dear colleague, I think just the opposite. What happened to my country, as happens to many other countries, is that it did not comply with the rules. When Spain has complied with the rules, it has returned to the path of growth, it has once again been one of the fastest growing countries in the European Union. I believe that is why all the countries of the Union should be required to comply with the rules.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation)).

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking the question. Sir, do you think it was a good decision or a bad decision for Spain to enter the euro?

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: "blue card" response. – I think it was the best decision the Spanish Government has made in the last twenty years. Thank you very much for your question.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, Mr Commissioner, Europe needs a sound recovery to reduce unemployment and to provide help again. So far we just have very small signs of recovery and the fundamentals remain very fragile.  We had a coincidence of special factors: low oil prices, favourable exchange rates, and most of all expansionary monetary policy, the ECB providing quantitative easing – but these are special factors. For a sound recovery we need certainly a push for reforms, but I would say reforms having in mind better growth potential in our economies, providing better jobs – these are the kind of reforms we need to have – but most of all we need to have a large investment plan really providing opportunities for many strategic projects which are still waiting for proper financing. So this is a really big priority for us, but we believe that this is not all, because we need also to have a favourable fiscal policy allowing for Member States to push for this investment and job creation. Then we also see the landscape in Europe: we still have very deep economic and social divergences within Member States and between Member States, and this can only be solved if we go ahead in completing the Economic and Monetary Union and in rebalancing it in such a way that they can count on proper coordination of economic and social policies and on a fiscal capacity.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Economic recovery, that is what the European Commission predicts. That is a good thing, but, ladies and gentlemen, let us not tell each other blows. Our economic engine had stalled. We were able to get it going again. But how? Mainly because of low energy prices and the monetary dumping currently practised by the European Central Bank.  Yes, the ECB's policy pushes us from the red to the green figures, but those advantages do not outweigh the disadvantages. The interest on our savings accounts is falling. Our pensions are becoming increasingly insecure and we are blowing bubbles in our economy. Anyway, the economic engine is running again. How can we ensure that we continue to progress and to keep moving forward? This can only be done if we opt for a genuine recovery policy, because short-term windfalls can never be a foundation for a strong economy. So we need to reform, we need to increase productivity and get more people to work. This is the only way to achieve these positive growth rates, as predicted by the Commission, and to continue to achieve them in the future. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure]

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Loones, do you think that the Juncker plan, in the end, is going to improve the European Union’s economy and is going to create jobs?

name: Sander LOONES
text: "blue card" answer. – What I see above all is that Europe has found a golden solution, and that is: we are throwing some money at it. The European Central Bank: we're throwing some money at it. The Juncker plan: we are throwing some extra money into the economy.  That does have an effect. We are now seeing this with the policy of quantitative easing, and we see that in this report. But that has no lasting effect. As I said, short short-term windfalls are not a basis for real recovery. Real recovery will only come when we really reform. So Mr Juncker's plan will undoubtedly have an effect, but it will only be able to be anchored in a sustainable way until the Member States implement the reforms that are needed.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – It is indeed good news that the euro area economy appears to be climbing out of the valley. We're really moving in the right direction. It is good that we see that the euro area grew faster than the US economy in the first quarter.  But we're not there yet. Colleagues have already said it. If we want to stabilise this, if we are to make real progress, we really need to reform. And I think we can contribute to that. I would actually like to use the Indian Prime Minister Modi as an example, because he said, as we did here: 'We have to cut the red tape'. That is what Commissioner Frans Timmermans has just presented his plans for. I very much hope that he will go through with that and that this will be successful. But Prime Minister Modi added something. He said, "We have to replace the red tape with a red carpet for our businesses.". And that red carpet for our business, I don't see it that bad.  We do have plans for an energy union, because energy prices are of course much higher than in other parts of the world. We really need to work on this quickly with the internal market. We are talking about a capital union, but we are still working on a green paper there first. We really need to try to get momentum into that. And what I certainly miss: the Juncker plan talks about reindustrialisation, and it has remained deafeningly silent about that. So I would also like to hear about the Commission's plans in the short term. Which way are we going now? Because if we want to solve this unemployment, jobs are created by business and not by the public authorities. So then we really need to give that business the space to create those jobs, and so we also have to make sure that we explain the red carpet for the companies. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure]

name: Paul TANG
text: blue-card question. – Mrs van Nieuwenhuizen, you speak about cutting red tape and that is no surprise, coming from your position. But does cutting red tape also include the budgetary rules? We have many budgetary rules that do indeed frustrate structural reforms and frustrate public investment, and are not lived up to – for example the debt rule. How do you see this? Is cutting this red tape also acceptable for you then?

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: "blue card" answer. I am surprised that Mr Tang says that he understands that cutting red tape is really something I would like, because it is his own European Commissioner, Frans Timmermans, who is working this.  Of course we are for that. When you talk about budgetary rules, it is asking about the familiar way, because we absolutely believe that you should simply enforce the rules.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Commissioner, they left you here. The others are in Riga. You are not responsible, but you will listen to them as a representative of the Commission. I do not share at all the solemn, optimistic tones of the spring forecast. These optimistic tones do not arise from the numbers and realities. Are you excited about yourself? Where's the growth? Where is the reduction in unemployment, especially among young people? Where are the investments, public and private? Where is the strengthening of cohesion, social and regional? In recent years, Europe has gone backwards and the weak growth rates of recent months are mainly due to external factors. So we need a shift in economic policy from the doctrine of unilateral austerity and cuts. And this shift needs to be made, at last, also in Greece, which has suffered from the most catastrophic recession and the most savage unilateral austerity. It's not just a matter for the Greeks, it's your case. We must ensure better administration, less bureaucracy, less corruption, a stronger economy, but you must also rid the country of a programme that has destroyed both the economy and society. I hope that those who are missing in Riga and who have left you here will help break this knot, both for Europe and for Greece. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, of course you have criticised what the Commission is doing – I do not agree with all things either. However, in your speech you said nothing about the fact that more should be invested for SMEs to have jobs in Greece and to pull Greece out of recession. Don't you think investment funds should also have geographical criteria?

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. Thanks for the question. I believe, first of all, that the Investment Fund should be strengthened with more resources because at the moment it does not have a single euro of new, fresh money. Criteria for allocating these investments should also be taken into account in the criteria for allocating these investments. In other words, investments from the Juncker Fund should go to the countries most suffering from disinvestment, high unemployment and, therefore, there should also be geographical criteria and social criteria and economic criteria.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, surprisingly, perhaps, I agree with much of what the previous speaker has said. The long-term economic reality is wholly different from that which is put forward in this document. The fact is that EU regulation hampers the flexibility of labour markets a lot more. As an EU member, the UK has to accept all of the EU’s growth-toxic legislation; and by the way, only 15% of the UK’s GDP is accounted for by EU trade. The EU also imposes alternative energy policies. In direct consequence, electricity in the European Union now costs twice as much as in the United States, and indeed energy prices in the EU increased by 40% from 2006 to 2013. Further, the EU is a protectionist construct. It was set up that way. It inhibits free trade, and one example is that Member States cannot enter into their own trade agreements.  The EU single currency – the euro – defies economic sense, Mr Pons. Spain is in a monetary union with Germany. Greece is in a monetary union with Germany. It does not work. The euro began as a one-size-fits-all currency. It has now become a kind of economic doomsday machine that engenders massive unemployment and the consequent human suffering. Burdensome regulation... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – Many of you are jubilant at some figures these days and are already talking about turning and climbing the valley of the economy. Frédéric Bastiat spoke at the time about That Which is Seen and That Which is Not Seen in economics. So a lot of things can be underexposed. Let me mention a few: The small effects on consumer behaviour and employment are the result of falling oil prices, i.e. not the merit of the euro area in itself.  The Juncker Fund will compete with private projects through public investment.  The euphoria does not take into account stock market bubbles as a result of the massive money creation of your own ECB and the risks to the profitability of pension funds.  In short, Italy's public debt is now 146%, and Greece's is outstripping it by 180%. At the rate of 0.4% today, we are therefore still working on growing a debt economy into a capital gains economy for the whole of this currency zone. Ladies and gentlemen, I think optimism is totally misplaced and, in a sense, immoral.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The recovery of the European economy, albeit a slight one, is certainly good news. Nevertheless, we must continue to push ahead with the economic and investment agenda. It is important to ensure that economic growth in Europe is sustainable and sustainable. Three aspects are, in my view, of particular importance here. Firstly, this is a responsible budgetary policy. Especially in the current environment, it is essential that budgetary rules are respected in order to make economic and monetary union fit for the future. Secondly, more investment. I am sure that the investment offensive that is just beginning will bear fruit in the long term. However, we should not forget that investors are looking not only at economic data and risk indicators, but also at economic performance, debt ratios and deficit figures. Investment and forward-looking economic policy are two sides of the same coin. Thirdly, the implementation of structural reforms. At the root of all efforts are still the Member States, especially those Member States that are in difficulty and need to press ahead with the reform agenda. It is about the courage to undertake far-reaching structural reforms, not empty promises of reform, the implementation of which is a long time coming. It must be a matter of course that European pressure is maintained. Reforms are a basis for investment to fall on fertile ground and growth to emerge. We must not let up now. On the contrary, the tailwind for economic recovery predicted by the Commission must encourage us to make further efforts.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have a Commission forecast which has improved by 0.2 percentage points. I have to say: I am very impressed! If the European Central Bank puts EUR 60 billion in circulation every month, if interest rates are pushed to below zero levels, then the forecast will rise by 0.2 percentage points! This only shows that monetary policy can do almost nothing. This only shows that the real problems of the eurozone are still completely unresolved, completely unresolved. You can see what you have to keep from forecasts when you look at Greece: for a long time, Greece has been projected to grow by 2.9%. And what do we see now? Growth in Greece is not 2.9%, but a miserable 0.5% – almost nothing! The Greek problems are building up, unemployment is still enormous, and young people have no prospects there. The European Union's economic policy has failed completely, and Greece is tumbling towards bankruptcy. Unfortunately, this is the consequence of European economic policy.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, you have come here to say that growth is going to come, that the debt will decrease, that the unemployment rate will decrease, that the deficit will fall and that inflation is expected to rise a little bit, supported by increased demand. And then it says that the European Commission's policy, as it stands, is to continue.  Commissioner, this is fiction and has already been written with much better quality than by the European Commission. It's called "Waiting for Godot," it was written by Beckett, and in the end, Vladimir tells Estragon, "So we must leave?" And Estragon replies, "Yes, let's go!" But they do not go out of the way, and that is exactly the fiction that the European Commission is doing about European citizens and citizens.  You come here to say that for the first time since 2008, we were going to get out of the crisis and that everything would improve. I have one piece of news to tell you, Commissioner, is that all commissioners since 2008 have come here to say every year that for the first time everything would improve and yet there has not been a single forecast that has been fulfilled. They all failed without exception.  But there is a relevant data, which is the inflation data of 0.1%. If this is confirmed, it sets up a very serious liquidity trap context and the European Commission seems satisfied with quantitative easing and yet so far we have not seen anything rigorously and this simply means that the ECB is failing in its mandate and the Commission too, because the only way not to fail is to promote public investment for all countries.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the figures released in May are worrying, and I am thinking in particular of the Greek case. I wonder, in fact, how it is possible to move in the space of just three months from a growth prospect for the Greek country of 2.5% per annum to the paltry 0.5% indicated a few days ago. Perhaps there are people in the European Commission who enjoy using random numbers and figures, or there have been further signs that the situation is actually much more dramatic than we want to tell the citizens of Europe. In any case, the central point is that we cannot emerge from the crisis, least of all through the policies decided by the troika, which have proved to be totally unsuccessful. The way Greece repaid the Monetary Fund this week is just a palliative, a grotesque and tragic way of postponing, and not very much, a huge problem that risks leading the country to an imminent default, with unpredictable consequences. My question for the Commission is whether it has considered possible alternative solutions, such as Grexit, or whether it will wait for the system to burst before taking concrete action.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the latest forecasts on economic growth and inflation in the European Union seem to be converging. In April, the zone would have emerged from price deflation with zero inflation over a slippery year, after four months of negative inflation. So, officially, everything is going well in the best of worlds.  Of course, these figures mask a very different reality. Firstly, these results are the result of a deluge of financial resources put in place to revive economic growth, whether through national budgets, the ECB's quantitative easing programmes or Mr Juncker's miraculous plans. Big means, small effects. Secondly, this statistical swallow does not make the economic spring: 0.4% in the EU, 0.6% for France in the first quarter of 2015, when the United Kingdom made 2.80% in 2014.  Finally, I must recall that this increase is also the result of a new way of calculating GDP imposed at EU level, of which the National Front is the only one to speak. Indeed, criminal activities such as prostitution or drug trafficking as well as smuggling have been gradually integrated into a new method of calculating GDP, leading to an artificial increase in economic growth.  Unfortunately, households do not feel the recovery we are being touted for, neither in employment nor in the order books of SMEs. The accounting illusion and the communication plan of the governments and Brussels cannot hide the reality. There is no real recovery and we are still in a structural recession.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There are now figures that say that there is growth in Europe now, and there will soon be a little more growth. Normally we would have to say: we are on the right track. Instead, they are just complaining about it. We are on the right track at a difficult time. I recommend that we look at the reality instead of complaining. It is different in the Member States. There are Member States that are strict, that are struggling, that are also a little bit of a thing for their citizens, but they are making progress and they are generating growth figures. There are Member States that care about an intact and interesting culture for business start-ups and less regulation, and there are Member States that are spending more and more money. Where are people better off? I recommend a look at the realities, and we will see that there is more and less progress. But, in principle, europe is making progress. There is a big problem, that is true. Because a government has been elected that obviously does not absthestinuate what is agreed. But this is not a problem for Europe in general – that is unfair. Most of these countries that have been in difficulty – Spain, Ireland, Latvia, Portugal – are making progress, and other countries are making really good progress. It is about corporate culture, it is about frugal fiscal policy, about incentives for growth. It is not a question of spending more money – such nonsense! I can no longer hear that there is always a demand that we spend more money. Then the Schlendrian goes on there, and nothing changes. Those who want to invest and businesses need support and help. Yes, we can think about whether we have perhaps regulated too much in one place or another. We can be wiser, we can agree. But this lawsuit doesn't help at all. Only courage, tackling and going forward will help. Thank you to the Commission. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Listening to your optimistic words, I must ask whether you think it is appropriate for the European statistical system to regard as an employee or an employed worker a person who has fled a country for economic reasons, such as from Spain to South America, from Hungary to England, etc. Are you on top of these numbers?

name: Herbert REUL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It is possible to discuss statistical issues very much and frequently. But if you have made basic assumptions, then you have to persevere with them in the long term, otherwise you have no comparative figures. Incidentally, this question of statistics does not help at all in the question of whether we can get growth going. The question depends on whether we have sound government finances, whether we have smart business investment, and whether we have regulations that encourage companies to create jobs. That is the answer that needs to be given, not statistics. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned Ireland as one of the countries that apparently is doing well. Other than the fake figures on GDP which are boosted by Google and Microsoft, etc., which barely pay a cent in tax in our country, what evidence, what information, do you have that things are growing in Ireland? Because I can tell you one thing for sure: for the vulnerable it is complete and utter hell. A few more specifics please, rather than sound bites that you might have picked up in the Financial Times, which is rubbish.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Just ask the people of Ireland, the majority. And take a look at how economic development has developed there. I think it's huge how you got out of such difficulties. I am not saying that everything is fine. It's not all good. We just have to make a damn hard effort. I am just saying that the Irish, the Irish Government, the Spanish Government, the Portuguese Government and also the former Greek Government have done something that is successful. And success can be measured and experienced. That doesn't mean everything is top, not at all. (Interjections from Mr. Flanagan: "Rubbish, you know nothing.") In my political life, and this has been going on for a few years, I have often seen that there are political forces that do not deal with arguments, but who, by roaring or insulting or denigrating, think that they have leased the truth. There is not only one truth. Most of the time, life is complicated. That is why we must make an effort to solve problems. Sayings are not enough.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Mr Flanagan, please stop shouting. This Parliament, this is not a good place for you to shout here. There's a different culture here, please adapt to it. I did not give you the floor to interrupt Congressman Reul later. He has also honored you, you should do the same! Please keep that in mind.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: - Madam President, if an independent observer were to see an economy with a growth outlook of 1.5%, an unemployment forecast of 11%, and inflation close to zero, I would say that he would have to do something in economic policy to resolve the situation. The European Central Bank is doing so, interest rates are close to 0% and yet the euro area has savings – a current account surplus – of 3.5%. That is, interest rates are sunk and private savings are brutal.  Therefore, we need to mobilisation these savings, we need to mobilisation that investment capacity to get Europe to work and that is where the Juncker plan goes, but it is not enough. It is not enough because we need a fiscal policy that is capable of mobilizing these savings, we need to solve the liquidity trap in which we live and that the European Commission does not only recommend neutral policies. We need a fiscal union that will finally solve the crisis in the euro area.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I am very concerned that with your forecasts we will be invited to dance on the edge of a chasm. Indeed, the growth you are talking about is a mixture of lower oil prices, changes in the value of the euro, liquidity thrown at continuous jets by the Central Bank in the flames of private bank speculation and internal and external economic wars, without creating stable jobs, without reducing inequality and precariousness. We will not build a modern Europe, a strong economy or sustainable development with austerity and social disruption everywhere. Why, moreover, do you not refer to the work of economists at the Central Bank, who believe that the unemployment rate will remain in double digits, including in 2017? The growth you are talking about is the swelling of the capital market against labour and the environment, which can prepare for another financial crash. It is to avoid austerity, to invest heavily in training and education, skilled employment, innovation and research, and in the development of services that contribute to human and ecological development. It is also necessary to dismantle the straitjacket that encloses the Greek people. Both the general interest and the interest of European integration require change.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). – The spring economic forecasts confirm that, despite the sacrifices of the people, the billions of state-supported large enterprises show that the capitalist recovery is uncertain. The risk of another recession is visible. The different management prescriptions do not concern the people but the lesser or greater damage or aid to large enterprises and urban states. That is why in Greece, and with a SYRIZA-ANEL government, a new memorandum is being prepared. Not only do the people not see their losses being made up for, but there are also new taxes, reductions in wages and pensions, further demolition of insurance and a reduction in social spending in order to create surpluses to pay the debt. Peoples, whether in times of crisis or in times of capitalist development, can only expect an escalation of the unpopular attack, for budgetary discipline, for structural changes, for "investments". The only way out for the benefit of the people is to leave the European Union, write off the debt and socialise the concentrated means of production.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, like many colleagues, I welcome these cautious signs of economic recovery in the EU but at the same time we do have to be realistic. We cannot forget that these signs are mainly due to external factors like low oil prices, a weak euro and the supporting programme of the ECB.  We also cannot be blind to important economic differences between Member States, as well as crucial regional differences. Looking at my country, the economic situation of my constituency, the West Midlands, is profoundly different from the one in London. As long as these differences are not tackled in a structural way, it will be difficult for us to address economic growth in the EU.  Therefore, I am convinced that a lot remains to be done to link to a sustainable growth path to help SMEs find the right access to financing, and to tackle youth unemployment in a serious way. There are three main structural regulatory challenges that we need to tackle in the coming months, which could contribute towards a sustainable growth path. A social reform of the economic governance rules with enough flexibility for Member States; making an ambitious European investment plan operational; and a swift and ambitious reform of the European Capital Markets Union.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, just to contradict what that Member across there said, the majority of people in Ireland do not agree. Thirty-five percent support the current government. Do the damned maths. Growth in Ireland may well be one of the best in the EU. One of the reasons we will be given is structural reform. The headline looks good but, behind the headline, it is hell for the most vulnerable in Irish society.  Structural reform has meant bullying those who are least able to fight back. Structural reform requires our government to urinate down the backs of our people while demanding we appreciate the free shower. Talking about the most vulnerable is abstract. So let us talk about Breda. Breda has Alzheimer’s. Breda is happy in her home. Structural reform says Breda would be better off in a private nursing home. Reality says otherwise. However, structural reform demands that reality is manipulated. Reality says Breda will not live much longer if she is moved from her home. Structural reform says she will thrive. We know who is lying. GDP – what does it mean? It does not mean happiness, it means hell! That is what it means.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 25 million European citizens are out of work. In Italy, 82 000 companies have gone bankrupt since the beginning of the crisis and 1 million jobs have been lost. In Italy, it has risen from 20% of young unemployed people in 2007 to 40% in 2013, and unemployment continues to rise. These are the real, real numbers of a crisis that is by no means outdated. How can the Commission say, in view of these figures, that the recovery has the wind in its sails? I, like 60 million Italians, am still waiting to see the economic recovery announced by Mario Monti in 2012, when he saw the light at the end of the crisis tunnel. That light, however, was the beacon of the train, a train called Europe. The Europe of absurd treaties and sacrifices. A train driven by those who defend the interests of banks, finance and strong powers. A train that must stop immediately and immediately change direction. Ladies and gentlemen, we are on that train and we have a very great responsibility. Let's stop that train before it overwhelms everyone. Let us stop this Europe before it is too late.

name: Paul TANG
text: – The growth rates give the impression of a united Europe. A cautious economic recovery everywhere, but what those figures do not show are the underlying big differences. In Germany, unemployment is lower than ever and in Greece one in four people are unemployed. We expect the European semester to be a reconciliation. And it has to be more than a circus of reports and recommendations.  The country-specific recommendations are totally inadequate. Germany and the Netherlands have a high trade surplus, but are only addressed on the rail market or on the pension system. So the rules are arbitrary, hapsnap, that's not enough. This does not lead to mutual trust, but rather reinforces the contradictions. Every country will have to contribute. A balanced approach is needed, desperately needed.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Madam President, the good news is that the indicators of recovery have been reinforced, even if prudently. Within this context, questions of economic governance have become vital, especially in the Eurozone. We need effective governance mechanisms to promote and enhance the emerging conditions of recovery. Those introduced these past years to buttress the Eurozone need simplification and democratic accountability; beyond that, though, some argue that further structural deepening is needed to compensate in part for deficiencies in the Eurozone’s design. Now, they claim, is the right time to carry out these partial changes. However, the fundamental problem facing the Eurozone beyond economic stagnation is the growing economic divergences between regions and national economies.  Parts of the Eurozone system are benefiting from an internal under-valuation. This allows them to maximise sales of their output within the zone. They thereby achieve better scale economies for their output, which helps them penetrate better in non-Eurozone markets. Meanwhile, other parts of the euro system are internally overvalued, which makes them uncompetitive both within and outside the Eurozone. To correct this, they can only carry out a painful internal devaluation, creating huge problems without guaranteeing success. Partial deepening of the Eurozone’s governance structures, on the basis of the existing structural imbalance, leads only to increased…  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – The investment plan announced by the President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, the actions of the European Central Bank, the positive economic climate, also because of the low price of oil, are circumstances that are on our hands. We are all aware that we still have problems within Europe, european economies, budgetary balance is a problem in many countries, public administration reforms, pension reforms, labour law reforms, there is a need to change the education system in many places. Economic growth at the moment is simply not to be used just to bring this economic growth from hand to mouth, as we say in Slovenia, but to actually reform the countries well. And one more piece of advice: let us not look for problems outside the borders of the countries, we have to solve the most problems in the Member States themselves.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Commissioner, growth in the European Union cannot exist unless the policy of austerity is abandoned, unless the issue of debt is settled by writing off the shameful debt. With regard to Greece, I would like to note that Mr Draghi has illegally excluded my country from the credit relaxation programme. Thus, while spending 60 billion euros a month on the purchase of government bonds and private debt, it has imposed credit suffocation on Greece that needs credit, both to boost liquidity in the real economy and to enable the Greek government to meet its debt obligations. This is because the ECB acts as Greece's lender and not as a supposedly independent monetary authority. The conflict of interest within the ECB will cease to exist when the European Central Bank leaves the troika, as decided by the European Parliament, adopting on 10 March the amendment I tabled calling for the ECB to be evicted from the troika, as also requested by the Advocate General of the Court of Justice of the European Union, Pedro Cruz Villalón, in Case C-62/14.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, Dear Mr. Commissioner, we must be very objective. The data is favorable, positive, however, as you said yourself is based on the low price of oil and so to speak Draghi's moves. This cannot be part of our medium-term growth strategy, because the only thing it can be for us is a real economy.  That is why I would like to highlight in particular the two sectors that are the great potential of Europe and have not been fully exploited. One of them is certainly tourism that we talk about too little at the level of Europe, we talk too little about the potential of tourism, which unfortunately becomes less competitive in the world, and we have destroyed e.g. shipbuilding ourselves. That is why I would like to stress in particular that I expect, firstly, an efficient Juncker Fund that will really boost investment, and secondly, I expect the rapid realisation of the Energy and Digital Union. These are ways in which we can grow in the medium term.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). – The numbers are prospering, ladies and gentlemen, and the people are suffering. The profits of monopolies are increasing and workers are in hell. The reality is quite different from that mentioned in the report. Unemployment across Europe is rising. Malnutrition is increasing, shop closures are continuing and there are still suicides of people who cannot afford it. In order to escape this situation, we must stop the strangulation by the lenders and in particular the strangulation of the Greek people – the strangulation of Greece. Let me give you just one thing: over the years they have given us EUR 226 billion and we have given back EUR 270 billion, that is, an additional EUR 43 billion!

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Economic growth in the European Union in 2015 may be a small silver lining. In reality, however, we have to look at this very critically and question it. We know full well that external factors are primarily responsible for this low growth. These external factors are the low exchange rate of the euro compared to other currencies, that is the ECB's quantitative easing, and it is, of course, the price of oil. This is not sustainable growth, and that is why it must be critically questioned. A second point that must be viewed critically and critically: the reality in the Member States is, after all, quite different – it has already been mentioned today. If you take the growth rates of Ireland or Spain, and if you then take Cyprus with negative growth, then we know that the Member States have not implemented the structural reforms, that there is no fiscal consolidation, and that is why this is a figure that does not really help us. The third point is this: we must, of course, compare Europe with other global economic blocs. I say to you that the United States has economic growth of 3.4% this year, and China has one of 7%. This puts into perspective the 1.8% we have. What to do? The economic sustainability must be established, the unemployment rate must be reduced, the public debt must be reduced, the budgets must be consolidated and structural reforms must be implemented.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam President, positive change does not happen on its own. The result is a combination of measures. It is not only public or private investment that can result in long-term and sustainable growth, nor will only reforms or fiscal consolidation lead to growth. It takes a smart combination of everything.  Europe as a whole is heading in a positive direction. This is shown by these latest spring forecasts of 2015. However, some Member States are more successful and some less successful, and are surprised by their negative or positive rates. Examples of successful ones show that determination is needed in economic policymaking, reorganisation, putting untapped resources into operation, innovation, investment in science, new technologies and manufacturing solutions. Determined, courageous, smart and open governments restore the trust of the public, entrepreneurs, investors, changing trends. From these examples we must learn all and build a Europe that is growing at rates of 3 and more percent.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). – The text of the Commission's forecasts for 2015, which we are discussing today, is of a strong ideological nature. It attempts to justify the austerity policies in place by distorting the numbers many times. I will give you a simple example: the Commission is talking to us about development, supposedly, in Greece in 2014. The reality is, if you read the figures, that the supposed "increase" in national income at constant prices, because there was deflation, i.e. a fall in prices, in fact, in absolute terms, was a "decrease". So reality is distorted. The Commission is trying to impose deregulation of industrial relations – this is the essence of its programme – which is contrary to international human rights protection treaties. For example, Greece has again been condemned by both the Committee on the European Social Charter and the International Labour Organisation for violating fundamental rights enshrined in international labour conventions as well as in the European Social Charter.... (The Chair interrupts the speaker)

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this has been a very rich and very lively discussion. The European economic forecast has rarely benefited from such a strong conjunction of supporting factors. However, these are expected to be largely temporary and the legacy of the crisis will continue to be felt for years to come. In order to make the recovery sustainable and avoid the risk of falling back into negative growth, it will be essential to invigorate more permanent growth drivers. Three sets of actions are imperative. First, a coordinated boost to investment. Many of you have already mentioned this. It could be achieved by reorienting public expenditure towards more growth-enhancing investment and by swiftly implementing the investment plan for Europe. Second, a renewed commitment to growth-enhancing structural reforms and reforms in product, services and labour markets that increase productivity and foster investment, which are key to enhancing the euro area potential growth. Reforms implemented in recent years in some Member States are starting to bear fruit, and accommodative monetary policies help facilitate their implementation and enhance their effectiveness. Third, the continued pursuit of fiscal responsibility. The current broadly neutral aggregate fiscal stance is appropriate in the light of the gradual recovery. Yet, in order to address both the short- and medium-term challenges Europe faces, Member States with fiscal space should seize opportunities to step up useful investment, while those with large deficits can consolidate debts. Everywhere, the composition of public finance can be designed in a more growth-friendly manner.  These three actions have been the economic priorities of the Juncker Commission since its first day in office. They were the guidance given in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, and the package of country-specific recommendations we adopted last week fully reflects these key priorities to reinvigorate growth and employment in the European Union. Under this new Commission, we have revised our policy coordination process to promote better implementation of the recommendations. So far, about 55% of the recommendations to Member States from last year have recorded at least some progress in their implementation. The ongoing recovery is an opportunity for all stakeholders to redouble their efforts. Let us not miss this opportunity, and let us make sure we act on the new recommendations.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The projected growth rate for 2015 is 1.5% compared to 0.9% in 2014. This mechanical increase is due to the improvement of external factors such as the fall in the price of a barrel of oil, the fall of the euro and the massive injection of liquidity by the European Central Bank (ECB). In addition, ECB economists say that despite the recovery, the unemployment rate will remain in double digits by 2017. That is why there is no reason to rejoice because this growth is only a temporary rebound that will not be confirmed in the coming years. That is why the economic policy of the Brussels Commissioners needs to be thoroughly reviewed and the Member States should be given back freedom. Finally, I take this opportunity to denounce the scandalous integration of certain criminal activities such as prostitution in the calculation of GDP. No one is fooled by this attempt at diversion, which serves only to justify the ultra-austerity policies pursued by the European Commission.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next point is the debate on jerzy buzek's oral question to the Commission on the monitoring of human resources by ACER on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (O-000028/2015) (B8-0118/2015) (2015/2627(RSP)).

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Vice-Chairman of the ITRE Committee. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am speaking on behalf of the chairman, Jerzy Buzek, and therefore on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy – which is also represented here by other Members who will certainly be speaking in this debate – to ask the Commission very strongly for an answer on certain points in the question, which relate to significant compliance with our energy policy.  We are all very aware that over the years there has been a growing need for an EU energy policy, there is also a legal basis with the Treaty of Lisbon. There is, however, a very strong need for the integration of the various national markets towards the creation of a single European market. In this respect, Parliament has worked legislatively over the past few years and we have arrived at the so-called third energy package, which contains very significant rules, a whole series of implementing regulations.  I call on the Commission – and in particular you, Commissioner, to also make an active spokesperson for it – to emphasise the fact that our objectives, which are always very ambitious, must, however, be just as ambitious, as much tenacity in the implementation phase, otherwise we are making great objectives but then we are not achieving them because we are not setting in motion the necessary instruments, the necessary resources.  I am thinking in particular of the third energy package. I was in Parliament, like other Members, when we launched it, but we are very deficient, as we know, in the implementation phase. Not all the rules laid down have been implemented in all countries, in all Member States: in some, yes, but in others these objectives are still a long way off. And there is also a strong asymmetry between the reality of the different countries, which makes our European market very limp. That is why – and I stress this – this attention to the need to proceed more concretely in our policies as well. In particular, the question concerns the case of the implementation of the obligations provided for in the regulation called REMIT (the regulation for the monitoring of the wholesale energy market). With this 2011 regulation, it is expected that from this year ACER – the European agency that has been entrusted with coordinating national energy regulators – will be given, in addition to the tasks it already has as a coordinating body of regulators, also the task of monitoring the wholesale market. And as early as this year it should look at a very large number – I do not know if we are recalling this here, in the question, but it is a very, very considerable number – of contracts, of transactions that have been carried out, but on which we are not sure that they correspond to those criteria, those rules of transparency, those rules of fairness that we foresee. ACER therefore faces an absolutely demanding task for our mandate and must do so as from October of this year. But we have noted, in the hearings that we regularly hold in committee with all the agencies that deal with matters that are also within our competence, that it has absolutely no human strength and the appropriate resources to do so. So we ask the Commission: what do you think? If this monitoring task fails, what happens in the European market? Is there more certainty or is there more uncertainty? Is there more transparency or is there more opacity? That is why we are asking precisely to assess this situation, to predict what will happen if ACER is not able to carry out this task.  We would also point out that the partial authorization that has been given to supplement the resources it currently has with about 15 units is insufficient. They calculated with a very accurate study that it takes at least 45 units of a certain level. I know that the Commission has adopted – and I agree with it – a policy of constraints and sobriety for staff, including cuts, and we often oblige the agencies and also our parliamentary institutions, the Commission and the Council, when they make requests for enlargement, first of all to see whether there is a possibility of a review of the distribution of staff within it. All this is absolutely right. But here, it seems, there is no possibility of using internal resources or even of having experts from the national authorities who, at times, are already under-equipped for the tasks they have. So there is an invitation to examine the situation well, to take responsibility for these obligations and to provide solutions.  I will end with another final remark in the few seconds I have left. We have a flaw, which we are also proposing again in the digital union: large drawings and a few concrete implementation steps. This is a great damage for Europe, because then it remains the Europe – which is criticized by many – of the proclamations but poor achievements.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank my dear colleague Ms Toia for her question and for her contribution. I am here just to deliver the following statement on behalf of Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete who unfortunately cannot be here today.  The Commission shares the view of the European Parliament that ACER will play a key role in the compilation and proper functioning of the Internal Energy Market (IEM). The implementation by ACER of the remit which ensures the effective monitoring of the wholesale energy market is essential for the functioning of the IEM. The Commission is committed to ensuring that the agency is adequately equipped to perform all its relevant tasks. It has so far ensured that the level of funding allocated to the agency is sufficient and will be vigilant and propose additional funding when these prove necessary. When carrying out its assessment, the Commission will also consider the Energy Union framework strategy adopted in February this year, 2015, which has further emphasised ACER’s role in completing the EU’s internal energy market.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work. English is a very simple expression – there is no threads. Imagine now that you, Commissioner, would ask me to plough one ten-hectare field at the beginning of spring and give me a shovel in my hands. Well, I'd probably plough that field too — if not this year, then maybe next year, well, maybe next year, until I finish it. This work would be very slow and counterproductive.  We are in fact in exactly the same situation. The European Union has therefore adopted a law, a regulation on the monitoring of both electricity and gas wholesale markets. We have an agency in place to do this. But like you would give me a shovel in my hand and say, 'Go through that ten-hectare field', that is not giving us enough money, but asking the agency to do work that it cannot actually do.  What is the result of this? The result is that our European consumers are actually suffering from a possible lack of competition, which cannot even be really identified in order to be able to address their question. So there is indeed a request for you, Commissioner, to look again, to find the necessary funds and to reallocate them so that this work can be carried out, because indeed there is no thread with threads. Thank you! (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, there is something I would like to understand, because it seems that for Mr Kariņš the issue is only the number of staff of ACER. Is it possible to speak only about the number of staff when talking about the task to detect and deter market abuse? Is that the only issue?

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: blue-card answer. – In order to do a task, the first prerequisite is to make sure that you have the tools to do the task. The tools do not mean that everything will be done, and if you had the tools, then everything would be fine. But without the tools, without the funds to have the staff, it is impossible to do the task. So I would see that as square number one. If we have a task, if we have a regulation, we need to enforce that regulation and we need to provide the tools to do the work.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, every single day more than 500 million Europeans rely on having electricity in their power circuits, heat in their radiators, and gas for their stoves and boilers. It is a thing we take for granted, and indeed rightfully so. When it comes to energy, it has to just work. But someday, Commissioner, it very well might not work. I need not tell you that maintaining, running and supervising the energy infrastructure of Europe is no small feat. That is exactly why we need a strong, active and engaged ACER that can supervise it all and tackle the problems faced by Europe as we move towards an Energy Union and a true internal energy market.  The remit, of course, is the most pressing issue at hand, but before us lies a long list of obstacles to be removed before we can achieve the Energy Union that Europe needs: real infrastructure bottlenecks between European countries prohibiting the free flow of energy across borders due to the lack of transmission capacity, as you know; and artificial energy bottlenecks, where available transmission capacity is intentionally under-utilised or blocked outright, fragmenting further the internal energy market. To combat this, we need ACER to just work, but without manpower it will not.  Commissioner, when will the Commission provide ACER with the necessary financial resources to handle its obligation on the remit? That is my first question. When will the Commission come forward with concrete and detailed information on how and when the mandate and powers of ACER will be expanded, and will the Commissioner guarantee that such a proposal would be accommodated by the much-needed increase for the ACER budget, keeping also in mind that new responsibilities must also come with additional resources?

name: Marek Józef GRÓBARCZYK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab ACER plays an extremely important role within the energy union currently being created. This is particularly important in terms of reporting and control of energy markets. It is not possible to manage well without adequate information, especially in terms of energy prices and flow.  As rapporteur for the Energy Union report, I wanted to pay particular attention to the need to increase ACER's resources and resources, as this will condition the proper integrity of national energy markets. Moreover, the Energy Union is imposing new tasks on the Agency, significantly expanding its participation in the negotiation and monitoring of external markets. Without reliable information and relevant information, it is not possible to put in place solutions that will build the Energy Union properly.  On this occasion, particular attention should be paid to the need for deeper cooperation between the Agencies and the national energy authorities responsible for energy management in each Member State. This is of great importance in terms of creating a common energy policy in line with the policies of the individual Member States of the European Union.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we need a European Energy Union in order to strengthen our energy security and achieve our climate and environmental objectives. This can only be achieved through a strong system of governance which ensures that Member States do not pull in different directions and pursue contradictory policies. Above all, it must ensure that we increase cross-border energy flows to deliver a genuine, functional single market for energy. This is precisely why we have an agency like ACER. As previously mentioned, ACER has been given increased responsibilities within the third energy package. However, it is crystal clear that it lacks the resources needed to meet all those responsibilities. ACER itself has identified the need for 118 members of staff but has been approved resources for only 77 members of staff. As a result of this, crucial actions related to its remit are being postponed at a time when action must take place faster than ever before in order to build a true European Energy Union. So my question to the Commission is, what vision does the Commission have for the development of ACER’s tasks and responsibilities? Most urgently, how does the Commission envisage closing the gap in funding and budget requirements that we are facing now?

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Commission President Juncker, when he took office, he started with a very capful announcement. He said the new Commission wanted to be big on big things and small in small ones. I took that statement with some skepticism at the time. I don't think you can build big things without paying attention to the little ones. In the current situation, when it comes to financing ACER, this is precisely the problem we are facing again. The Union proclaims great things: it proclaims an Energy Union, the Commission appoints a special Vice-President, Maroš Šefčovič, for the Energy Union, and adopts an energy security strategy.  ACER itself is being assigned tasks that go far beyond the tasks it has carried out so far, and when it comes to small things, it is practiced to create the necessary conditions and to provide it with the necessary resources, then somehow the Commission's attention disappears and runs out. This is a very important issue. ACER is a guarantee that the big plans that the Commission cherishes in the context of the Energy Union, in the context of the unification and interconnection of the European energy market, can also be put into practice.  Moreover, it is not just the energy market. In general, it is a question of trust in the EU institutions that we face. If the Commission deploys tasks to one of its institutions and does not provide the necessary resources to ensure that it is able to carry out the tasks properly and fully, it will encode in the system that that institution will fail, and sooner or later consumers, whether retail consumers or market participants, will experience this on their own skin. And what are they going to conclude from that? They will conclude that the institutions of the Union are not functioning, they are not able to carry out their tasks. Therefore, if we want European voters and European energy market participants to have confidence in the European institutions, it is essential that we provide the necessary resources to do the task. And when we talk about consumers, it should also be bearing in mind that ACER's task is, inter alia, to eliminate market disruptions that may mean higher energy prices that consumers may need.  Is the Commission determined to do everything possible to ensure that European consumers have access to energy at the lowest possible price, by enforcing competition on the market, or not? My final question to the Commission is whether you are determined to provide the necessary resources for ACER to operate later this year, or at the latest in its 2016 budget?

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ACER already has very important tasks today which, as envisaged by REMIT, will be even more onerous from October 2015. No one can know exactly how much more human resources will be needed, but we believe that the request of the ITRE Committee – of which I am honoured to be a member – of more officials and resources than has already been foreseen is justified. Serious irregularities can occur in the energy market and, given the level of economic interests at stake and the importance of the future energy union, we do not think it is a wise decision to skimp on staff. We would like to take this opportunity to highlight another critical issue, since we also consider it unwise to be broad-minded about the possible exemptions provided for by REMIT, which allows for far too many exceptions on communication obligations: we do not understand, for example, why companies in the same group should not report data relating to internal transactions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, given that there are thousands and thousands of officials in the European Union, it does not seem so impossible to train some officials who may be sleeping a little on their feet, perhaps they have little work: I believe that there are many of them in the European Union. And so it would be helpful, without spending too much money, to get these people to go to work in the energy agency, ACER. But I also ask myself: but we who want energy, which we want to control, why do we not want the Russian gas pipeline? We are talking about energy: we want to improve energy, but then Europe is against the Russian gas pipeline. Just because Putin's here? Then it's a nonsense. That is, on the one hand you want to show something, but in concrete things you make war on Putin because Putin is the bad guy. Instead of waged war where it has to be done, that is, against the issues of illegal boats, we are going to break the boxes with Putin, so they are destroying our businesses too, in this case also Italian companies.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think one of the exciting aspects of being involved in the Industry, Research and Energy Committee (ITRE) at this point in time is the whole enthusiasm for an energy union and the proposals made by an enthusiastic Commissioner Cañete. Certainly, that is something that will be very good for Europe – not just for markets, but particularly also for citizens, because we can help to connect Europe and guarantee security, diversity supply, and President Juncker’s target of being the number 1 renewable energy source in the world. But to do that, we need a properly functioning market and we need proper supervision and action, and ACER has a huge role to play in that. That is why we are so concerned here because it is quite obvious that it does not have the human resources to do the task and, if it cannot do the task, then we are not going to have a combined and coordinated approach across the Member States, but regulators in different Member States taking different approaches.  The Commissioner has said to propose additional funding when this will prove necessary, well surely it is proving necessary now, and surely we can get the people. It is not a whole lot of people, but people with the proper qualifications to do the job, and to create the confidence that we are serious about an Energy Union and that we are going to make it happen.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: – Madam President, one crucial dimension of the Energy Union is the completion of a fully integrated internal energy market. This cannot be achieved without a strengthening of the role of ACER. Europe’s energy system is still too fragmented. Building a well-functioning, well-connected internal energy market will bring down retail prices in Europe, contribute to the fight against energy poverty in my region, the Northwest of England, and across the EU, while at the same time strengthening EU energy security.  ACER plays a key part in creating the seamless internal market as it deals with cross—border issues and enhances interconnections within the EU. From October 2015, ACER will also monitor the wholesale market to detect market abuse. The Energy Union Action Plan foresees the reinforcement of the European regulatory framework. Commissioner, as my colleagues have asked, will this be accompanied by the additional budget for human resources that ACER has requested?

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, the importance of ACER is growing with the size and complexity of the European energy market. As the Single European Energy Market has not yet been opened up, the role of joint supervision of fair behaviour is all the more important. For the reasonable functioning of the market, we need a REMIT system monitoring extreme variations in energy trade. We all know that sufficient technical and personnel equipment for the Agency is essential for such a complex task. Unfortunately, ACER is facing a shortage of people and funding. ACER's activities cannot be substituted by national regulators who have a different, independent and irreplaceable role in the system. That is why I, too, join the question: How will the Commission address this urgent problem?

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Madam President, the Vice-President for Energy Union has said several times that Europe needs functioning energy markets and ACER to oversee the markets. So that agency needs adequate resources to deliver on its tasks. But it not only lacks adequate resources right now, it also lacks the right toolbox to deliver its tasks because it struggles to get information from the Member States regarding projects that are ongoing. I think, therefore, that in addition to adequate resources we also need the right toolbox and mandatory information-sharing so that ACER actually knows what is going on in the energy markets.  This is not only about fighting protectionism in the Member States, it is also about delivering an energy market that really functions and gives people lower prices. It is also about energy security, considering the situation in Russia.

name: Roger HELMER
text: – Madam President, my good friend and colleague, Jerzy Buzek, tells us that the staffing of ACER is insufficient for the task we have set out for it in the 2011 REMIT regulation; he calls for 30 additional staff. I am sure that he is right in his diagnosis, but I am not quite sure that I share his prescription. Rather than increase the staff, we must question the scope of REMIT. The famous Scottish economist, Adam Smith, described the behaviour of markets when thousands of economic operators make deals and decisions based on their own economic self-interest. He called it the ‘invisible hand’. Modern analysts might call it an ‘emergent property’. It is a general rule that legislative interference in markets almost invariably makes them perform worse rather than better. Of course, no one imagines that a modern economy can operate without appropriate regulation and supervision, but we do not need detailed analysis of each and every deal. Rather than employing more bureaucrats, we should curtail the scope of REMIT.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Madam President! We heard the Commissioner say today that we must be vigilant with regard to ACER. It is clear that proper supervision and enforcement also require both competent and adequate resources. In this context, I find it particularly worrying that, in the case of ACER, this has not been taken into account when the Commission is now making very ambitious plans for a European Energy Union.  Better use and sharing of European energy is therefore essential if we are to make Europe independent of putin's whims and for us to make European companies more competitive and to create more sustainable growth. However, it is clear that, in order to get there, we still need a strong and also a powerful supervisory authority, and this is particularly relevant when, both in the context of the Energy Union and in relation to the electricity capacity objective, we foresee stronger regional cooperation. That is why there is a need for additional staff ing.

name: Martina WERNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has ACER is, after all, the agency for the cooperation of national energy regulators. And that is precisely what is crucial, namely that the regulators of the 28 Member States cooperate more closely and also better together, because, as we know, electricity does not stop at national borders. The regulatory authorities of the Member States are also doing a good job, but national authorities naturally have national interests. This makes it all the more important for an independent European agency to regulate the cross-border flow of electricity in Europe, solely in the interests of the European internal market. At the moment, ACER cannot do justice to this important task because its decision-making power is severely limited. ACER, however, needs a stronger mandate, especially with regard to the formation of the Energy Union. The transition from 28 national energy markets to a European energy market cannot be achieved without strong European market supervision. My question to the Commission is this: does the Commission intend to extend ACER's tasks and powers? And can you please tell us more about this?

name: Dawid Bohdan JACKIEWICZ
text: – The REMIT Regulation imposes on ACER the task of detecting and preventing abuses in wholesale energy markets. However, the side effect of such measures – actions of course needed – may be the choking of price investment signals, which are, after all, the foundation and guarantor of ensuring the long-term security of europe's energy supply.  The Commission is promoting a single-market energy market as a reference model for Europe. However, this model requires free price formation. Methods for detecting and combating abuses must therefore distinguish between cases of price increases caused by a resource deficit and cases of unjustified profit abuse. In view of the long-term security of energy supply challenges in many European countries and the possibility of further deepening them through the implementation of the fraud detection mechanism, does the Commission plan to abandon the dogma of the single-stock market in Europe to the dual-stock market, namely the energy and power markets?

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you also to the Commissioner and Commissioner Cañete, to whom he will report on our requests on this subject.  At the last plenary session, we decided to postpone discharge for certain EU agencies because it was felt that further study was needed on their accounts. This is not the case with ACER. ACER is an agency that operates on one of the great issues on which the future of the European Union is at play: we have the major traditional infrastructure networks, namely TEN-T, we have e-TENs in the digital market and we have TEN-E in the energy market.  We have two challenges, in addition to the cultural challenges, which I look at with particular attention. In the economic field, the two challenges are: the digital single market and the energy market. We have to win them and to win them we need regulators who are capable of doing their job.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: – As the European Parliament, we must ensure that European taxpayers' money is spent where it can have the most added value. Well, in the field of energy, it is clear that Europe can indeed have added value, and we must therefore ensure that the necessary resources are spent on it.  On 25 February, this Commission presented its proposal for a European Energy Union. Among other things, the proposal is a step in the right thinking about better connections between Member States, and we encourage that. The free flow of energy must ensure that we get more competitive wholesale prices in the European energy market, which will benefit consumers and businesses.  But in order for that system to function properly, we also need control systems.
