Unfortunately, I note that the European Commission is failing to provide sufficient resources to ACER, the energy regulator's cooperation agency, to fulfil that task. As rapporteur of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy for the 2016 budget, I therefore call for funds to be shifted so that the agency will have the necessary means of operation.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we are at a crossroads where we must decide which path we want to follow. We need more Europe and to put the necessary resources to build a Union capable of facing the challenges that arise in order to respond to the needs of citizens. We won't be able to make it strong without consolidating its structures. For this reason, we believe that devoting a third of the resources deemed necessary for the good operation of the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators can only lead to the blockade and provide the image of inefficiency that the most Eurosceptics want to transfer to the public. It is our obligation, inherited from the founding fathers, to deepen European integration. The problems we face have long exceeded the area of action of States. Therefore, in this age of globalisation, in which markets and people are increasingly interrelated, the answer must be more Europe and, in the specific case at hand today, more Europe means more human resources for the Agency.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Madam President, if we really want to achieve a European Energy Union, we need to fully liberalise the twenty-eight national energy markets, to ensure the integration of these markets by achieving their physical interconnection, but we also need harmonisation of national regulations and monitoring of these markets. That is why we need to strengthen the work of this European agency, both in terms of coordinating the work of national agencies and in terms of monitoring energy markets. We cannot accept negative practices like those that assign additional tasks to the Agency without the necessary resources being given. They de-motivate staff and dilute responsibility.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, energy security must be a permanent concern at the level of the European Union and the Member States. This requires close cooperation between States, enabling them to identify common, cross-border solutions, thus enabling them to rapidly develop their own energy resources. We are at a time when we are facing threats and constraints due to energy dependency, and some Member States are forced to make a number of compromises to ensure their domestic energy needs, but at very high costs. The regulatory measures imposed by REMIT on the angró energy market must ensure the security of the information transmitted and remove any suspicions of market manipulation. That is why we believe that ACER must be strong enough - and here we stress: and well sized - so that it has the capacity to cooperate effectively with national and competent financial authorities. This will enable a reciprocal exchange of information to enable it to track transactions, assess and identify abuses with a view to removing them.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Agency for Energy Regulators has been and is one of the elements of the so-called Energy Package. This package is a comprehensive strategy, defined at European Union level, to privatise and liberalise the energy sector. The strategy is always the same: first, they privatize the public sector; then comes the myrific regulation to solve the problems created with this privatization. In this case, new bureaucracies are coming at national and European level, with greater external control over what is happening in each country, in a strategic area such as energy, which affects all sectors of society horizontally. By imposing standards, codes, market rules, decisions of higher bodies, the objective is only one: to better serve the interests of economic groups in the sector.  We know well the meaning of the talk of more independence and more decision-making powers for the regulator. The result of liberalisation was only one: more profits for the economic groups in the sector, at the expense of more costs for households and businesses. This is how liberalisation is used.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I believe that the European Union Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER) has a key role for the transparency of the wholesale energy market. ACER estimates it needs another 45 full—time staff to effectively monitor energy transactions and thus prevent fraud and market manipulation, which has a negative effect on energy prices and consumer trust. Considering that the Commission has so far only allocated 15 new staff members, I agree that, in order to effectively carry out an important task such as detecting and deterring market abuse, the Commission should allocate sufficient resources.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). – Energy is a development and social good that everyone must have access to, inclusively, in order to stop energy poverty. Energy union must not exacerbate economic and social inequalities in the European Union. At the same time, care must be taken not to turn the energy market into an area dominated by monopolistic energy giants, just as is the case in the oil sector. In Greece, the troika is pressing the government to sell off public property instead of a lentil plate, even in the energy sector, by privatising the small PPC. At the same time, the Commission as a member of the troika is pushing for an increase in VAT, which will lead to an increase in the price of electricity, which will further increase energy poverty as thousands of households already do not have access to electricity. The troika had also for months blocked the implementation of the institution of maturity which would lead to a reduction in the price of energy for energy-intensive Greek industries such as LARCO.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, Dear Mr. Commissioner, in this high house we talk about energy practically every session. Whether we speak in the form of threats or in the form of the need for competitiveness of the European economy, in any case energy is what is in some ways one of the key preoccupations of both this Commission, and us Members. Therefore, the Single Energy European Market is the conditio sine qua non of our competitiveness and definitely ACER must be the model, that mechanism, what will enable the creation of a single energy market and what will eventually enable the competitiveness of the European economy and of course to banish the threats we have in the energy market today.  So I ask the Commission on this oral question – how and at what speed will it allow ACER to truly meet all those expectations we have of it?

name: Claude TURMES
text: – Madam President, we have here an alliance which stretches from the ECR to GUE; I think this is relatively unique when discussing energy matters. So this whole Parliament wants the Commission, but also the Member States, to finally deliver the budget to make it possible for us to have a real European regulatory authority, with ACER, which is functioning.  One big Enron scandal in Europe would set us a decade or two decades back, and without a powerful regulator you cannot organise the cost benefits in a market. It is more expensive on an island than in a larger country. It is always less expensive to organise an energy system in 28 countries than in one country. So this must be a priority for the Juncker Commission, and Mrs van Bossuyt is right: if the Commission does not deliver in the 2015 budget, we should make this a break point in the budget discussions.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank everyone for their interest and contributions to this discussion. The Commission takes good note of the elements and arguments put forward during these interesting debates. I will convey the substance and climate of the current discussion to my dear colleague Arias Cañete, who is responsible for energy. I am sure he will take into account all proposals ahead of the next steps.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – We disagree with the term of ACER's mandate and in particular with the implementation of the third energy package. The aim is to strengthen the single market, a position with which we disagree, as policies to strengthen competition in the single market strengthen the interests of monopolies and multinationals. The transfer of powers by national or independent authorities to the jurisdiction of ACER may act to the detriment of the interests of the peoples. More generally in the market, let alone in the energy market, state control is very important and must have a strong regulatory role. However, in this particular case the request for an increase in funding concerns the need to meet the needs that exist in order to pay the salaries of existing ACER employees and to employ new people in order to discharge existing staff. For these reasons we have decided to abstain.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the European Union has been pursuing a single energy market for two decades. Three legislative energy packages have been adopted, but we are still far from this market because Member States have almost complete sovereignty in energy policy.  The Single Energy Market is not possible without free cross-border energy flows subject to regulatory rules common to all Member States. A strong pan-European Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators is therefore needed to have the necessary human and power resources to lead the single market and ensure uniformity of the rules for the functioning of the energy market in individual countries. ASER has a responsibility not only to ensure the regulatory completion of the internal energy market with the relevant rules and regulations in cross-border energy exchange, but also to coordinate the activities of national regulators in this regard. The new European Energy Union, on which work has begun with a strong political impetus to achieve greater energy security, requires significantly greater coordination and cooperation between Member States on connectivity between energy systems and for open and free trade in energy between them. Only this will allow competition, lower prices for consumers and certainty in everyone's energy supply. I therefore support the increase in the powers and expertise of ASER.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: – The next item is a debate on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law – up to one hour (Article 135 of the Rules of Procedure) The next item is the human rights protection case of Zimbabwe, Itai Dzamara (2015/2710(RSP))

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: author. – Madam President, over two months have passed since the disappearance of Itai Dzamara. This should be a matter of great concern, not just to people in Zimbabwe, but to the wider international community. Most regrettably, it is indicative of the very serious situation in Zimbabwe, which is in a state of economic and political turmoil and where political freedom does not exist. At the same time, we have seen a massive increase in China’s presence in the country. I have to say that we have been discussing the issue of Zimbabwe since my time in this Parliament began – and I have been here 15 years now – and it does not seem to get any better, in spite of some efforts. We constantly defer to the South African Development Community (SADC) and to the African Union and specifically to the regional power, which is South Africa. Given our major role as a provider of humanitarian and development assistance in the region, is it not time that the Commission and the Council again paid attention to Zimbabwe? In particular, I ask that the Council reconsider its decisions of February 2014 and of February this year to scale back almost to zero the targeted sanctions on Zimbabwe.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Itai Dzamara was kidnapped on 9 March 2015. He is an activist, a leader of Occupy Africa Unity Square, a dissident against President Mugabe. Mr Van Orden has already said that there is a situation in Zimbabwe where if you are a dissident against the government you risk being kidnapped, you risk disappearing.  In all of this, for a couple of months now – that is, in February – we have decided to ease sanctions, we have provided 234 million in aid for Zimbabwe. It does not seem to me that this is very consistent with what we are asking for in this resolution, so this should probably be reviewed. In all this there is China, which, unlike us, finances without demanding respect for human rights. And there, too, we should reflect on how we relate to other powers operating in developing countries.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Author. – Itai Dzamara, a human rights activist from Harare, has been missing since 9 March. No one's heard from him since. His wife went to the Central Intelligence Organisation and the court. No one can tell us where he is. The government says he's not in our hands. Whether that is true we do not know, but we are more than two months further and the question is: how is he doing? Is he still safe? Is he still alive is even the question you can ask. It is a signal from us to President Mugabe that he cannot make everything he thinks he can make.  After the 2013 elections in which his party Zanu PF won the majority, Europe revised its relationship with Zimbabwe. That probably couldn't be very different either, because we had been on the same route for a long time. But it didn't help. Meanwhile, palace coups are underway in his political party and the idea of relaxation and normalization is gone, as he has put his wife forward as the new person. That gives me the idea that things are not going to get better in Zimbabwe in the next few years and that we have to be careful that there are not many more people like Itai Dzamara.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: author. – Madam President, we are all watching human rights abuse in Zimbabwe in despair, particularly the case of Mr Itai Dzamara, abducted in March by people unknown. However, it is not the first time that Mr Dzamara has been targeted. He has been beaten and harassed and now detained. By whom? We do not know. The police and intelligence organisations are denying involvement and failing to comply with a High Court order instructing them to search for Mr Dzamara and report on his progress.  This all raises concern about the Mugabe regime and how it deals with political opponents, journalists and activists who dare to criticise the government and state in Zimbabwe. We know that human rights activists in Zimbabwe face severe challenges and restrictions on their work, including political intimidation, harassment, arbitrary arrest and physical violence to them and their families. This is all taking place in the face of a new constitution and a new Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission, both of which were supported by the EU and brought hope to the people of Zimbabwe. The government, police and Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO) must do all they can to identify the location of Mr Dzamara, protect him and bring to justice the thugs who have taken him.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, Itai Dzamara is indeed a young journalist and human rights activist, a pacifist of the Occupy Africa Unity Square movement, an organizer of sit-ins, which has been calling for the resignation of 91-year-old Robert Mugabe, who has been in power since the country's independence in 1980.  Two days before his disappearance, Mr. Dzamara participated in one of these pacifist demonstrations denouncing the country's economic and social situation, and not without reason: unemployment approaching 80%, poverty exceeding 70%, hyperinflation that has ruined the country, a chronic shortage, not to mention the Ebola virus and sexual violence suffered by two-thirds of women.  At the end of 2014, when the crackdown was once again under way, the European Union lifted its sanctions against Zimbabwe. I find it difficult to understand why, and why she has maintained these only with respect to Robert Mugabe and his wife. There is no shortage of oligarchs close to power in the country. There are fears that development aid - EUR 234 million - will benefit them rather than the Zimbabwean population.  So, yes, we must do everything to find out what happened to Itai Dzamara, to protect his wife and political friends. Does the resumption of dialogue with that country at least serve any purpose in this context? That is the specific question I am asking you, Commissioner.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Unfortunately, the fate of Itai Dzamara stands only pars pro toto. Political repression in Zimbabwe continues. For years, there has not been any change from the fact that Mr Mugabe is supposedly now again finding a clear majority in his parliament. His structures definitely want to retain power, and he personally wants to transfer that to his wife. It is ultimately secondary whether he succeeds within the party or whether other cronies share power after his death. The problem is that for the people of Zimbabwe, this party and this structure have really led to a situation that is economically and socially intolerable. And I expect the European Union to take measures here that do not, by means of 'business as usual' cooperation, ensure that the regime makes it a little easier to govern the country.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the When Stevie Wonder said 35 years ago in his famous song "Master Blaster" "Peace has come to Zimbabwe, (...) we've just started," he said of another Zimbabwean. This Zimbabwe today is actually a never-ending nightmare, a distortion of it. The last tragic case in a long chain of human rights violations is the case of Itai Dzamara. The authorities are playing a grotesque confusing game here. You could call it endisappearanceforced , something that the international community outlaws. Zimbabwe has committed itself accordingly. We demand complete clarification. We are asking for his release as long as he is still alive. I hope that this could also be a new beginning. However, we must help. We in the European Union have that in our hands. We can really intervene in this with sanctions in a supportive way.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, freedom of expression is a fundamental right. It implies the right not to be worried about one's opinions and to be able to express oneself freely and without fear. Unfortunately, this principle is not universally applied, and journalist and human rights defender Itai Dzamara seems to have paid the price. Abducted since 9 March, as has been pointed out, he does not appear to be at the centre of the Zimbabwean authorities' concerns. Despite his wife's requests to the Harare High Court, no information about Mr. Dzamara's disappearance is available. No credible investigation appears to be under way as the High Court, which ordered Zimbabwean police and state security officials to begin the search, wanted to be made aware of their progress every fortnight. I would of course like, together with all of us and by this joint resolution, to support the family of Itai Dzamara in its long time, and very much hope that he can be found soon and that he will finally be able to live freely and without fear.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Zimbabwe is Mr Dzamara. Zimbabwe is also his wife, who is undergoing enormous pressure. But Zimbabwe is also dozens, hundreds and thousands of other people, who do not know for an hour, a minute, when something can happen to them. So Zimbabwe is a dictatorship regime. Mr Mugabe is a dictator, and against this background we decide to soften and ease up the sanctions! I am aware that I am speaking to the vacant chairs of the Council on an issue which is completely impossible to comprehend.  This is yet another concrete example, another concrete case, of a country that just confirms that we need to be very consistent in including binding non-negotiable, strong human rights clauses that we are ready to implement, to enforce with clear conditionalities. It is time we did that, I invite the Commission to be thorough on that, and I invite the Council also to be extremely sensitive about drawing wrong conclusions, as it did some time ago, on sanctions.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the usual hypocrisy within the EU institutions continues unabated. The EU gasps in horror at yet another tragedy facing this country but, as usual, says one thing and does another. Why is it that President Mugabe can still visit a European country despite a ban?  But the problem goes a lot further. If human rights activists such as this are being deliberately targeted because individuals had their eyes on the EUR 234 million annual EU grants, then here, in the EU institutions, we ought to look inwardly at the consequences of that grants programme. Because we are responsible for the situation that we have this morning and for other instances where voters’ rights and citizens’ rights in that country are at risk and individuals are also at risk in terms of their personal security and safety.  Let the EU look at itself and the consequences of that grants programme.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the political and economic situation in Zimbabwe is indeed of great concern, and it is right to demand an explanation of the disappearance of Itai Dzamara more than two months ago. This opponent of Mugabe's dictatorial regime has repeatedly denounced the catastrophic situation in his country. But how did we get to this point? Before experiencing famine, misery, AIDS, arbitrary expropriations and the racist killings of white farmers, Zimbabwe was called Southern Rhodesia. This former British colony was one of the most prosperous countries in Black Africa and was its breadbasket. The general view is that it is in particular the "land reform" that has plunged the country into misery and chaos. This "reform" consisted of unceremoniously expropriating, without any compensation, thousands of white farmers whom the country's authorities accused of all evils. If I am generally opposed to the right of interference, which the European Union continues to abuse, how can we remain indifferent to this terrible ethnic cleansing? So, yes, let's demand answers about Mr. Dzamara's disappearance, but let's no longer turn a blind eye to state racism, promoted by an old Marxist dictator, who dreams of being emperor of Monomotapa.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, state-sponsored violence in Zimbabwe has reduced since more than 200 people were killed during the disputed 2008 elections. I am wondering how many people must be killed before state-sponsored violence in Zimbabwe disappears once and for all. The forced disappearance of civil society activist Itai Dzamara echoes the darkest days of Zimbabwe’s political instability. It is only the latest of events that show how in Zimbabwe a worsening of human rights and democracy is taking place, as well as harassment and abuses against human rights defenders, journalists and members of civil society.  I stand by the 83 courageous civil society organisations that called for the immediate release of Itai Dzamara, otherwise demanding the resignation of President Robert Mugabe. Finally, I call on the responsible authorities to stop ignoring the High Court and to comply with this ruling, taking all the necessary measures to find Mr Itai Dzamara and bring all those responsible to justice. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Mr. Frunzulică, I have listened very carefully and I would like to ask you if you really think that after all Zimbabwe, instead of being The Zimbabwe of Stevie Wonder and the gentleman we are looking for, the gentleman who has disappeared, do you think we really need a complete review of the European Union's policy towards Zimbabwe, a state that has disappointed us greatly after all the expectations we have had?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card answer. – On many occasions in the Committee on Development I have maintained that the European Union has to use the leverage of humanitarian aid and of development aid for all these African countries, and other countries, led by dictators, where they do not respect human rights, they do not respect the law – they respect nothing. We should, indeed, use all necessary leverage to put all such countries on the right path to respecting international law and the law in general.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to speak here. I would also like to support, of course, Mr Dzamara. As regards finding him, I wish that this victim of Mr Mugabe's regime be released as soon as possible. However, I think that the view of the European Union should be whole. It should include a look at the support provided by the European Union to various countries, which, as has already been said here, often fail in their direction. Undoubtedly, South Rhodesia has been a relatively successful and relatively wealthy state in its history, and all this has been destroyed by the Mugabe regime. I think that human rights violations, ethnic cleansing, murder, kidnapping, these are precisely the hallmarks of those countries that should not receive any support at all. The European Union should put pressure on these regimes to change. It's not meddling, it's simply demanding the natural rights of man that are universal throughout the world.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the disappearance of Itai Dzamara is of great concern. The situation in Zimbabwe is in a state of shock. Journalists, activists, representatives of non-governmental organisations are being arrested. We therefore condemn the arrests of journalists and activists and it is certain that Zimbabwe must proceed with profound democratic reforms, guarantees of freedom, freedom of thought and expression, freedom of the media, equality, strengthening the rule of law and respect for human rights. We must therefore stop the persecution that is taking place in this region. Violence against women must also be stopped and, of course, there is also a problem with malnutrition in this country. So you realize that the European Union cannot sit idly by. He's got to take action. It cannot provide development aid in a region where there is a massive violation of human rights. Measures are needed here and now.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, freedom of expression is a thorn in the eye of any totalitarian regime. I have personal experience of my youth with the Communist regime, which persecuted political opponents in Czechoslovakia. An example of this is our former President Václav Havel. It is said jokingly that the difference between democracy and totalitarianism is that under totalitarianism there can be freedom of expression, whereas in a democracy there is also freedom after expression. Zimbabwe may be far away, but the European Union must show that human rights must also be defended in its external relations. The effort to free Mr Dzamara is therefore also a struggle for our own European identity. I therefore want the European Union to renew sanctions against Zimbabwe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, we want Zimbabwe Itai Dzamara, we want Stevie Wonder's Zimbabwe, we want a tailor-made Zimbabwe that the European Union needs, the values of the European Union because Zimbabwe is our partner. and we really have to use the tremendous help we give Zimbabwe, over 230 million euros that Zimbabwe gets, and Zimbabwe's response is the dictatorial regime of Mugabe, the person who disappointed this world as well, because when freedom started in Zimbabwe we believed in another Africa, we believed in one democratic Africa and Zimbabwe was a good example and, at one point , almost a model of such Africa.  Today, what do we have? We have great disappointment, and that is why I am calling for the release immediately of the imprisoned person, Mr. Dzamara.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we share the concerns for the welfare of the journalist, human rights defender and leader of Occupy Africa Unity Square, Itai Dzamara.  Previously, human rights defenders abducted in Zimbabwe have usually reappeared after a few weeks. Prior to their release, Zimbabwean civil society could also usually get information about them through informal contacts with members of the security forces. Mr Dzamara was abducted on 9 March and it is a matter of concern that there have been no indications about his situation. The European External Action Service (EEAS), through the EU Heads of Mission in Harare and services in Brussels, is closely following the fate of Mr Dzamara. The European Union seizes every opportunity to convey to the Zimbabwean Government our concerns and to demand that the authorities do everything in their power to restore him to freedom, as well as respect to their legal obligation to report to the court the progress of the investigation. The European Union also reminds the Zimbabwean Government that human rights lie at the core of our partnership and the gradual normalisation of our relations. To mark the second month of this abduction, the European Union missions in Zimbabwe published on 9 May a new statement underlying these concerns and calling on the government of Zimbabwe to ascertain Mr Dzamara’s whereabouts and safety, and to bring to justice those responsible for his abduction. EU statements were previously released on 11 March and 9 April. EU statements have been welcomed by Zimbabwe’s civil society and human rights defenders who expressed their appreciation for the EU’s swift action. The fate of Itai Dzamara was also raised by the head of delegation in Harare during his Schuman Day speech. Vice President Emmerson Mnangagwa described in the parliament on 11 March the kidnapping as a barbaric act and gave assurances that the government was engaged with the relevant departments to investigate this case. So far, the lack of results remains deeply disappointing. This is the situation.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after two further debates.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the dramatic situation of rohingya ethnic minority refugees, including the issue of mass graves in Thailand (2015/2711(RSP)).

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Rohingya people for the United Nations are the most persecuted minority in the world, a veritive ballast that all the states around them want to undo in a way. These people live between the persecution of Buddhists in Myanmar and the flight through sea boats – something we see very similarly in the Mediterranean – from the Bay of Bengal to neighbouring states, states that reject or states such as Thailand, which has inhumane treatment, torture in the southern jungle on the border with Malaysia. With this resolution, we welcome the attitude that has changed on the part of Malaysia and Indonesia, which are taking in these refugees, and we intend to send a strong message to countries such as Thailand and Burma, which will meet at a summit in eight days' time, to change their attitude towards these people and protect those minimum rights, because this is a truly tragic situation.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the In southern Thailand, there are many hidden camps where traffickers detain, torture, sell them in slave-like jobs, or force them to call their families and ask for ransom. Thailand's police chief describes these camps, which have now been found near 30 mass graves, as prison camps. Since the Thai government announced the fight against people smuggling, the traditional escape routes have become more controlled and it is difficult to bring the refugees ashore. This is how the flow of refugees, many of whom want to come to Malaysia by sea, is intensifying. They are Rohingyas from Myanmar and Bangladesh; In 2014, there were at least 25,000 people. Currently, about 8,000 people have been floating in bad boats without water or food on the high seas for weeks or months. Malaysia and Indonesia have refused to land some boats despite extreme exhaustion. It is admirable that Indonesian fishermen have rescued boat refugees on their own initiative. We call on the governments of Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand to adopt at the forthcoming conference a policy that saves the refugees from danger to their lives and grants them asylum. We also call on the Thai Government to continue to combat trafficking in human beings in order to put an end to slave-like exploitation. However, victim protection must play a central role in this. The situation of the Rohingyas in Myanmar is desperate. We therefore call on the Myanmar Government to fundamentally reconsider and change its policy towards the Rohingyas. They must be granted citizenship and the government must take active action against discrimination and persecution.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: author. – Mr President, the problem of migration in the Mediterranean cannot be treated in isolation. The crisis of the Rohingya refugees starkly reminds us of this. It is time we adopted a comprehensive approach to tackle the problem of migration globally. Men, women and children fleeing sectarian violence in Burma and poverty in Bangladesh are dying in camps and abandoned at sea. I welcome efforts to immediately relieve the suffering of the Rohingya. Providing humanitarian aid and states offering temporary protection are critical to the hundreds of migrants at immediate risk. The solution of providing temporary protection, however, will not solve the problem of migration in the long run – not in the Straits of Malacca nor in the Mediterranean. We must first put an end to the networks of smugglers that take cruel advantage of human suffering and desperation. To truly address the problem of migration for good we must engage with countries to take responsibility for the safety and well-being of their citizens. Burma must change its approach towards minorities and recognise the Rohingya as lawful citizens.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, the last few weeks have seen much debate in Europe about our own migrant challenges in the Mediterranean, and the plight of those fleeing their countries from persecution and economic disaster in the Middle East and in North Africa.  The long-suffering and persecuted Rohingya Muslim minority in Burma is now creating the same pattern of push and pull factors in South-East Asia. But I am pleased to note that in the last few days we have seen both Indonesia and Malaysia agree to take up to 7 000 people on a temporary basis, and even today, in the last few hours, the President of Gambia has announced his intention to offer permanent refugee status to all of the Rohingya refugees.  In the longer term, however, the only way to solve the problem is to remove the factors that are forcing people to attempt such perilous journeys. The economic discrimination and persecution against the Rohingya in Burma is a well-documented and long-standing issue and more must be done to tackle it.  I am pleased that the opposition party in Burma of Aung San Suu Kyi has now issued a statement calling for an end to discrimination and to denial of citizenship. We in the European Union should do more to press for changes in our dealings with Burma-Myanmar as it looks to open up its markets and seeks EU aid and investment.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, the mass graves opened in recent weeks in Thailand have revealed to the world the plight of migrants in thailand, interned in appalling conditions, dying of hunger, exhaustion or disease, when families cannot pay their ransom.  The repression of these traffickings pushes these unfortunates by the thousands to go to sea. On board, men, women, children, mostly Bangladeshis, and especially Rohingya fleeing Burma and persecution. They are rejected from all sides. UNHCR is talking about 25,000 people since January, an unprecedented flow in the region since the Vietnam War. Nearly 3,000 migrants have reached the coasts of Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand in recent days, and nearly 8,000 are believed to be in decline in the open sea, seeking refuge.  There, as here, the national authorities are fleeing their responsibilities. Since 2013, the European Union has spent only 325,000 euros on the Rohingya refugee camp in Thailand, a paltry sum.  The Union must do its best to stop persecuting the Rohingya, those damned on earth, in Burma, their country; so that they stop being victims of predators and can be welcomed in good conditions, where they seek refuge.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: author. – Mr President, we are shocked by the discovery of these mass graves in jungle camps in Thailand of Rohingya refugees who were murdered or simply left to die of disease and starvation. The resolution rightly calls on the Thai Government to conduct an immediate and credible investigation into these mass graves.  At the same time, there needs to be a regional solution to the humanitarian crisis at sea with thousands of refugees stranded in very dire conditions. I welcome the commitment by Indonesia and Malaysia to actually take care of these stranded migrants, but we also have to call on all the countries in the region to take their responsibility and at least to participate in the summit in Bangkok at the end of May. We also have to address the root causes of this crisis, and this is the continued persecution and discrimination of Rohingya refugees in Myanmar. The government must change its policy and must make sure that it does all that is necessary to respect the fundamental rights of all people on its territory.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Rohingya chapter is one of the most tragic chapters of our time. The United Nations calls it the most persecuted population. They therefore deserve all our attention and deserve our full efforts. If this does not succeed, it will be very difficult for the region. It is the test of the success of the democratisation process in Myanmar. Just as the Mediterranean refugees are, as it were, a reflection of our humanity for Europe, so the boat refugees are the touchstone for the region. A humanitarian and human rights-compliant solution to the Rohingya problem is a priority. The most important contribution can probably only be made in the region itself. A solution must be found here, and there must be recognition of the Rohingya as a population group. We in the European Union also have the opportunity to intervene within the framework of our programmes. We are the largest trading partner for some of the neighbouring countries, such as Bangladesh, and we can therefore exert direct influence.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as is the case with the migrant crisis in the Mediterranean, we can state that the exodus by boat of Myanmar’s Muslim residents is not a new phenomenon. In 2009, for example, many Rohingya refugees were rescued after 21 days at sea. Similar root causes behind this mass movement of people can also be distinguished, namely poverty, violence and persecution. Here as well, the most vulnerable groups are victims of human trafficking, of which the recent discovery of mass graves in Thailand is a gruesome testimony. The last parallel is the potential loss of credibility, not only for the ASEAN countries involved who are benefiting from the GCP scheme, but also for the EU if it decides to ignore these violations of international human rights law.  The European External Action Service should put pressure on Myanmar to grant genuine citizenship to the Rohingya and should encourage all countries concerned to develop a solid cooperation scheme that aims at tackling the human trafficking networks.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, if Europe is currently facing a migrant crisis, as has been pointed out, with a constant influx from the shores of the Mediterranean, we must also look to South-East Asia, which is experiencing a similar situation. Indeed, as Vice-President of the Inter-Parliamentary Delegation with the ASEAN countries, it is my duty to pinpoint this ordeal that the Rohingya are going through. This minority, which is considered the most persecuted in the world and lives mainly in Burma, is stateless. Burma refuses to grant him citizenship and citizenship. Faced with the misery and persecution in Burma, the Rohingya are fleeing by the thousands to Thailand and Malaysia. Unscrupulous smugglers do not hesitate to abandon them at sea after promising them a future that is ultimately no better. They landed in their new land of asylum and often find themselves in camps, where they are regularly beaten or worse. The discovery of mass graves in Thailand shows us the urgency of the situation. It is high time that the countries of Southeast Asia unite to stop the migratory movements that lead so many people to death rather than a better future. The Rohingya must be recognized as an ethnic group in their own right and must be able to enjoy the same rights as the rest of the Burmese population. Finally, the recent decision by Malaysia and Indonesia to stop the refoulement of boats and to agree to provide assistance to the 7,000 permanent migrants still at sea should be welcomed. Provided that other countries follow in the footsteps of these two countries and can follow their example in order to establish solidarity in this part of the world.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, let me begin by thanking colleagues from all political groups for their help in giving the tragic plight of Rohingya refugees the attention it deserves. As legislators, it is our duty to denounce governments that are responsible, both directly and indirectly, for the current situation. Recent news is a testament to Myanmar’s appalling civil rights record and unworthy of a nation that is seeking to be part of the international community. Firm action should be taken until Myanmar finally passes legislation that will help minorities in that country come out of the Middle Ages and into the 21st century. While Europe faces issues of its own closer to home, there is a common understanding that we have a moral responsibility when it comes to saving human lives. Myanmar’s neighbours should not beat around the bush but should fulfil their obligations under international maritime law to rescue Rohingya refugees.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, those who have seen reports of the abuse of the Rohingya in Burma: people burned alive, beheadings, rapes, abuses of all kinds; those who know that the Burmese authorities are not only doing nothing to protect them but persecuting them by depriving them of citizenship; those who have seen this and who know also know that the main culprit in the Rohingya's ordeal is Burma.  Burma must be called to order. The Burmese government must be required to comply with the declaration of rights of people belonging to national or ethnic minorities. The Burmese government must be forced to stop blocking humanitarian access to Rohingya refugee camps on Burmese territory. Finally, Commissioner, if you wanted to listen to me, I would have a question. Do you allow me to ask yourself a question, Commissioner?  In 2012, we decided to reintegrate Burma into the system of generalised preferences, which allows it to export its products without tariffs or quotas on the European market except for arms and ammunition. If Burma continues to violate human rights so systematically, does the Commission intend to challenge this reintegration?

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Mr  President, I have visited some of the camps for the Rohingya people in Bangladesh, where people have been eking out an existence for at least a couple of decades. What we have seen going on in Burma/Myanmar, as many have said here, has basically been a form of ethnic cleansing, where we see the Rohingya who have been there for generations instrumentalised by the government and allowed to vote at times when it has been convenient in sham elections; now, when maybe it is not so convenient, the white cards that had allowed Rohingya people to vote have been removed.  Rohingya people there need the State’s permission to marry and to have children. They have had no protection from sectarian violence and, indeed, they have been victims of state violence and eviction. So it is not surprising that many of them have fled across the borders, where again they find themselves at risk of being instrumentalised. It is clear, as others have said, that the source of this problem lies in Burma/Myanmar. They have not even taken back the 200-300 people that they have recognised as their citizens from the camps in Bangladesh. So I would add my voice and that of my Group to those who are saying we need to do more with the Burmese Government to actually make them live up to their responsibilities and to take back, take charge of and give citizenship to these people who they have persecuted for so long.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I am following up on the words of my pre-speechers. I think that we can all agree on the need very the part of the European Parliament to condemn the violence that is happening against the Rohingya. But it should not just be a formal condemnation, that is, in my opinion, a little.  I join those colleagues who say that this should have an impact on our relations, those relations between the European Union and the countries of the European Union with these countries if Burma and other countries do not change their policies. This should also have a concrete economic impact, especially on Burma, which has been mentioned here, which is the originator of all evil. It must be made so clear, it is incomprehensible that the Rohingya do not have citizenship. It was mentioned here by some colleagues, it is incomprehensible that people who were born in Burma and their ancestors have lived there for centuries do not have the citizenship of this country. In short, it is difficult to do business with a state like this and have good relations. Similarly, the surrounding countries, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, if they do not respect the principles of refugee international law, the failure to investigate crimes of people smuggling, crimes of trafficking in human beings, must be sanctioned by the European Union. It is not possible to stay with words only.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the motion for a resolution raises the plight of the Rohingya, who were rejected by Burma and rejected by the countries in the region, with the exception of a certain commitment on the part of Thailand, which must be greatly improved. No one wants them, they are persecuted and mistreated. They're stateless, not people but ghosts.  Of course, Europe is right to remind distant countries of their responsibilities. But Europe would be more authoritative in this appeal if this tragedy of the boats off the seas with human beings inside did not also occur in the middle of the Mediterranean. Today Indonesia and Malaysia have decided to welcome the desperate, but will the European states on reception quotas show the same willingness? Hopefully.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, the discovery of mass graves in Thailand and the appalling situation of Rohingya refugees adrift in South-East Asia are a humanitarian disaster. Thousands of migrants are still believed to have been trapped by smugglers for weeks. We cannot help but draw parallels here with the refugee crisis we are facing in the Mediterranean. Whether in South Asia or the Mediterranean, the only possible solution is a regional solution. All countries in the region should therefore be encouraged to take part in the Bangkok conference next week in an attempt to achieve an integrated solidarity mechanism. We must no longer turn the ball over and disengage from the problem as Burma unfortunately does. Yesterday's agreement between Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand, which provides for humanitarian assistance and temporary reception of migrants, is a positive development, but the lasting solution obviously lies in granting civil rights to the persecuted Rohingya in Burma. I will add a word because I had proposed not to move the emergency debate in the morning by making the argument that there are more people in the afternoon. We have evidence of that today: there are fewer of us than in the afternoon. We have to go back to the emergency debate in the afternoon.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you very much, Mr President. I will forward your comments to the Bureau of the European Parliament. Questions from the room

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, in the last three years more than 140,000 Rohingya have left Myanmar and Bangladesh by boats, and in the first three months of this year more than 25,000 of them. Last weekend, 2,000 refugees landed on the coasts of Indonesia and Malaysia, with about 8,000 trapped in the middle of the sea.  I welcome the change in decisions of the governments of Indonesia and Malaysia that have started accepting refugees and given them temporary protection. I call for urgent resolution of the causes of these problems, which implies that Myanmar must change its policy that has led to human rights violations and sectarian violence, and Thailand needs to stop human smuggling, investigate and prevent new mass graves from emerging.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, we all know that Rohingya are one of the most persecuted populations in the world. They continue to be smuggled through Thailand and from other countries in the region by human traffickers and held captive in inhuman conditions in jungle camps in the south of Thailand, where they are tortured, starved and beaten to death. We must cooperate with these countries to put an end to these atrocities and to this extremely serious violation of human rights. I strongly encourage Myanmar to grant full citizenship to its Rohingya minority and grant them equal access to services. Moreover, I find it unacceptable that refugees are pushed back into the sea. This is a violation of international law and human rights law and we should take it into consideration in the next talks with Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the discovery of mass graves with Rohingya refugees in southern Thailand has shocked international public opinion. This region is the crossroads of human trafficking and slave traders who lead refugees to prison-camps where inhumane conditions prevail. The Rohingya are an ethnic minority of a Muslim religion oppressed by the Buddhist state of Myanmar, where the government, under the control of the military, is violating human rights. Once again, lives are being lost for religious reasons. Here, the victims are Muslims. In other areas, the Jihadists are the perpetrators. But, as we have pointed out before, the causes of poverty and poverty are not religious or ethnic. They are due to the economic exploitation of peoples by large international multinational companies. So immediately the European Union's negotiations with Thailand are stopped in order to take measures to stop human trade, to take measures in the region, because in Asia we may also have a new Lampedusa.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Europe must continue with its clear policy in Asia, precisely in this case when we talk about the suffering of hundreds of thousands of people, when we talk about mass graves, when we talk about the greatest possible crimes and when we talk about the fact that there is simply one whole nation that wants to be buried.  I am convinced that Europe has its mechanisms and good intentions now expressed by Indonesia and Malaysia in relation to those intentions that are really not acceptable and that we should reject as unfortunately Burma and Myanmar and Thailand do. I think we are in a situation where we say to these countries: you have neighbors, you have friends, you have us as friends, here you go to do what we expect you to do because it is a minimal respect for human dignity.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I find this very incredible. Some have clearly described the Rohingya people as the least wanted people in the world and one of the most persecuted minorities. They are certainly right: thanks to a law of 1982, they cannot take citizenship in Burma, they cannot travel without official permission or own land and they must even sign a commitment not to have more than two children. This seems to me to be a blatant, total and massive violation of the fundamental human rights that should be accorded to every population. Moreover, they are then forced to flee to neighbouring countries, and so what is happening is the exploitation of minor workers and the trafficking of human lives in Thailand shamefully, in camps that are often not far from the images we have seen in the history books with regard to the Nazi concentration camps. I believe that the message to be sent to Burma, to Thailand must be very clear: the only things that must not have citizenship in these states are racial hatred, discrimination, exploitation and any form of non-respect for human rights.  If we are not consistent with ourselves, if we are not strong on this point and continue to favour trade relations, it is difficult for this disaster to find a solution. Let us be consistent in our relations.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there is no doubt that the plight of the Rohingya refugees is very painful for all of us. The European Union watches with great concern the unfolding humanitarian crisis involving thousands of Rohingya and Bangladeshi migrants and human trafficking victims adrift on the Andaman Sea. The situation definitely calls for urgent action by all countries involved, in line with their international obligations and international human rights standards. The priority has to be on saving lives and not putting more lives at risk. I therefore welcome the outcome of the meeting of the Foreign Ministers of Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand on 20 May, which clearly recognised the serious humanitarian dimension of the crisis, including their commitment to provide at least temporary shelter to persons still at sea. We also understand that a further regional conference will take place in Thailand on 29 May. Dealing with this crisis requires a regional response to tackle transnational organised crime, human smuggling and trafficking networks. It must include addressing the root causes of the problem. The EU encourages ASEAN to play an active role in addressing the issue.  One of the root causes is, of course, the status and welfare of the Rohingya minority in Myanmar and the under—development of Rakhine State, where most of the Rohingya originate. The situation needs to be urgently addressed by the government of Myanmar. Only an improvement in the overall human rights situation, including the status of the Rohingya, can put an end to the exodus of this minority, which has been going on for a number of years and has recently increased dramatically. The European Union has been at the forefront of calling for a durable solution for the Rohingya. Over the years, the situation in Rakhine State has dominated our political dialogue with Myanmar, including at high-level meetings and in the EU-Myanmar human rights dialogue. We continue to table resolutions on the human rights situation in Myanmar in the EU and in the General Assembly of the UN Human Rights Council, with a strong focus on the situation in Rakhine State. The EU is also a key provider of humanitarian assistance and development cooperation, benefiting Rakhine State in Myanmar as well as areas hosting the Rohingya in Bangladesh. We encourage the countries in the region to jointly address the scourge of human trafficking. It was deeply troubling to learn about the discovery of mass graves in the southern part of Thailand and victims of human trafficking kept caged in camps for ransom. Human beings should not be reduced to commodities. The European Union has consistently called upon Thailand to combat human trafficking, including forced labour on fishing vessels, and the European Union stands ready to work together with the countries concerned in addressing this issue. Thank you for this debate and the very strong resolution. All your comments have been noted. I will soon discuss this matter with Vice-President and High Representative Federica Mogherini to make our action more effective on this matter because it is necessary to be more active in this very painful situation regarding the Rohingya refugees.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the last debate. (There was a pause in the debate) Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: in writing. –  It is extremely worrying that we hear of the plight of a nation only once their faith becomes tragic. The Rohingya are being stripped of their basic human rights, trafficked, tortured and mass-murdered. Let there be no mistake: the roots of desperate migration, just like that of Rohingya refugees, or Libyan refugees, or Syrian refugees, lie in the oppressive regimes that these people flee.  However, there is a huge degree of responsibility that lies within the international community. And that applies to the western international community, as to the Asian international community. What we are witnessing now in the south-east Asian seas, ʽthe human ping-pongʼ, must find a political solution. A solution that will end the long-lasting gambling with human lives and recognise the rights of the Rohingya people not only in Burma/Myanmar, but in the region as well. The upcoming elections in Burma/Myanmar in autumn 2015 will be a test not only for the governing party and the opposition, but also for the minority groups, such as the Rohingya. We should make sure that they are able to participate in the elections.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Suazi: the cases of human rights defenders Thulani Maseko and Bheki Makhub (2015/2712(RSP))

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – Since the abolition of the constitution and the ban on political parties in 1973, the absolute monarchy in Swaziland has been in stark contrast to developments in neighbouring South Africa and Mozambique. The current king, Mswati III, also retains supreme authority on the administrative, judicial and legislative level and shows little willingness to share power. Under his rule, the human rights situation and living standards deteriorated sharply. The incidens of AIDS is among the highest in the world, with life expectancy falling accordingly and adding thousands of orphans.  We condemn today the wrongful conviction and imprisonment of Thulani Maseko and Bheki Makhubu. However, they are not an isolated case and are part of a worrying trend to stifle freedom of expression and peaceful assembly and to ignore the demands of opposition parties and trade unions regarding a democratic rule of law. However, the Cotonou Agreement bound Swaziland to respect democracy, the rule of law and human rights. Eu policy towards Swaziland should therefore focus not only on the immediate release of Thulani Maseko and Bheki Makhubu and all other political prisoners, but also at enabling the transition to a democratic rule of law and a better socio-economic situation.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, mr Demesmaeker has already said that Thulani Maseko and Bhekithemba Makhubu have been arrested and imprisoned simply for criticising the swaziland judicial system. One is a lawyer for the Swaziland Labor Congress and the other is the editor-in-chief of "The Nation," the nation's most prominent magazine.  Swaziland is a country that has been under a state of emergency since 1968. It is an absolute monarchy, as has already been said, but it is also a country that has the generalised system of preferences with the European Union and the Commission should check that the requirements are met. So that is one of the things we are asking for in this resolution.  Moreover, it seems clear to me that it is impossible to think of having relations with those who systematically violate human rights, so we hope with this resolution to send a strong signal to the Government of Swaziland.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thulani Maseko and Bheki Makhubu wanted to draw attention to the human rights situation in their country and to the situation of their own legal systems and the administration of justice. The sentences against these two have been much harsher than in comparable cases. And we see from this that this was an attempt to deter the people who want to take action in this area. It is our task to draw the attention of the state authorities of Swaziland to their own constitution of 2005. They must respect their own constitution, in which they have enshrined in Article 24 the right to freedom of expression, freedom of the media and freedom of the press. They must respect the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights in the same way as the Catonu Agreement concluded with the EU, which also emphasises human rights and democracy. We must demand that the two men be released immediately and unconditionally – not only them, but all those who are imprisoned in Swaziland for similar reasons. We must also address the conditions of detention here. The two are in solitary confinement, and that really equates to torture. We in the European Parliament urgently need to send out a signal here!

name: Javier NART
text: Author. – Mr President, one is already accustomed to many condemnations, all of them rhetorical, where we agree our conscience with our own essence. But I think it's more important to get to practice. We have Article 2 of the Association Agreements, which is the democratic clause , which is never carried out, even if everything is democratically violated , we have the Cotonou Agreement , with Article 9(2) which also has a decisive democratic definition — and the Cooperation Agreement with the countries of Southern Africa, including Swaziland , which requires democratic behaviour. Let's get him out! I do not want one more conviction, I want a first practice and, consequently, that the message be resounding: that there will be no agreement of any kind, nor will agreements or preferences of any kind be maintained if our own agreement is not respected: the democratic clause and the democratic demands contained in our agreements.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Author. – Mr President, Swaziland: we are facing a case of violation of freedom of expression, of assembly, of association, also of violation of the right of workers and workers to unionise. This is something very interesting, no doubt, for transnational corporations. Moreover, all these rights are enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. That is why in this Parliament and in the Commission we must be uncompromising in the face of this and use the mechanisms at our disposal to ensure that the Government of Swaziland guarantees respect for the rights of workers, workers, peasants and peasants. And also freedom of expression, democracy and pluralism. We also ask for the freedom of those detained. I would also like to draw the attention of this Parliament and the Commission to the quality of democracy in some states, such as the case of the Spanish State, where the 'gag law', changes to the penal code, torture, arrests, police brutality or prison sentences for trade unionists are a concern of international organisations, the most recent of them , the United Nations Committee against Torture. If we do not watch for freedom in our States, we will be very uncredible at international level.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, the human rights situation in Swaziland has been problematic for a long time, to put it mildly; but recently, respect for the rule of law has dramatically deteriorated. Today our concern extends to the lawyer Thulani Maseko, who has been defending the interests of the local trade union congress, and also to the journalist Bheki Makhubu, who is editor of the last independent newspaper in the country. Both have been sentenced for a ridiculous charge – contempt of court. Therefore, our message should be that independence of the judiciary must be fully respected in all circumstances. We ask the Swaziland authorities to unconditionally release these two persons, as well as all others who have been sentenced for using freedom of expression.  We call on Swaziland to unconditionally respect their commitment to the rule of law and human rights under the Cotonou Agreement, which includes freedom of expression. The granting of trade preferences to Swaziland must be directly linked to respect for the rule of law and human rights by the country’s government. There have been hopeful signs that, finally, the local trade union congress has been registered once again, but this is only the first step. We expect that Swaziland will continue in the same direction.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: author. – Mr President, we have massive political repression and a climate of fear in Swaziland: a fragile civil society urgently needs our support. Trade unions such as TUCOSWA are central to this movement, and they are watching the European Parliament today and so is the Swazi Government.  With this resolution we are telling them that Europe is paying close attention to the human and labour rights situation and that the imprisonment and treatment of Thulani Maseko and Bheki Makhubu are intolerable. They must be freed at once and unconditionally. Our determination to help those who fight for progress in Swaziland can only be meaningful if it is matched with real action. In this resolution we call on the EU to use all political and economic levers available to us to protect human rights in Swaziland. Importantly, this must be taken up by the Commission and its representatives in Swaziland. Commissioner, the US has acted. Why haven’t we?

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the case of Swaziland is certainly very concerning for all of us. Any country that declares a state of emergency in 1973 and still has it in place 42 years later tells its own story. Regarding the cases here of Mr Maseko and Mr Makhubu and the way they have been treated, I particularly want to draw attention to the fact that the judge who presided at their trial was the same judge who was criticised in Mr Maseko’s paper. That tells you again what respect there is for a fair trial in Swaziland.  As people have pointed out, we have an EPA coming up to be discussed and approved, perhaps, by Parliament in the second half of this year. We should ensure, firstly, that the state of emergency is lifted; secondly, that these two gentlemen are released, as well as other people in similar conditions; and, thirdly, that respect is shown for trade unions, and particularly for women and the poor. We should try to get them to do something to give benefits to those poor people in Swaziland. Otherwise we should not agree with it.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in August last year Swazilandʼs Prime Minister Dlamini called for the strangling of two trade union leaders. They had criticised the government for the terrible state of human, political and workersʼ rights in the country during the African Summit in Washington. Despite appalling developments, Swaziland still remains part of the EU GSP and as such is still granted trade preferences without fulfilling the preconditions to respect core human and labour rights and adhere to the principles of good governance.  Considering the shocking violations by the government of Swaziland, the Commission should follow the United States in investigating the violations of labour rights, protected under the GSP, and if confirmed, the Commission should consider withdrawing the trade preferences granted. If the carrot is not working, now should be the time to show the stick.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Swaziland, the fight for freedom of expression is of particular importance. Thulani Maseko, the prominent lawyer awarded the Vera Chirwa Prize in 2011 for recognizing the defense of human rights in Africa, and Bheki Makhubu, editor of The Nation, are top examples of this struggle. Arrested in March 2014 and sentenced on 25 July 2014 to two years in prison for articles criticising the lack of independence and integrity of their country's judicial system, their trial offered no guarantees of impartiality and the sentence that condemned them is manifestly disproportionate (indeed, as my colleague Kelly said , the judge who was the target of these articles was the one who convicted them).  It is therefore urgent that the Government of Swaziland honor its commitments under international law with regard to freedom of expression, association and assembly, and respect the principles of the rule of law, democracy and respect for human rights.  I end by quoting a text from a letter maseko wrote from prison: "when freedom is taken from us, it becomes the supreme duty, even hard, of man, to claim it to his oppressor, for giving up freedom is tantamount to giving up man's right to dignity."

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, under the Cotonou Agreements, Swaziland must respect democratic values, which undoubtedly include freedom of expression. That's why I see the imprisonment of lawyer Thulani Masek and journalist Bheki Makhubu as illegal. No state must violate fundamental human rights and use brutal methods and brutal ways against its critics. It must be said unequivocally to Swaziland that democracy works differently. The Swazier government must ensure and strengthen democratic values, as is set out in its constitution. The European Union wants nothing more, the European Union only wants Swaziland to respect its own constitution, and the European Union's task is to oversee this and further protect human rights in Swaziland. Otherwise, Swaziland will not be a trading partner for the European Union, and this discussion should send a clear signal to the Swaziland Government.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I believe it is very important that international solidarity is expressed to the political opponents who have been imprisoned by Swaziland’s monstrous royal decree. We cannot turn a blind eye to the conditions of political prisoners. This is a matter of human dignity and social justice. Swaziland engaged itself, under the Cotonou Agreement, to respect democracy, the rule of law and human rights principles, which include freedom of expression and freedom of the media. The government should stand by the promises it made, take concrete measures to respect and promote freedom of expression, guarantee democracy and plurality, and establish a legislative framework allowing the full participation of political parties in line with international and regional human rights obligations. The authorities of Swaziland should guarantee, in all circumstances, the physical and psychological integrity of Swazi political and civil rights prisoners and release them without delay.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the situation in Zuaziland is well known. For 41 years there has been an absolute monarchy, a state of emergency has been imposed, democracy, the rule of law and the judicial system do not actually work. Labour rights are being violated and there must be no collective freedoms for workers themselves. We therefore have the continuation of a situation of repression of human rights. Maseko, in this case, is a well-known lawyer who defends workers, is a lawyer for the trade unions and has dared to criticise his country's justice system. Makhubu is a journalist and has also criticised the judicial system. Exterminating sentences, penalties contrary to the principle of proportionality, have therefore been imposed and human rights are being violated. Zuaziland, according to the Koton agreement, must respect democracy; but it does not. Measures must therefore be taken against this undemocratic regime.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Swaziland is an absolute monarchy, a monarchy in which even the last two independent voices, Maseko and Makhubu (the first is a courageous lawyer who has had the courage to criticise a judicial system that he defines as non-impartial, not independent, is an understatement; the second is the last editor of the country's only independent newspaper), have been arrested. , silenced, mistreated.  Also in light of the fact that Coca Cola represents as much as 40% of the country's GDP, controlling all water reserves, and precisely because of its presence, I am shocked to think that even the United States, despite these major commercial interests, decided to suspend the preferential trade agreement in November 2014 precisely because the reforms were not implemented. So what can we do? We can, for once, be consistent and remind ourselves that the treaties we have signed, starting with the future economic partnership agreement with the SADC countries, are not waste paper when they also mention democracy as conditionality, just as the Cotonou Agreement is not waste paper. It is time to be consistent with our positions and to throw our fists on the table when it comes to enforcing human rights and democracy, otherwise it is we who lose ourselves as credibility and image.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a very famous television broadcast in Italy called 'Jokes Aside': they make jokes and one thinks it is true. But here we are at "Jokes Aside"? A moment ago we talked about the immigrants in Burma. We Europeans are unable to solve the problem of immigrants arriving from Africa, Libya and other countries, but we are committed to looking at what Malaysia and Thailand are doing. That is europe's problem.  Now let's talk about Swaziland. I'd like to know, of everyone in here, who knows where Swaziland is. Where's Swaziland? Instead of worrying about Swaziland, let us concern ourselves with our companies, with our elderly, with our young people, with what the future of Europe is, with what we need to do to move forward better, not with unknown countries! That then, at the end of the fair, here we waste time, we make motions for resolutions that then serve no purpose at all other than to take them to the bathroom, because these things are of no use! These two gentlemen and the Government of Swaziland don't give a about what we're doing here today!

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we welcome the European Parliament’s interest in the specific case of the lawyer and human rights activist, Thulani Maseko, and his co-accused, Bheki Makhubu, editor of The Nation magazine.  In our active engagement, we have since the very beginning in March 2014 always expressed our serious concerns regarding the issue of freedom of the media and freedom of expression in Swaziland. Thulani Maseko and Bheki Makhubu were arrested on 17 March 2014 after they had written an article in The Nation magazine criticising the way the courts had handled the arrest of a government vehicle inspector. From the outset, the EU delegation in Mbabane, in consultation with our partners, has followed both cases very closely. The EU Ambassador, who has been present at the court, has been in close contact with the relatives and the legal team and has introduced a formal request to visit both men in prison.  The European Union made a local statement on 31 March last year in order to express its concern about the detention of the two accused, followed in June 2014 by mentioning this in an EU statement during the ILO International Labour Conference while discussing labour standards in Swaziland. Nevertheless, the men were sentenced to two years’ imprisonment without the alternative option of a fine. The trial was widely condemned by leading international rights groups as unfair and not complying with international standards. A spokesperson’s statement was issued after this severe sentencing in July 2014, in which we called upon the Swaziland authorities to respect and promote the freedom of expression in line with the country’s constitution and international and regional human rights obligations. The European Union admits that the human rights track record is unsettling, and unfortunately improvements are extremely slow but, since last week, trade unions are no longer banned. The latter unfortunately does not guarantee that their meetings will not any longer be disturbed nor that their militants will not remain in prison. Let me conclude by saying that Swaziland’s whole justice sector is under pressure. Chief Justice Michael Ramodibedi has been accused of 28 infractions, including abuse of power. Judge Simelane, who tried the two activists, is himself currently arrested and charged with abuse of power and defeating the ends of justice. Finally, the Minister of Justice...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, I am not sure whether colleagues are complaining. I seem to have missed the vote on Amendment 8 unless it was withdrawn, but I did not hear of any withdrawal and I assume that is why my colleagues are complaining.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, just to be clear, the original text of paragraph 8 fell because we adopted Amendment 1 by the EPP. Does that clear up the confusion?

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, it clears up the confusion but you did not mention at the time that this was happening and I believe that we have therefore voted a different way on Amendment 3 to paragraph 11 than we would otherwise have done.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
