text: Colleagues, mea culpa if that is the case, but I would repeat that once an amendment is carried, the original text falls. I will take this lesson and in future make these matters clear. We can now continue with the vote. – After the vote on Amendment 6:

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President, I ask you to repeat from 9, because we and many more people have voted confusingly. We start with 9 – since 8 we have removed it – and we will vote well.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Couso Permuy, just to be very clear: we have clarified the issue on paragraph 8. All votes since have been roll call. We are now on paragraph 23. Amendment 6 has fallen so we vote now on the original text of paragraph 23 by a show of hands.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, I would like to propose to postpone the vote to the June session. There was only one week before the committee vote and the plenary vote with a lot of new amendments, and I think it is in the interest of all the Groups that on such an important report as Turkey we try to find a broad majority. In order to give us more time to do that, I would like to propose to postpone the vote until June.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that this motion is reasonable. We have now worked very this report for over five months. However, the gap between the vote in committee and the plenary vote was so short that it was not possible, in this short time, to reach the last compromises that are necessary. I therefore propose that we vote in favour of Mrs Piri's request.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Madam President, I was hoping that a representative from a larger group than ours would actually speak against. Turkey is a very, very important matter. We have responsibilities to our constituents: our constituents are entitled to know where we stand on this, and I would suggest that the vote goes forward and people do not try to evade it.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, what a curious idea that we are obliged to conduct foreign policy collectively and that we have no influence in the world as independent voices. Consider the example of non-EU Norway, a nation of five million people, whose diplomats have nonetheless been active on almost every continent and archipelago. They negotiated the peace deal between Sudan and South Sudan, the Oslo Accords between Israel and the Palestinians. They are active in South-East Asia, in Sri Lanka.  Do you not think that a large country might just be able to have an impact on world affairs? The United Kingdom is a nation of 63 million, a trading maritime nation connected by its enterprise, by habit and history, by law and language to every continent. I think it might just be able, as the fifth largest economy and the fourth military power in the world, to have some kind of independent foreign policy and, to state the obvious: you are more influential in foreign policy terms if you have... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I abstained on this report because whilst I fully agree that we should look into how we could step up cooperation to make the EU’s common security and defence policy more efficient, I think it is crucial both for the EU and my country that the UK is kept on board.  Yes, the EU needs to add a bite to its bark on security and defence, but when this happens outside NATO, or by duplicating actions already covered by NATO, I find it difficult to support this. It simply means wasting more money and getting less global clout in return. I do, however, think that the report addresses a number of issues of major importance that should be addressed when the Member States discuss the CSDP in June. Crucially, we should be looking into where we can provide added value and do more with the few resources that we have. That is why we need to connect the dots between all policies that touch on... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, Unlike my previous sayers, I think that the common foreign and security policy should be as common as possible for all the countries of the European Union and should be so common that it should also be a common single policy. I think that in that common strength there is then a much greater strength of all the nations that are united within the European Union. Unlike my colleagues, I believe that this represents a huge opportunity to promote europe's voice throughout the world, which is becoming increasingly globalised. I would like to open up one more topic, which concerns defence policy or its doubling down with NATO forces. I have long held the position that NATO should not be doubled by the European Union in defence policy. However, the events in Ukraine and the european Union's inability to directly enter this conflict is a sensible solution, I think, a question for defence policy.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For me, the question is not whether the European Union can make a greater contribution to a common security and defence policy in this world. I believe that the European Union must make a greater contribution. If you look around the world, you only have to look around the external borders of the European Union and ask yourself the question: has the situation there become more stable or not more stable? The situation has become increasingly unstable. This is what is literally crying out for a common European security and defence policy. That is why I was able to vote in favour of the motion and the report, i only hope that a result will now be achieved in the discussions with the Council and with the Commission, because – as previous speakers have also said – the most important side provision is, of course, that there should be no duplication of structures and that the Member States are prepared to work with Parliament and the Commission to work together with Parliament and the Commission. to establish a common security and defence policy.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, almost a year ago I was in this Chamber for the first time as a new MEP when I heard Members demanding sanctions against Russia, and even some Members saying that the EU should declare war on Russia. I was told not to worry as the EU does not have these desires and does not have an EU army. But, under the guise of this policy of implementing a common security and defence policy, today this Chamber voted on financing for an EU army, they voted on financing EU military research, it voted on tax incentives for companies providing finance and support for EU defence, and it also voted for the ability for the EU to initiate its own drone killings. Today this Chamber has turned the EU into a dark and dangerous place. That is why I voted against it, because I do not believe the EU should have the power to wage war on other countries.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it analyses the objectives set by the first European Council on Security and Defence in December 2013 and will serve as the basis for the preparation of the next European Council in June 2015 on the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), which should relaunch the efforts made in the last year and a half , with the aim of achieving a more efficient PCSD. The report aims at the need to jointly address the global threats and risks we are currently facing as they are the need to establish a global security framework at a time when threats to internal and external security are so high. Similarly, the new global situation highlights more than ever the need for greater security and defence cooperation and integration, especially with regard to capabilities in an area as essential as the fight against cyber-terrorism, cyber-attacks and cyber-crime.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The report put to the vote contains aspects which have made me value it in a negative way. For the rapporteur, the situation in Ukraine is a "security challenge", ignoring the fact that this is a political problem in which we are playing a relationship of sound cooperation with our most important neighbour, Russia.  The security-oriented approach is also seen in the call for increased military spending by States. On the other hand, it is striking that the Union's "strategic autonomy" in security and defence materials is called upon, while calling for complementarity with NATO. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy as much of it was concerned with greater militarisation of the EU which I, and Sinn Féin as a whole, oppose. The report was concerned with what it called ‘synergies’ and ‘efficiencies’ of pooling defence resources and directing more funding at R&D in ‘defence’. I do not support a Common EU military defence nor do I support the use of Irish and European taxpayers’ money in research and development for the military industry. The report also argues the importance of defence to EU ‘strategic interests’ and the need for complementarity between the EU, Member States and NATO in territorial defence. As an Irish MEP I support the policy of Irish neutrality and I oppose militarisation in the EU. For these reasons I voted against this annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Europe is currently surrounded by crises and conflicts. The Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) should therefore be at the centre of our attention. This report suggests that the only way for the EU is to establish strong international cooperation, particularly with the United Nations, NATO, the African Union and the OSCE. However, this cooperation must also take place at Member State level, for which incentives must be created. Another important point from the EU's point of view is the strengthening of the European defence industry. I welcome the report and hope that a common EU strategy on security and defence policy will also be adopted in a timely manner.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report begins by denying the sovereignty of Member States in foreign policy as it aims to make it impossible for a state to oppose the Union's foreign policy. The rapporteur of the text, Arnaud Danjean, wants to forcibly integrate all Member States into a Community foreign policy, arguing for common external interventions in which a state could no longer refuse to participate. The idea behind this report is the need to abandon national defence resources since most States are no longer able to maintain their own armed forces. The solution would therefore be to establish a single European defence which I oppose in order for France to retain its sovereignty and defence. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I am opposed to the common security and defence policy in principle: the UK is a member of NATO, and this arrangement works very well for ensuring national security. The tone of this report pushes us ever closer to a fully-fledged EU army and indeed proposes tax incentives for companies cooperating with it.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because I am in favour of greater coherence between foreign and domestic policy instruments and for more cooperation and coordination between Member States, particularly in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, as well as in the areas of cyber security and immigration. This is a first step towards a European army...

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote on this report, I would like to support the idea that the European Union and its Member States must adapt as soon as possible to the new challenges that arise on a daily basis in the field of Security and Defence.  To this end, it is essential that they make better use of the tools of the Common Security and Defence Policy, especially in their interconnection with the European Union's tools for foreign affairs, humanitarian aid and development policy. It is essential to find a more pragmatic and flexible way to demonstrate European solidarity, while improving the effectiveness with which the actions and resources of each Member State are coordinated.  As indicated in the report, I hope that decisions will be taken at the next European Defence Council in June to move forward.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Eu-2012 faces increasingly important security challenges, as shown by the many crises on the EU's borders (Libya, Sahel, Ukraine, Syria, etc.). It is therefore essential that we make more effective use of the tools of the PSDC and that they are integrated into a comprehensive EU action strategy. In addition, Member States need to better coordinate their actions on the international stage in order to speak with one voice. They also need to pool more resources to increase efficiency and reduce military spending. Finally, as the recent cyber attacks in some Member States demonstrate, it is necessary for them to immediately strengthen their cyber defence capacity in order to protect critical infrastructure, such as nuclear power plants, from cyber attacks.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Danjean report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy is deeply contrary not only to my convictions but also to the self-interest of each Member State of the European Union. First, the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) is an old Europeanist fad that has been repeatedly held in check. I recall that france had rejected the disastrous European Defence Community (EDC) as early as 1954, which had basically the same objectives as the CFSP. The European Union has therefore still not understood in sixty years that our citizens do not want a mutualisation of the defences of the Member States. Moreover, this policy would be ineffective or even dangerous, since Member States do not have the same interests in defence as well as in foreign policy. The links between the CFSP and NATO, from which I hope France will stand out, are another reason for me to vote against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some passages that we can support, I find many of the positions supported in the report unclear. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against all three reports on the common defence and security policy. They are all characterised by militaristic thinking, require strong rearmament and underline the link with NATO. In addition, the ATHENA mechanism is needed to finance the EU's military missions, and it is argued that eu battle groups are involved in all types of crisis management.  The EU has been claimed to be a peace project, but it is not at all apparent from the current reports, which are instead characterised by an attempt to build a military power for a federal Europe. As an advocate of détente and peace, I would like the EU and its Member States to emphasise civilly peaceful strategies for conflict resolution instead. That is why I have voted against these three reports

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it analyses the objectives set by the first European Council on Security and Defence in December 2013 and will serve as the basis for the preparation of the next European Council in June 2015 on the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), which should relaunch the efforts made in the last year and a half , with the aim of achieving a more efficient PCSD. The report aims at the need to jointly address the global threats and risks we are currently facing as they are the need to establish a global security framework at a time when threats to internal and external security are so high. Similarly, the new global situation highlights more than ever the need for greater security and defence cooperation and integration, especially with regard to capabilities in an area as essential as the fight against cyber-terrorism, cyber-attacks and cyber-crime.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). The eu's strongest and most important feature is the ability to mobilise resources, while applying a wide range of diplomatic, security, defence, economic, trade, development and humanitarian instruments, in line with the provisions of the United Nations Charter. The European Parliament considers that the future financing of missions and operations under this policy needs to be addressed in order to ensure a common security and defence policy. In December 2013, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. No concrete proposal has yet been submitted at the Council meeting following the opening of a debate on this issue. Parliament therefore calls on the costs of CSDP operations and missions, in particular those involving EU battlegroups, as well as the costs of force accommodation infrastructures, force entry points into the operation area and, where appropriate, the cost of food and fuel supplies to be systematically covered by the ATHENA mechanism. In addition, this mechanism is called upon to manage bilateral funding from Member States and funds received from third countries or international organisations in such a way that they can contribute to the financing of a specific operation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European security environment has changed considerably in recent times. New challenges have emerged that the Common Security and Defence Policy must respond to. This requires strengthening the aspect of European security and defence policy. In this respect, the report urges the development of a common European strategy in order to respond adequately to these new challenges. The report calls for closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, cyber security and migration. It also calls on the Council to encourage Member States to increase their defence spending, much of which should be focused on crisis management. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The conflict in eastern Ukraine, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq, the spread of the IS terrorist organisation, the Libyan crisis and the terrorist threat in Africa are direct threats to the security of the European Union. The fact is that the Union cannot play a key role as an actor in any of these threats, as a result of its internal organisation and powers. The EU is too often compelled to rely on initiatives from one or several Member States or ad hoc alliances where its role is marginal or in the background. This is why a common security and defence policy needs to be strengthened to make it a more effective policy instrument and guarantee the security of EU citizens.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy as much of it was concerned with greater militarisation of the EU which I, and Sinn Féin as a whole, oppose. The report was concerned with what it called ‘synergies’ and ‘efficiencies’ of pooling defence resources and directing more funding at R&D in ‘defence’. I do not support a Common EU military defence nor do I support the use of Irish and European taxpayers’ money in research and development for the military industry. The report also argues the importance of defence to EU ‘strategic interests’ and the need for complementarity between the EU, Member States and NATO in territorial defence. As an Irish MEP I support the policy of Irish neutrality and I oppose militarisation in the EU. For these reasons I voted against this annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that a development of the common security and defence policy in the direction of greater and closer integration is necessary and desirable, especially in the light of the international situation on europe's borders, which cannot be tackled effectively by individual members but which must all be tackled together. , at EU level.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy merely repeats the council's annual report to the European Parliament. The report uses ambiguous semantics to move towards uniformity of Member States' foreign policy positions. In addition, the report seeks to use austerity policies on the management of defence budgets to promote the pooling of military resources at European level; the aim is to create a European military projection force under the authority of the Commission. Finally, the report clearly sets out the convergence of European defence objectives with those of NATO. Because foreign security policy depends on the vital objectives of each Member State, the European Union is not the appropriate level to carry out an effective fight against the new threats facing the European continent. That is why I voted against this text which calls for the stripping of national sovereignty.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Common Security and Defence Policy emerged and developed as a natural consequence of the European construction process, as the benefits of the joint action under the aegis of the Union at international level became apparent. In essence, it consists of all the decisions to which the Member States jointly reach, concerning their relations through the Union with other actors in the international system. The European security environment context, especially in the eastern and southern neighbourhood of the European Union, due to the large number of challenges, is increasingly unstable and volatile. A number of conflicts such as those in eastern Ukraine, those in Syria and Iraq, the rise of the terrorist organization ISIS, the crisis in Libya or the terrorist threat in Africa, pose direct threats to the security of the European Union. I voted in favour of this report because the common security and defence policy provides a framework for cooperation under which the European Union can carry out operational missions in third countries, the main objective of these missions being to maintain peace and strengthen international security.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I preferred to abstain. Despite some points that we support, the report as a whole is too 'crushed' on NATO's positions and Mogherini's disappointing capabilities, as well as on the imposition of a single line for all Member States.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it analyses the objectives set by the first European Council on Security and Defence in December 2013 and will serve as the basis for the preparation of the next European Council in June 2015 on the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), which should relaunch the efforts made in the last year and a half , with the aim of achieving a more efficient PCSD. The report aims at the need to jointly address the global threats and risks we are currently facing as they are the need to establish a global security framework at a time when threats to internal and external security are so high. Similarly, the new global situation highlights more than ever the need for greater security and defence cooperation and integration, especially with regard to capabilities in an area as essential as the fight against cyber-terrorism, cyber-attacks and cyber-crime.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy highlights the need to adapt European security and defence policy to current challenges. Cyber defence, the increase in the defence budget, the fight against terrorism and the resolution of conflicts in the vicinity of the Union are elements that need to be put in place. The international context calls for swift, effective and coordinated action between Member States. It is not isolated interventions that will change the situation, but enhanced cooperation.  I have, of course, voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy (in accordance with the Annual Report of the Council to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy).  The wave of armed conflicts, crises, instability and widespread human rights violations in the immediate vicinity of the European Union give rise to many concerns. If we add to this the current terrorist threat, we understand that the security of the EU as a whole is at risk. Faced with threats of this kind, the European Union still fails to act as a single, decisive and decisive player, and all too often the Member States resort to un coordinate initiatives. The new challenges facing Europe, on the other hand, highlight the absolute need for Member States to work together within the framework of truly coordinated joint action within the framework of the common security and defence policy. I therefore hope that the June European Defence Council will be able to make important progress in this direction, improving the EU's territorial defence capability and its ability to make a significant contribution to crisis management.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The drive to ever closer union is a major concern for us and many of our constituents. We are against the centralisation of powers in Brussels and the transfer of sovereignty from the Member States to EU level. Foreign and defence policy has so far remained the prerogative of Member States, with less far—reaching EU interference than other areas. Sections of this report called for increases in, or support of, EU foreign, security and defence policy, which is something we do not support.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 In my opinion, this report is too critical for me to be able to vote in favour. In particular, I am opposed to member states investing more resources in defence and to an EU offensive capability which, according to the report, should be able to intervene in every aspect of crisis management. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Danjean's report on the common security and defence policy, whose recommendations I share, and welcome its adoption in plenary session. I am convinced that it is more than necessary to strengthen the means at the disposal of the European Union to implement a credible and operational defence policy, able to guarantee the strategic autonomy of our common area.  This means greater participation by Member States on the ground and greater shared responsibilities. Common defence capabilities must also be strengthened, notably through the implementation of joint programmes such as the European surveillance drone and government satellite telecommunications. Finally, it is essential to focus our efforts on the European defence industry; the consolidation of Europe's defence technology industrial base is therefore essential. All these measures will enable us to adapt our efforts to the level of threats we face today in the European Union.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I strongly opposed Mr Danjean's report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy, which seeks to use the security and economic issues that Member States face to justify a gradual stripping of their sovereignty in favour of a European army that will only be NATO's lieutenant. The report thus deplores the disaffection of some Member States in the main ongoing military operations of the Union, which leaves us wondering about the freedom that it is left to States to take part in a particular conflict. I am also concerned about the possibility mentioned in the report of setting up 'tax incentives' to force Member States to 'military cooperation'; this proposal is nothing more than the real implementation of tax blackmail. The recent increase in defence funding by the German government proves that states have the opportunity to invest in a large national army. The objective of solidarity in the field of defence should not be used to acknowledge the death of national defences.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Current conditions as they develop at geostrategic level, both in the south-east of the EU and in the Mediterranean, create conditions of instability that directly or indirectly affect the EU itself. New data and critical developments in the EU's neighbouring countries require the EU and member states to make the most of the opportunities offered by the CFSP in conjunction with the tools offered by EU foreign policy. Strengthening the CFSP through increased funding , coordinating Member States and strengthening the European will to shield the CFSP to meet new challenges must become a top priority for all. The fact that up to now CFSP civilian and military operations have suffered from shortcomings and weaknesses leading to ineffective missions. European integration goes through the integrated CFSP that the EU must develop. There is enormous scope and potential through the development and strengthening of the CFSP in the EU. I believe that the EU has a duty to be able to develop its own Defence and Security Policy and at the same time to safeguard the sovereign rights of its Member States.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the measure examined concerning the implementation of the common security and defence policy, I believe that the European Union and the Member States must adapt without further delay to the new security challenges. I also believe that the European Defence Council must take decisions that improve the territorial defence capacity of the Union and its Member States, in total complementarity with NATO. I agree with the political framework for systematic and long-term defence cooperation, based on the convergence of capacity planning processes and the exchange of information. For all these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is too evident the instability in the world. The European Union, in particular, faces enormous challenges in its neighbourhood. The impacts of this inaction are projected at various levels, also affecting the role of the Union as a key actor in the international scene. As we have seen recently, the concerted action of the Member States has been mainly based on a reactive role through crisis management. This context, as the rapporteur points out, further shows that the efficiency of the decision-making process, policy coordination and shared equipment management are objectives that must be pursued.  I therefore voted in favour of this report which can, in an integrated way, present the challenges, diagnose problems and propose solutions to the Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the common security and defence policy which, in my opinion, provides a precise description of the current situation. In particular, it highlights the large number of new challenges, some of them long-term ones, that the European Union is called upon to face: the increase in instability and tensions at its external borders represents a serious threat to Europe, which, together with the other States, is responsible for ensuring the security and defence of its citizens.  In the face of cuts in public spending, in order for governments to ensure an adequate level of protection for their citizens, it is considered essential to achieve an ever-increasing union of resources while exploiting the economic, diplomatic, security and defence capabilities of the EU institutions. With regard to criticism, I would like to add my voice to the concerns expressed about the obvious structural deficiencies in the interventions, the slowness and rigidity of decision-making processes and the lack of logistical and financial responsiveness; I share the view that greater solidarity between The Member States in the financing of missions and in the effective constitution of forces is essential to ensure the functioning, now and in the future, of the common foreign and security policy.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The security environment of the EU and of its eastern and southern neighbourhoods are increasingly unstable. At the same time, national defence budgets have been reduced due to the effects of the 2008 economic and financial crisis and the reductions have taken place without coordination between the Member States, thus jeopardising the Union’s strategic autonomy. The EU has a vital interest in a secure, open and clean maritime environment that allows the free passage of goods and people, so an implementation of the Common Security and Defence policy is necessary, and thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on crises in the south and east of the Union to raise the need for the EU to expand its role and military capabilities: the only one capable, according to the report, of ensuring stability and security in a scenario such as the current one. It calls for impetus from VP/HR Mogherini to credit the importance of defence policy in the EU framework. It also calls for bilateral or other international organisations to participate in the Athena system, so that military missions within the EU framework can be financed and stimulated by external sovereign actors. It calls for investment in the defence market to be facilitated, clearly as a sector of economic return and positive social impact.   I voted against the proposals and the very structure of the report because I believe that, in the areas of defence as well as foreign policy, there has never been a 'transfer of sovereignty' at the base of every area of EU law, it can be fuelled by international organisations, it could end up putting the European defence system at the service of external players who, although allied, are not said to be in line with the real interests of the Union. I also believe that the priorities, at a time of crisis such as the current one, must be different: combating poverty and social inequalities over all.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The report put to the vote contains aspects which have made me value it in a negative way. For the rapporteur, the situation in Ukraine is a "security challenge", ignoring the fact that this is a political problem in which we are playing a relationship of sound cooperation with our most important neighbour, Russia. The security-oriented approach is also seen in the call for increased military spending by States. On the other hand, it is striking that the Union's "strategic autonomy" in security and defence materials is called upon, while calling for complementarity with NATO. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe in strengthening the European Unionʼs common security and defence policy. However my vote is subject to the reservation that where security cooperation and joint action by the EU as a whole in collaboration with NATO is contemplated, I voted against. As long as it is not clear that such references cover neutral states that are also members of the EU or unless such neutral Member States do not autonomously decide to be associated, I am not in agreement with these parts. As regards defence spending and NATO defence spending, I believe that this is the prerogative of the Member States.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report takes stock of the common foreign and security policy for 2014, and in particular the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). It provides a realistic constant deterioration of the security environment in the southern and eastern European neighbourhoods, in a context of US refocusing on Asia and un concerted cuts to national defence budgets. It calls on Member States to set up and respect the conclusions of the December 2013 European Council, which recognised the need to strengthen the CSDP, improve its effectiveness, visibility and impact, increase capacity development and strengthen the European defence industry. Considering that it is necessary for the European Council next June to carry out a critical assessment of the implementation of the decisions taken at the European Council in December 2013 and to present concrete measures in line with the commitments already made and not implemented, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Union has a role to play in preserving international peace and security. It is both an issue of visibility of our action on the international scene, and of guaranteeing our own safety. I voted in favour of this report, which once again underlines the inconsistency of a proactive discourse which is not followed by concrete means to strengthen the common foreign and security policy. I deplore the reduction in defence budgets in a number of Member States. France cannot continue to provide defence efforts on its own that benefit its European partners. This is all the more regrettable because many threats, including terrorist threats, are at the gates, even within, our territories.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The level of instability at Europe's borders must encourage Europe to provide a firmer response to security and defence. It is vital that Member States use defence tools more effectively and increase the pooling of their military forces. Foreign and internal security policies also need to be more integrated. The security challenges facing the Union cross borders and require better tools. I am thinking in particular of our counter-terrorism or cybersecurity strategies.  Finally, the Union's action must focus on its immediate neighbourhood by developing civilian and military missions to manage crises and post-crisis. The situations in the countries of the southern Mediterranean but also in the East, in Ukraine, have shown that a security approach must go hand in hand with an approach to economic development.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European security environment has changed considerably in recent times. New challenges have emerged to which the DGP must also respond. This requires strengthening the aspect of European security and defence policy. In this respect, the report urges the development of a common European strategy in order to respond adequately to these new challenges. The report calls for closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, cyber security and migration. It also calls on the Council to encourage Member States to increase their defence spending, much of which should be focused on crisis management. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The PSDC is an important asset of the European strategy. It must assert itself as such. The current level of instability at Europe's borders means that the EU and the Member States have a comprehensive, coherent and strong action strategy to address new security and defence challenges. That is why I supported the resolution calling on Member States to make more effective use of the tools of the CSDP, to improve the adequacy between internal and external security measures and to share more resources, with the aim of combating terrorism and organised crime, but also to strengthen cyber defence and to face the challenges of migration. The EU needs operational resources to assert its own strategic autonomy. It must also be able to protect critical digital infrastructure from cyber attacks. I hope that the European Council on Security and Defence on 25 and 26 June will go in the same direction.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The European security environment has changed considerably in recent times. New challenges have emerged that the KBVP must respond to. This requires strengthening the aspect of European security and defence policy. In this respect, the report calls for a common European strategy in order to respond adequately to these new challenges. The report calls for closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, cybersecurity and migration. It also calls on the Council to encourage Member States to increase their defence spending, much of which should be focused on crisis management. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst highly alarming, it is not unsurprising that the aim of a Common EU Defence and Security Policy remains a top priority for these institutions.  It is no secret that I and my party believe wholeheartedly in the sovereign role of the armed forces in the United Kingdom to keep our borders and our people safe. Their skill, their courage and their enduring sacrifice is testament to the fact that this crucial function must not be outsourced to the eurocrats of Brussels and Strasbourg. One must question whether this fascination is more about integration and harmonisation than the safety of our collective nations. That is why I have opposed the report. I do, however, welcome the pressure placed on Member States to adhere to the principle of at least 2% GDP spending on defence. This was a key part of my party’s recent election manifesto and one to which we will seek to ensure that the UK Government remains accountable in times ahead.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy. The aim of this report is to revive the debate on the communitisation of defence and security policies. It lists the new threats facing Europe, including the terrorist risks that have been on the rise for several years. The sole purpose of this is to give credit to this report, which does not deceive anyone. The Union seems to do not understand that maintaining defence and security necessarily requires border management. No one can claim to protect themselves from an external threat if they do not optimally manage the gates that lead to their territory. The consequence of communitarianization will only be to severely affect national sovereignty, but it will not solve the problems. On the contrary, the solution is to increase cooperation between states, masters of their foreign and defence policies.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR believes defence policy must always remain a matter of national sovereignty. We continue to resist moves towards the creation of an EU army and expensive new EU military structures which will undermine NATO and weaken our links with international defence partners.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy as I believe that defence policy must remain a matter of national sovereignty. I agree with several of the opinions made in the report, namely that the economic crisis has led to a serious decline in defence budgets. This threatens the strategic autonomy of the Union and creates a lack of military capabilities of its Member States, which obliges us increasingly to rely on others.  The very idea of creating a common army worries me, because I am of the opinion that the Union should support the development of each Member State's military capabilities and not seize from the few existing sovereignty. It is not the Union, but every Member State that needs a strong and autonomous army, because it is the guarantor of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the country that is an instrument for upholding national interests.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 There is confusion between military and non-military missions and military assistance and direct action operations. The existing treaties do not allow the implementation of what the report says. Member States cannot implement the commitments proposed, bearing in mind that not all EU states and NATO members are. It is wrong to believe that economic instruments and diplomacy are capable in themselves of achieving an outcome. There is no adequate infrastructure for the collection and sharing of equipment as there are panspermia of materials, interoperability problems but above all different national needs, priorities and aspirations.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European security environment has changed considerably in recent times. New challenges have emerged to which the Common Security and Defence Policy must also respond. This requires strengthening the aspect of European security and defence policy. In this respect, the report urges the development of a common European strategy in order to respond adequately to these new challenges. The report calls for closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, cybersecurity and migration. It also calls on the Council to encourage Member States to increase their defence spending, a significant part of which should be focused on crisis management areas. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report highlights how the Eu ropean Union has dealt inadequately with crises in the south and east, but does so in the wrong way. According to the report, it is considered that the Union must strengthen its role, including by strengthening its military capabilities by facilitating investment in the defence market, probably believing that this sector, which is economically beneficial, can have a positive social impact. Here, too, we note that instruments of peaceful dispute resolution and the promotion of peace based on the founding values of the Union are not being taken into account. Finally, the possibility of allowing military funding through the Athena system, which in turn can be fuelled by international organisations – including NATO – could end up causing heavy external interference in the European defence system that may not be in line with the real interests of the Union. I voted against.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The security environment of the European Union and its neighbouring regions, to the east and south, is increasingly unstable and volatile, due to the high number of security problems, both long-standing and more recent, which will only have an effective response if its structures and their Member States work together in a common and truly coordinated effort in the context of the CFSP/CSDP. I believe it is essential that the Union and its Member States should, with the utmost urgency, adapt to these new security challenges, in particular through the effective use of existing CSDP instruments and a better interconnection between these instruments and EU instruments on external affairs, humanitarian aid and development policy, coordination between national actions and closer pooling of resources.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it analyses the objectives set by the first European Council on Security and Defence in December 2013 and will serve as the basis for the preparation of the next European Council in June 2015 on the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), which should relaunch the efforts made in the last year and a half , with the aim of achieving a more efficient PCSD. The report aims at the need to jointly address the global threats and risks we are currently facing as they are the need to establish a global security framework at a time when threats to internal and external security are so high. Similarly, the new global situation highlights more than ever the need for greater security and defence cooperation and integration, especially with regard to capabilities in an area as essential as the fight against cyber-terrorism, cyber-attacks and cyber-crime.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted resolutely against this deliberation, which organises a genuine tutelage of national sovereignty and freedoms, and excludes any possibility of establishing a strong and independent Europe, made up around free nations.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. Taking advantage of the unstable situation of neighbouring regions, as justification for the process of militarisation and strengthening of the so-called security policies associated with it, the report ardours the effective responsibility of the EU and its powers in the processes of destabilisation of countries, in the financing and support of extremist groups, terrorists and authoritarian regimes, in the effective underdevelopment of those countries, in the policies of aggression and interference. In its objectives, the European standardisation of security measures on the most diverse fronts, intervention within NATO's policies and objectives, a tool at the service of US imperialist policy, european federalisation of its foreign policy, in particular through the role of the VP/AR which we do not recognise and reject, the enhancement of the Athena mechanism, a path to the decision of militarisation outside the control of the Member States and Parliament, are pursued. It promotes the strengthening of financial incentives and tax benefits of the European war industry, in the logic of consolidating a common European defence market, with advances in cybersecurity and increased surveillance.  Contrary to what is said, the strengthening of a military and war Europe will never be europe's contribution to security and peace in the world. Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is of particular importance while preparing for June 2015 a Council meeting on a common security and defence policy, which should summarise the efforts over the last one and a half years and contribute to greater csdp efficiency in the future. The text seeks to address a number of aspects of interest, such as assessing the overall security context, clarifying whether the CSDP has become a real priority, assessing the situation in CSDP missions and operations and, last but not least, assessing the situation of the European Union's defence industry and its capabilities and capabilities.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report will not have a vote in favour but only one abstention since there are some points that we can support, but on the whole it is too much a "copy and paste" of the US/NATO positions.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Poland is an active participant in international projects affecting the stabilisation and restoration of peace in conflict areas. We believe that the threats we face require very close cooperation between democratic states, including European countries. The Common Security and Defence Policy cannot be an alternative to the North Atlantic Alliance, which is a tried and tested guarantor of security. It cannot duplicate tasks or potential. However, the CSDP can be a helpful tool in areas where NATO cannot and does not want to get involved. These actions must be complementary. And we're pragmatic. Therefore, while appreciating the quality of the report and supporting some of its demands, I abstained.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because I fundamentally disagree with Turkey's accession to the EU. Turkey has nothing to do culturally and ethnically with Europe. Its accession to the EU will act as a fifth column. On the substance, I disagree with the views expressed in the progress report, namely that Turkey is a strategic partner of the EU. Furthermore, I fundamentally and vertically disagree with the undying exhortation referred to in the proposal for mutual settlement and reunification. Finally, I disagree with the characterisation of the attilarch as a "leader of the Turkish Cypriots". And I find the proposal to open the port of occupied Famagusta ridiculous so that the Turks and the settlers of the occupied can trade their illegal products.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The report has a particular importance in view of the preparations for the June 2015 Council meeting on the Common Security and Defence Policy – a meeting that should sum up the efforts made in the last one and a half years (since the previous December 2013 meeting) aimed at making the CSDP more efficient. The text is aimed at tackling a few aspects of interest: an assessment of the overall security context to clarify if the CSDP has become a real priority; to evaluate the situation in the CSDP missions and operations; and to assess the situation of the capabilities and of the EU defence industry.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European security environment has changed considerably in recent times. New challenges have emerged that the KBVP must respond to. This requires strengthening the aspect of European security and defence policy. In this respect, the report urges the development of a common European strategy in order to respond adequately to these new challenges. The report calls for closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, cybersecurity and migration. It also calls on the Council to encourage Member States to increase their defence spending, much of which should be focused on crisis management. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. The EU faces an unecredited level of insecurity at its external borders. We are living in a time of great tension in much of the EU's borders and areas of influence: in the east, the war in Ukraine; in the Middle East, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq with the emergence of the terrorist group IS; on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, the terrorist threat spreads in the face of political chaos in Libya and the Sahel area. Europe must work together and immediately on the conflicts that afflict our nearest neighbours. The EU's defence and response capabilities must be increased in line with the challenges we face, and cooperation and implementation of already operational tools at EU level should also be strengthened. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it analyses the objectives set by the first European Council on Security and Defence in December 2013 and will serve as the basis for the preparation of the next European Council in June 2015 on the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), which should relaunch the efforts made in the last year and a half , with the aim of achieving a more efficient PCSD. The report aims at the need to jointly address the global threats and risks we are currently facing, such as the need to establish a global security framework at a time when threats to internal and external security are so high. Similarly, the new global situation highlights more than ever the need for greater security and defence cooperation and integration, especially with regard to capabilities in an area as essential as the fight against cyber-terrorism, cyber-attacks and cyber-crime.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. This report analyses the objectives set by the first European Council on Security and Defence in December 2013 and will serve as the basis for the preparation of the next June 2015 European Council on common security and defence policy (CSDP), where efforts in the last year and a half should be relaunched, with the aim of achieving a more efficient CSDP. It aims at the need to jointly address the global threats and risks we face at the moment such as the need to establish a global security framework at a time when threats to internal and external security are so high. Similarly, the new global situation highlights more than ever the need for greater security and defence cooperation and integration, especially with regard to capabilities in an area as essential as the fight against cyber-terrorism, cyber-attacks and cyber-crime.  That's why I voted for it.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy because I believe that the international context is increasingly unstable and needs decisive and decisive action.  The new global challenges, such as the conflict in Ukraine, the advance of ISIS, the Libyan crisis and the instability of the African continent, represent a serious threat to the security of the European Union and a new awareness and greater responsibility between the Member States are therefore needed.  All too often, in past years, the European Union's contribution to international peacekeeping missions has been designed to give visibility to the EU itself, while these interventions need to be implemented responsibly and strategically in order to respond to international crises with greater adequacy.  I agree with the doubts about a mission to the Libyan borders; Rather, I believe that further efforts should be encouraged to speed up the funding of faster and more flexible civilian missions, with qualified, competent and trained personnel.  Finally, I believe that cooperation between the European Union, the UN, NATO, the African Union and the OSCE is essential in order to take more effective and effective measures to strengthen and improve the response to international and humanitarian crises.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against the Danjean report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy. The aim of this report is to relaunch Member States' cooperation in the field of foreign policy and defence, in particular due to the international environment and new threats such as cybersecurity, organised crime and terrorism. The main proposals in this report relate mainly to the financing of CFSP operations, staff training, sharing of resources and the development of a common strategy against new threats. However, this report once again ignores the responsibility of NATO and the European Union in the development of conflicts on Europe's borders. In Libya, the Middle East or even Ukraine, Euro-Atlanticists have played wizard apprentices by supporting extremists, Islamists in the south, Russophobic in the east.  Peace on Europe's borders will only be brought back if European states pursue a policy independent of the United States and the Gulf monarchies. Giving more resources to European "hawks" would only serve to extend war and despair to our borders.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against it as the report calls for strengthening the role of the CSDP, with an emphasis on improving cooperation mechanisms and adapting them to security threats and challenges. One of the key ideas of the report is the development of the so-called "Military Industrial Complex", which includes tax incentives as part of the plan (drone development, among other things). The economic crisis is interpreted as an excuse to change the ATHENA mechanism, paving the way for possible funding directly through budgets. Moreover, alignment with NATO (as stipulated in the Lisbon Treaty) appears as one of the report's biggest political challenges.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Overall, I support the report. The need for Europeans to work together to improve their defence capabilities has never been greater. An effective and credible European security and defence policy is, therefore, the foundation of our citizens’ well—being and welfare. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full cycle approach to tackling conflict, using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence. However, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO, or interfere in what should be Member State or industry—driven activity. I therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The aim is to combat terrorism and organised crime, strengthen cyber defence and deal with illegal immigration. The security environment of the European Union and its neighbouring countries to the east and south has reached a level of instability which must force the Union to become a decisive and united player. In particular, I defend the strengthening of the European Defence Agency and the European defence industrial and technological base.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for an EP resolution on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy (according to the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common foreign and security policy) because I believe that the large number of old and newly emerging security problems is making the security environment of the EU and its eastern neighbours increasingly unstable and volatile, and the conflict in Ukraine, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq with the involvement of the terrorist organisation ISIS , the Libyan crisis and the terrorist threat in Africa (especially the Sahel, Libya and the Horn of Africa) pose a direct threat to the security of the European Union. In addition, the Union and its Member States must adapt as quickly as possible to the new security challenges. I also supported the eu as an important player in the overall defence context with NATO. We must take into account the importance of accelerating cooperation with NATO in the field of cyber defence.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. "We Swedish Social Democrats believe that the EU, with member states' resources, should contribute to maintaining peace, preventing conflicts and contributing to crisis management in the surrounding area and internationally. We therefore believe that it is important to make the common security and defence policy more effective. However, we do not support the report's consistent wording on increasing European cooperation in the field of defence and establishing a permanent cooperation structure that can lead to a common defence. We believe that the report is failing to address the reservations that exist against this and therefore chose not to support the report as a whole.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it analyses the objectives set by the European Council on Security and Defence in December 2013 and because it will serve as the basis for the preparation of the next European Council in June 2015 on the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), which should relaunch the efforts made in the last year and a half , with the aim of achieving a more efficient PCSD. The report aims at the need to jointly address the global threats and risks we are currently facing as they are the need to establish a global security framework at a time when threats to internal and external security are so high. Similarly, the new global situation highlights more than ever the need for greater security and defence cooperation and integration, especially with regard to capabilities in an area as essential as the fight against cyber-terrorism, cyber-attacks and cyber-crime.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European security environment has changed considerably in recent times. New challenges have emerged that the European Union must respond to on its merits. This requires strengthening the aspect of European security and defence policy. In this respect, the report urges the development of a common European strategy in order to respond adequately to these new challenges. The report calls for closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, cybersecurity and migration. It also calls on the Council to encourage Member States to increase their defence spending, a significant part of which should be focused on crisis management areas. In agreement with the above objectives, following the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I would like to commend the quality of the annual report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy written by my colleague Arnaud Danjean. This report comes at the right time: the proliferation of crises at Europe's doorstep and the prospect of the European Council on 25-26 June on security and defence issues required us to produce an objective analysis of the situation. Defence Europe should be a priority for the European Union which, through the values it defends, has a duty to protect its citizens and a responsibility to intervene in conflict zones to reduce instability. Unfortunately, we often feel that the Europe of defence is just a pipe dream. This is the result of the uncooperative nature of the Member States, some being reluctant to provide the operational means, others the financial means while security and stability are the problem of all. I hope that the next European Council will present more ambitious conclusions for the future of the common security and defence policy by authorising the most ready-made states to move forward through enhanced and more flexible cooperation.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against it as the report calls for strengthening the role of the CSDP, with an emphasis on improving cooperation mechanisms and adapting them to security threats and challenges. One of the key ideas of the report is the development of the so-called "Military Industrial Complex", which includes tax incentives as part of the plan (drone development, among other things). The economic crisis is interpreted as an excuse to change the ATHENA mechanism, paving the way for possible funding directly through budgets. Moreover, alignment with NATO (as stipulated in the Lisbon Treaty) appears as one of the report's biggest political challenges.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the utmost urgency that the Union and its Member States adapt to these new security challenges.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Joint Security and Defence Policy Implementation Report, given the extremely challenging and unstable security situation in the EU's eastern and southern neighbourhoods, the conflicts in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, as well as the spread of the IS terrorist organisation, the Libyan crisis and terrorist threats. I agree that the EU will only be able to respond effectively to these new security challenges if its structures and Member States work closely and in a coordinated way. The EU needs to adapt urgently to these new security challenges, in particular through the use of existing CAP tools and their better linking to EU external policy instruments, humanitarian aid and development policy, pooling resources and implementing new European solidarity mechanisms. The Union should use its strength based on the mobilisation of diplomatic, security, defence, economic, trade, development and humanitarian instruments, respecting the provisions of the UN Charter. It is necessary to look at the impact of the economic crisis on the weakening of the defence and security power of EU Member States.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against the implementation of the common security and defence policy. This text begins by denying the sovereignty of Member States in matters of foreign policy, since it tends to make it impossible for a State to oppose the Union's foreign policy. Therefore, the rapporteur of the text, Arnaud Danjean, wants to forcibly integrate all Member States into a Community foreign policy, arguing for common external interventions in which a State could no longer refuse to participate. Finally, the idea behind this report is the necessary abandonment of national defences since most States are no longer able to maintain their own armed forces. The solution would therefore be to establish a single European defence which I oppose in order for France to retain its sovereignty and defence.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Arnaud Danjean's report on the common defence and security policy. This report provides an update on the state of the Union's foreign policy and welcomes in particular the commitment to defence issues of HR/VP Frederica Mogherini, and also points to the need for greater military and strategic cooperation between the various Member States in order to ensure the best defence of the European Union. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report points to a development in the common security and defence policy which I cannot support as an Austrian. This development amounts to the creation of a common army with an offensive orientation, which also carries out combat missions in conflicts in other EU countries, which is why I must reject this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy (on the basis of the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common foreign and security policy). The instability and volatile situation in the EU's eastern and southern neighbours are also examining the EU's security and defence policy and also directly affecting the citizens of our Member States. More than ever, the European Union needs a common security strategy that will effectively address the security challenges that have arisen and ensure peace and stability in the EU. Europe must stand together and cooperate in addressing and shaping the EU's security policy. The report stresses that it is easier for Member States to guarantee security by speaking with one voice, which is why I supported this initiative. With the emerging security risks, the EU needs to be sure that its security and defence policy keeps up with the new situation, ensuring stability and peace for EU citizens.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that the CSDP needs to be improved to enable Europeans to shoulder their international security responsibilities more effectively. The report, however, offers ideas which could interfere in what should be Member State competence.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European security environment has changed considerably in recent times. New challenges have emerged to which the DGP must also respond. This requires strengthening the aspect of European security and defence policy. In this respect, the report calls for a common European strategy in order to respond adequately to these new challenges. The report calls for closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, cybersecurity and migration. It also calls on the Council to encourage Member States to increase their defence spending, a significant part of which should be focused on crisis management areas. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. "Things seem to be going in the right direction, with some forces escalating and holding up more and more armed conflicts. They also want to involve Europe in an arms race. This should not go into this, it is necessary to find the political and economic methods by which respect for international law and the UN Charter can be forced.  Evidence is of the situation in Libya, where there has been chaos ever since as a result of armed intervention by EU countries. The EU and NATO must be firmly separated. The report is not in the interest of the majority of European citizens and is therefore ineligible.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote we stress the importance of the role of the common foreign and security policy and the common security and defence policy. I stress the importance of acting as one body and tackling phenomena such as immigration in a united and united manner. The territories of the individual States constitute the European borders and our security depends on our unity. I urge this House to take a holistic approach to migration and to seize its potential and to take responsibility not only as states but also as human beings.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Danjean's report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy. The resolution comments on the Council's 2014 annual report to Parliament on the common foreign and security policy, a fundamental pillar of the European Union itself. I believe that this report is more important in the current European and global context, where our security is threatened by the international phenomenon of terrorism.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's annual resolution on the EU's Common Security and Defence Policy (PSDC).  This resolution, drafted by my colleague UMP Arnaud DANJEAN, calls on the European Union and its Member States to take immediate responsibility for the common security and defence policy, which must become a major instrument to ensure the security of the European Union and its environment, in the current context of unprecedented instability at the EU's borders.  In this context of multiple crises, unprecedented since the launch of the European security and defence policy 16 years ago, Member States must quickly make substantial progress in equipping the EU with operational, industrial and capacity resources to prevent and manage international crises but also to assert genuine EU strategic autonomy on the international stage.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy. This report clearly aims at stripping down the sovereignty of member states and favours the creation of a European army subject to NATO. Paragraph 24, for example, "deplores the persistent problems in building forces experienced in launching military missions; notes that, with the exception of EUTM Mali, to which 23 Member States actually contribute, the EU's ongoing military operations each involves a maximum of half a dozen Member States; encourages Member States to make more forces available to operations." It is therefore simply regrettable that the Member States still have the choice of the missions in which they participate. Not only does this report call for the creation of a single defence market, but it also believes that Member States are not capable of having effective research programmes.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it favours strengthening the common European defence and security policy, paving the way for the creation of a European army. However, I believe that every state must remain in control of its national defence. Moreover, this European army would in fact be at the service of NATO and the United States, as admitted by point 9, which calls for "total complementarity with NATO". While France's interest is to develop a policy of balance between the great powers, in line with the policy initiated by General de Gaulle.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. The aim of this report is to build a common security and defence policy. To justify this, the text describes the threats that would weigh on Europe in order to convince of the need to create this common defence policy. Moreover, this report deplores the lack of resources of the European Union to be able to play an international military role (point 6). We find in this project the desire to dissolve the sovereignty of the Member States a little more, the European Union regretting the lack of involvement of some of them in the latest conflicts. We may even fear that sanctions will be taken against those states that are not cooperative enough (point 28 with reference to tax incentives). There is also a desire for allegiance to NATO, which is unacceptable. It is clearly a text of abandonment of sovereignty in a highly strategic area, defence, which guarantees the independence of a nation.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The text aims to address some aspects of interest in global threats and risks, such as the need to establish a global security framework; clarify whether PCSD is really a real priority; assess the status of the CSDP's peacekeeping and security missions and operations; assess the situation of European capabilities and the European defence industry. The report is of particular importance for the preparation of the next European Council in June 2015 on common security and defence policy, which should relaunch the efforts made in the last year and a half (time elapsed since the first Monographic Council on CSDP held in December 2013) with the aim of achieving a more efficient CSDP. For these reasons, it was especially important to support its approval.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The planning and implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), in particular as regards the new challenges facing this policy, such as the fight against terrorism, cybercrime and irregular migration, should be carried out through solidarity and close and effective cooperation between Member States and international organisations. New security challenges require a very comprehensive approach and a long-term perspective of the proposed actions.  In order to be effective and reliable, this approach must take into account the educational aspect. The roots of terrorism cannot be combated without education on tolerance, multiculturalism or mutual dialogue and understanding. Nor will we build an effective migration policy without education in the fields of integration, interculturalism or anti-discrimination. That is why we need joint education programmes on the common security and defence policy. In order to effectively implement and gain support for the CSDP, we must, through education, help Europeans understand its roots, values, new objectives and challenges.

name: Petr MACH
