text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution, which also contains paragraph 38, in which Parliament says that 'it is surprised that there are no mechanisms at EU level for tax incentives to cooperate and pool resources [in defence and security policy]', 'believes that such exemptions [from VAT] must be applied systematically' and 'calls for the creation of any other incentives that could encourage cooperation between European stakeholders'. It therefore calls on the Commission to do more on the common defence and security policy, apparently with a view to building a European army, as High Representative Mogherini says. I do not agree that the European Union should have its own security and defence policy, let alone its own army. As a defence alliance in Europe, NATO serves member states well, and it is neither necessary nor desirable to dub or compete with the European defence alliance.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Danjean's report was written in response to the Council's annual report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy and towards the European Council meeting in June this year. In April the Commission presented guidelines for more effective support for capacity building for the security of third countries and improving the coordination and consistency of access to security and development in the Member States.  While the 2013 Council meeting confirmed that the Common Security and Defence Policy is a priority and is one of Commission President Mr Juncker's priorities, the Union has failed to deliver on the policy and we have not responded to security challenges. I regret the EU's inadequate response to international crises, all because of the lengthy decision-making processes and the financial situation. International security is our security.  In the hope of better coordinating cooperation, contributing to peace and responding to security challenges, I support mep Danjean's report. The report asks the Commission to create a strategy for investing in equipment, developing an institutional framework and defining financial assistance in establishing a common Security and Defence Policy of the European Union. The Republic of Croatia first joined one of the ZSOP missions with police representatives in 2002 in the EUPOL mission in Afghanistan, and participated in the EU NAVFOR – ATALANTA and EULEX Kosovo.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution adopted by a minimum majority on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The unprecedented level of instability at the EU's borders requires the UNION and its Member States to take greater responsibility for ensuring their security and defence. At present, the EU does not have the resources to respond effectively to growing security threats, not only in European but also globally. It cannot be ignored that structural deficits, as well as the long and not particularly flexible decision-making process, are at the forefront of operations carried out under the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP). With regard to the Union's capabilities, there is unfortunately minimal progress on pooling and sharing projects. It is undeniable that Member States will make more effective use of CFSP instruments, improve coordination between internal and external security measures, and work towards progress in the field of pooling and sharing capabilities. That is why they must take an active role in taking concrete action, because the international context itself currently requires flexibility and willingness to act not only in the region but also on the global stage.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not vote in favour of this report, despite a number of good ideas in it. I have the impression that the EU wants to become another NATO. Instead of caring for the well-being of EU citizens, we continue to play a war.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – An active common security and defence policy should ensure greater stability and security in the world. The current situation, in particular the conflict in Ukraine and the situation in Africa, the problems with terrorism and radicalism of the Islamic State threaten the security of the Union and its Member States. All this requires the European Union, in cooperation with the Member States, to streamline its common security and defence policy, to step up diplomatic activity and to use all its means to strengthen its position while increasing the security of its territory.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy (according to the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common security and defence policy) because it promotes the image and subsequent action of a militaristic European Union that seeks to involve itself and its Member States more and more in EU military and non-military operations while funding from national budgets.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This report, under the guise of standardising and upgrading the Union's defence capabilities, leads us to a European army, a vassal of NATO, in which the Member States will be stripped of their sovereignty. It forces a uniformity of states' foreign policy positions, which prevents any disagreement, and goes so far as to suggest "fiscal incentives" to force Member States to participate in all military operations! We strongly oppose it.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. I voted against disagreeing with the basic idea of the report that advocates the development of the Military Industrial Complex, including through tax incentives, and uses as an excuse the economic crisis to change the ATHENA mechanism and pave the way for its financing through budgets, as well as strengthening alignment with NATO.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution because I believed it moved into areas that should be Member States’ competence.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I reject the need to develop the Common Security and Defence Policy towards a common offensive-oriented army that will carry out operations abroad in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. After Mr Juncker's statement on the need to create a European army, this report comes at a high speed for the Commission. It advocates greater autonomy for the European Common Security and Defence Policy (PSDC), particularly with regard to NATO by calling for the same budgetary capabilities. The Lisbon Treaty has increased the EU's exclusive powers in this area, leaving purely military issues to the states. But among the austerity measures, the states cut in budget spending.  The European Commission and Mr Danjean are therefore seized on this opportunity to gradually transfer national resources and thus the management of defence issues to the Community budget and the European Defence Agency. This report by the UMP and the two others put to the vote are in the same direction and are now finding an enthusiastic echo in the European Parliament in the light of the Ukrainian crisis.  I oppose the European bellicose defence policy and I vote against this report, which does not hesitate to twist the very interpretation of the treaties to further limit the sovereignty of States. In any case, France has nothing to do with such an agglomerate.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This text begins by denying the sovereignty of Member States in foreign policy, since it tends to make it impossible for a State to oppose the Union's foreign policy. Therefore, the rapporteur of the text, Arnaud Danjean, wants to forcibly integrate all Member States into a Community foreign policy, arguing for common external interventions in which a State could no longer refuse to participate. Finally, the idea behind this report is the necessary abandonment of national defences since most States are no longer able to maintain their own armed forces. The solution would therefore be to establish a single European defence which I oppose in order for France to retain its sovereignty and defence. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union and its Member States shall with the utmost urgency, adapt to new security challenges, including through effective use of existing CSDP instruments and better interconnection between these instruments and EU instruments on external affairs, humanitarian aid and development policy, coordination between national actions and closer pooling of resources and, where appropriate, pragmatic and flexible implementation of new mechanisms expressing European solidarity. The boundaries between external security and internal security are increasingly soothed. Therefore, there must be greater coherence between external and internal instruments and greater cooperation and coordination between Member States, in particular in the areas of the fight against terrorism and organised crime, cyber defence and migration, under the leadership of the VP/AR. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which stresses the need for increased in-depth analysis and planning when the Union undertakes civilian and military missions as part of the Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The growing number of conflicts at our borders represents a major security challenge for Europe's 500 million citizens. At present, however, the Union does not yet have operational, capability and industrial resources assembled within an integrated military force. It would enable it to respond to international crises more quickly and efficiently, but also to become an indispensable power allowing it to assert its strategic interests. The tradition of soft power dear to our Union must be accompanied by a strong military component. There is no community of destiny without common defence. There can be no foreign policy without a union defence policy commensurate with its economic capacity. Europe can no longer rely on the American strategic shield. It must develop a defence that is NATO's armed arm. I therefore fully support this report and any future initiatives towards a more integrated and coordinated common security and defence policy between all Member States.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ With the high level of instability at the eastern and southern EU borders, the EU should take responsibility for security and defence by using the Common Security and Defence Policy tools more effectively so as to counter terrorism, fight organised crime, strengthen cyber—defence and cope with migration. Therefore, I voted in favour of the final Report on the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), but did not support certain paragraphs calling for the exact defence spending each state should make, because I think that the level of defence spending is a state prerogative.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union as a global actor must reposition its strategy on the Common Security and Defence Policy. The conflicts and crises that plague the different regions of the world must change the position of the Union and the Member States, as we need a more interventional Europe capable of giving a common and faster response. In addition, we must work with our international partners, including the United Nations, NATO, the African Union and the OSCE.  We must make our Common Security and Defence Policy a priority. This takes clear resources for crisis prevention and management. We must also tackle the new challenges that jeopardise security. The Union's Civilian Missions and Military Operations should be based on an in-depth analysis, with planning and coordination between Member States. These must be flexible and have clear funding, capable of responding to the unforeseen circumstances characteristic of this type of mission. On the other hand, Member States should cooperate on matters of military capabilities, as the reality shows us that the Union does not have the autonomous and sufficient capacity to respond to security challenges.  For the reasons described above, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on the implementation of Mr Danjean's common foreign and security policy is a serious attack on one of the elements of national sovereignty. True to the policy of small steps, but denying this will, this report proposes to add a stone to the utopian edifice of "European army" already rejected in 1954 under the name of CED. We talk about pooling and sharing, i.e. pooling and sharing national defences through the common foreign and security policy. Worse, the pretext of austerity and the breakdown of national defence budgets is used to promote this mutualisation and thus speed up the Process of the European Army.  Moreover, the CFSP is only one of the faces that the EU's policy of submission to the American and NATO desiderata has taken. This pooling of resources and this embryo of the European army is inept as the interests of the various Member States differ. As a result, it is the interests of the American "external federation", to use the term used by General de Gaulle, that will always be served more and more.  I obviously voted against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Overall, I support the report. The need for Europeans to work together to improve their defence capabilities has never been greater. An effective and credible EU security and defence policy is, therefore, the foundation of our citizensʼ well-being and welfare. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full-cycle approach to tackling conflict, using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence. However, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO or interfere in what should be Member State or industry-driven activity. I therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the implementation of the European common security and defence policy. In the current context of instability at borders and in the vicinity of the EU, unprecedented since the creation of the CSDP in the late 1990s, this text stresses the need for the European Union to urgently adapt to the new security challenges it faces. The aim is to use the tools already in place in the Lisbon Treaty and to make the CSDP more correlated with the Union's foreign policy, humanitarian aid policy and development policy. This resolution also goes in the direction of closer coordination of national actions. The aim is to ensure that the Union becomes a decisive and united player in the face of each of these threats.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy, a text that is in line with the European Council on 25-26 June 2015, where security and defence issues will be discussed. The many crises and threats that Europe is currently facing question the means that the European Union is deploying for its own security and that of its environment. However, as this report shows, the common security and defence policy must be a major instrument for Europe to play a role to its measure.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report, which has become necessary as the security environment in the EU and its neighbours to the east and south is increasingly unstable and volatile due to the high number of new and long-standing security challenges, particularly in eastern Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, and due to the rise of the terrorist organisation ISIS, the Libyan crisis and the terrorist threat in Africa (particularly in the Sahel , in Libya and the Horn of Africa).  The current level of instability at the EU's borders and in neighbouring countries has been unprecedented since the end of the 1990s, when the CSDP was established, and therefore the Union and the Member States must adapt without further delay to the new security challenges, especially by effectively using existing CSDP instruments, including through better liaison with EU foreign affairs instruments.  Indeed, the strength and importance of the Union lies in its ability to commit resources and simultaneously mobilise a wide range of diplomatic, security and defence, economic, commercial, humanitarian and development instruments, in full compliance with the provisions of the United Nations Charter.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – With the new appointment of Federica Mogherini as the new Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, interest in the CSDP has risen and most likely will be reflected by a development boost of the CSDP. I have voted for this report because it will implement a more pronounced stance towards conflict prevention at European Union level.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy as much of it was concerned with greater militarisation of the EU which I, and Sinn Féin as a whole, oppose. The report was concerned with what it called ‘synergies’ and ‘efficiencies’ of pooling defence resources and directing more funding at R&D in ‘defence’. I do not support a Common EU military defence nor do I support the use of Irish and European taxpayers’ money in research and development for the military industry. The report also argues the importance of defence to EU ‘strategic interests’ and the need for complementarity between the EU, Member States and NATO in territorial defence. As an Irish MEP I support the policy of Irish neutrality and I oppose militarisation in the EU. For these reasons I voted against this annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text as I support the overall line it draws, despite the fact that in my own view we should be doing much more in the wake of the Ukrainian crisis. The report does note accurately some main issues and I believe our efforts in the EU should go towards solving these problems: we need to have real political will to contribute troops and money to EU strategic efforts; we need to use what we have, such as the Battlegroups; we need to act more in actual strategic ways, involving ourselves more in areas where we can make a real difference rather than being there when the crisis is over. And finally, the official language needs to stop being so self-congratulatory for minimalistic efforts, like low-scale training missions, when there are so many security crises worldwide with a direct impact on the prosperity and security of Europe.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. \u2012 The importance of a common European defence policy is growing amid growing international risks. The terrorist threat and aggressive Russian aspirations justify strengthening the common policy. In my view, the possibility of joint protection action increases the security of Member States and European citizens, contributes to avoiding conflicts and deters potential aggressors.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it claims that the boundaries of external and internal security are becoming increasingly blurred. For this reason, it is hoped that there will be greater coherence between external and internal instruments, as well as increased cooperation and coordination between Member States, in particular in the areas of counter-terrorism, organised crime, cyber defence and migration. However, the report does not clearly define terms such as terrorism. In addition, international military operations will be financed by the EU budget. I do not support this report because of the ambiguous statements and definitions.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. Underlining the instability and volatility of countries and the neighborhood, we advocate coordinated external action. To this end, we need to change the structural deficiencies of many of these operations, re-mentioning the sensitive issue of funding, and seeking to promote the EU's common external strategy. We must begin to visualize an old objective of the Union, which is the creation of a common Community army to give coherence and unity to external actions. Coordination and capacity building is paramount. We must be at the forefront of defending human rights and democratic principles worldwide. There are no excuses.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the security environment in the EU and its neighbours to the east and south is increasingly unstable and volatile due to the high number of new and long-standing security challenges; Whereas the conflict in eastern Ukraine, together with the conflicts in Syria and Iraq, the rise of the terrorist organisation ISIS, the Libyan crisis and the terrorist threat in Africa (in particular in the Sahel, Libya and the Horn of Africa) represent direct challenges to the security of the Union; it is therefore necessary for the Union and the Member States to take greater responsibility for their own security and defence through coordinated joint action within the framework of the CFSP/CSDP; For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy due to the strategic importance of this policy in today's European Union environment, which is exposed to a number of security risks. The European Union is exposed to strong crises and conflicts that have an impact on security, so it must be prepared to resist these risks.  At the moment, however, the EU barely has the necessary resources to contribute decisively to the prevention and management of international crises, as well as to maintain its strategic autonomy and interests, which is worrying. More active work also needs to be done to address the structural shortcomings of missions. The report underlines the importance of cooperation and support between Member States and recalls the common target of 2% of defence spending on research. It also recalls that Member States are individually unable to bear the burden of extensive research and technological programmes in defence and that funds already available for these purposes should be used. The report also underlines that only minimal progress has been made in uniting in joint projects. It is therefore necessary to work further on these priorities.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Defence is one of the ultimate regal functions. A country that can no longer decide its defence policy or judge according to its interests the use of its armed forces has lost all sovereignty. Recent geopolitical crises, including at the gates of the European Union, have shown that not all Member States have the same analysis or the same interests.  It is out of the question that I approve of the subjugation of France and the loss of its sovereignty in favour of an entity as illegitimate and undemocratic as the European Union, not to mention NATO, which would in fact be at the helm and decide on the use of a European army. I am, of course, voting against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒i2012 I support a report by my colleague Danjean that I had the opportunity to work as a shadow rapporteur on behalf of my S&D group. This report serves primarily as a summary of the implementation of the ZSOP in the last year, but also as a preparation for the upcoming Council meeting in June. It is certain that the CESD raises more questions than it answers, that it needs thorough reform, and this report seeks to make suggestions on how to do so, especially at a time when we are surrounded by protracted and crises in the making across the Union's external borders.  First of all, we need better connectivity and coordination between internal and external common policies. We need to increase the capacity of joint operational and peacekeeping missions and a competitive military industry that can be one of the cornerstones of economic growth. In this way, a common security and defence policy would also put its name into practice, which has not been the case until now.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The level of uncertainty in the environment was no higher than the creation of the ZSOP, and the lessons learned in the 1990s must be a caution for all future actions for new security challenges. The situation in Ukraine, the Middle East, militant terrorism, cybercrime and the rise in migration are expressions of the need for a more holistic approach to civilian and military aspects.  I support this report, but I must stress my concern that the EU barely has the necessary operational and industrial capacity to deal with international crises. A new strategy is therefore needed to address new security challenges. I agree with the High Commissioner that we can no longer ignore military threats in our environment, and therefore should focus on all aspects of crisis management, including the capacity to act offensively. The lack of constructiveness is evident in the unused athena mechanism, which has been used for only 5 missions, and the level of joint cost is only 10%. Progress has been made in the coordination of the equipping and information exchange system and I welcome the work of the EDA in this regard. Talking about the untapped potential of the EU as an actor on the global stage that maintains peace is inadmissible. Greater cohesion between THE COSD instruments is needed from the decision-making process, the Athena mechanism, the pooling of resource management systems, the regulation of the financing of private companies protecting staff in civilian missions to the need for a specific financial framework for European defence companies.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The security situation in the EU, especially in its eastern and southern neighbourhood, is becoming increasingly unstable and volatile due to a large number of long-term and emerging security challenges. The conflict in eastern Ukraine, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq, or the rise of daesh, the Libyan crisis or the terrorist threat in Africa (particularly in the Sahel, Libya and the Horn of Africa) all pose an immediate threat to the Security of the Union. I consider it necessary for the Union and the Member States to take greater responsibility for their own security and defence and to be able to respond effectively in an emergency situation. It is therefore entirely appropriate to make joint and coordinated efforts within the FRAMEWORK of the CFSP/CSDP and to develop a new common European security strategy that defines the geostrategic scenarios, threats and global challenges that have arisen and defines more precisely the steps that the EU can take in response. Particular attention must be paid to the integration of cyber defence into member states' national security strategies, as cyber attacks have intensified in recent years and this trend can be expected to continue. I hope that the June European Council will agree on further concrete steps that will lead to streamlining and deeper Pan-European coordination of security policy, including the issue of funding.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is clear to everyone the growing instability of various regions to the east and south of the EU's borders, which is increasingly putting the security of our borders at risk. It is no less the recent economic crisis that has led to restrictions on the defence budget of the EU and its Member States. We must ensure that the EU and its Member States commit themselves, as the report rightly says, more financially and with a more structured and comprehensive approach.  We are currently facing major defence and security challenges. the EU must provide a strong and unified response, ensuring that Member States work together with better coordination and closer cooperation to respond to terrorism, conflicts in neighbouring countries, organised crime, cyber attacks and human traffickers. Of course, this joint action must be part of the general framework of the common security and defence policy, under the aegis of the High Representative.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the face of the increasing number of crises and conflicts in some parts of the world over the past decade, it is necessary for the Union to have the right instruments to respond effectively. The main instrument is the common security and defence policy, but today it does not allow the Union to respond properly to crises and to impose itself on the international stage. The European Parliament has adopted the report of my colleague Arnaud Danjean on the implementation of the common security and defence policy. I have spoken in favour of this report and I support the areas for improvement. In particular, the Common Security and Defence Policy should enable the Union to respond in a more coordinated way and to try to act in a sustainable way.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. According to Jean Monnet, "Europe will be in crises and it will be the sum of the solutions to these crises". With regard to Europe and its common security and defence policy, there has been no shortage of crises and conflicts in recent years: in eastern Europe (Ukraine, Georgia), southern Mediterranean (revolutions in the Arab world) and the Middle East (the civil war in Syria). But the threat is not only external: the terrorist attacks in Brussels, Paris and Copenhagen have reminded us of the urgent duty to protect our people more and better. This requires a budget redeployment to internal security missions.  The budget is not the only issue. As the European Parliament recalled this afternoon with the adoption of the Danjean report, the Lisbon Treaty has provided us with the necessary means to intensify our policy: enhanced cooperation, permanent structured cooperation, financing and solidarity mechanisms. There is, however, a glaring lack of political will among some Member States to make a concrete commitment to a common security and defence policy. It is this will that Parliament reaffirms today.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported Parliament's annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).  The global environment is increasingly unstable. The war in eastern Ukraine, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq or terrorism in Africa are just examples. In the face of increasing conflicts and crises, we have a duty to act both to protect ourselves and to reduce this geopolitical instability. Our report calls for the development of a common security and defence policy in which the EU would be a decisive player. While European commitment is to be welcomed in some regions, such as the Horn of Africa, the EU clearly lacks leadership in most Member States' operations. At the next European Council in June 2015, we expect States to take concrete steps to improve the Union's territorial defence capacity.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The advance of constant threats to European borders makes us rethink our internal security policies. The latest developments, which we have all witnessed, show that Europe is not really prepared to respond to the various border problems, they arise by land or sea. It is crucial to take an active stance on issues relating to the defence of The European Area. The economic crisis affecting Europe has caused investment in the military to suffer major cuts. There is an urgent need to rethink this last situation, as threats to EU borders are becoming increasingly felt. Still in this field, it is important to promote research policies related to defense and military strategy.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it analyses the objectives set by the first European Council on Security and Defence in December 2013 and will serve as the basis for the preparation of the next European Council in June 2015 on the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), which should relaunch the efforts made in the last year and a half , with the aim of achieving a more efficient PCSD. The report aims at the need to jointly address the global threats and risks we are currently facing as they are the need to establish a global security framework at a time when threats to internal and external security are so high. Similarly, the new global situation highlights more than ever the need for greater security and defence cooperation and integration, especially with regard to capabilities in an area as essential as the fight against cyber-terrorism, cyber-attacks and cyber-crime.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This report I voted on underlines that, at present, the Union does not yet have all the resources necessary to make a decisive contribution to the prevention or management of international crises and to the affirmation of its autonomy and strategic interests. In particular, the report highlights the structural shortcomings suffered by missions and operations under the common security and defence policy, in particular the slowness and rigidity of the decision-making process. The report also called for the creation of a pre-financing mechanism to help Member States wishing to participate in operations to bear the costs; it is considered that these operations are an important element of the Eu's overall approach and contribution to international security, but it is noted, at the same time, that since 2009 missions have been deployed to improve the visibility of the Union's response to crises, not as strategic actions following extensive analysis and planning. The European Council in June will be devoted to defence. Case to follow.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported the report by my colleague Arnaud Danjean, which is in line with the European Council on 25 and 26 June 2015 and which will discuss security and defence issues. Given the current geopolitical context, where crises and conflicts are multiplying, it is necessary and urgent for the European Union to act to ensure its protection and the stability of its environment. There is an urgent need for us to strengthen the European Union's common security and defence policy, with particular emphasis on the development of cooperation, assistance and the financing and solidarity mechanisms provided for in the Treaty.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy because, given the increasingly unstable and volatile security environment in the EU and its neighbours to the east and south, it is necessary to enable the European Union to respond effectively to new security challenges by encouraging its structures and its Member States to work together within the framework of joint and truly coordinated action within the framework of the CFSP/CSDP.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted against it as the report calls for strengthening the role of the CSDP, emphasizing improving cooperation mechanisms and adapting them to security threats and challenges. One of the key ideas of the report is the development of the so-called "Military Industrial Complex", which includes tax incentives as part of the plan (drone development, among other things). The economic crisis is interpreted as an excuse to change the ATHENA mechanism, paving the way for possible funding directly through budgets. Moreover, alignment with NATO (as stipulated in the Lisbon Treaty) appears as one of the report's biggest political challenges.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ I wish to explain that my vote in favour of this report is conditioned by the following observation: where in this text, security cooperation and joint action by the EU as a whole, in collaboration or in tandem with NATO, is contemplated and endorsed, I am not in agreement for so long as it is clear that such references do not include or cover neutral states that are members of the EU, unless these autonomously decide to be so associated, and this not least with particular reference to Malta, which as a neutral country, is specifically barred by its Constitution from participating in the programmes of a military alliance.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Writing. \u2012 The European security environment has changed considerably in recent times. New challenges have emerged to which the DGP must also respond. This requires strengthening the aspect of European security and defence policy. In this respect, the report urges the development of a common European strategy in order to respond adequately to these new challenges. The report calls for closer cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, cybersecurity and migration. It also calls on the Council to encourage Member States to increase their defence spending, much of which should be focused on crisis management. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The report put to the vote contains aspects which have made me value it in a negative way. For the rapporteur, the situation in Ukraine is a "security challenge", ignoring the fact that this is a political problem in which we are playing a relationship of sound cooperation with our most important neighbour, Russia.  The security-oriented approach is also seen in the call for increased military spending by States. On the other hand, it is striking that the Union's "strategic autonomy" in security and defence materials is called upon, while calling for complementarity with NATO. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Overall, I support the report. The need for Europeans to work together to improve their defence capabilities has never been greater. An effective and credible European security and defence policy is, therefore, the foundation of our citizens’ well-being and welfare. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full cycle approach to tackling conflict, using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence. However, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO, or interfere in what should be Member State or industry—driven activity. We therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I consider the Common Security Policy to be an important part of the EU, and I believe that many trends in this policy can help the EU to become an active partner for stabilising the situation in risk areas. I believe that the situation with the EU's southern neighbours in the Middle East, especially in the case of persecuted minorities, deserves special attention.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The current level of uncertainty at and around the EU's borders has not set a precedent since the introduction of the common security and defence policy in the late 1990s. As a decisive player, the Union cannot jointly address all these threats and too often confines itself to relying on the initiatives of one or more Member States. The EU plays only a marginal or secondary role. The EU and the Member States should therefore take greater responsibility for their own security and defence, as the security environment of the EU and its surroundings is becoming increasingly unstable and volatile, due to the large number of long-term and new security challenges, such as the conflict in Ukraine, Syria, Libya and Iraq, with the rise of the terrorist organisation ISIS. The European Union can only respond effectively to these new security challenges if its structures and its Member States cooperate in a joint and truly coordinated effort in the context of the common security and defence policy.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Recent developments in Europe show that we must take care of our security. It is not necessary to replace collective security under the heading of NATO, but it is necessary to deepen and streamline existing cooperation between individual states, especially in the area of defence and security.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy, as I believe that the European Union needs to take greater responsibility for its own security and defence, and adapt to new security challenges such as the conflict in eastern Ukraine, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq, the spread of the IS terrorist organisation, the Libyan crisis, and the terrorist threat in Africa.  I believe that co-operation between Member States would contribute to the fight against terrorism, organised crime, defence against IT attacks, thus increasing the sense of security within the European Union and preventing further escalation of the conflict at its border. To achieve this, EU countries need to adopt a common strategy to address new security challenges.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I broadly support this report on the whole. An effective and credible European security and defence policy is the foundation of our citizens’ well-being and welfare. We need to provide a renewed focus on where CSDP can best contribute to global security, through a full cycle approach to tackling conflict, as well as using a comprehensive approach and complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence. However, the report offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO or interfere in what should be Member State or industry—driven activity. I therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy, as it is evident that the security situation in the EU and its eastern and southern neighbourhoods is increasingly unstable and unsettled by the high number of security challenges. The conflict in eastern Ukraine, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq, as well as the spread of the IS terrorist organisation, the Libyan crisis and the terrorist threat in Africa (notably in the Sahel and the Horn of Africa) are direct threats to the Union's security.   The EU must be able to respond effectively to these security challenges and can only do so if its structures and Member States cooperate through joint and genuinely coordinated efforts.  The Union and its Member States need to adapt urgently to these security challenges, in particular through the use of existing CAP tools and their better linking to EU foreign policy instruments, humanitarian aid and development policy, better coordination of national actions and pooling resources, and the flexible implementation of new European solidarity mechanisms.  The borders between external and internal security are increasingly difficult to distinguish, so there is a need for greater consistency between external and internal instruments and for better cooperation and coordination between Member States, in particular in the areas of counter-terrorism, organised crime, defence against IT attacks and migration.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal. Given the current state of security in the world, it is good to support efforts to unify defence also at European Union level.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy. There are not many crises and conflicts in the world where the European Union would not play its part. I understand the implementation of the common security and defence policy in such a way that the European Union takes responsibility for its security and for the security of all of us. At the moment, the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy is not yet at such a level that we can be satisfied with that. Despite the fact that each country has its own national security and defence policy and that many Member States are involved in NATO, I believe that the implementation of the European Union's common security and defence policy must be further strengthened and upgraded. That is why I supported the report.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The security of the citizens of the Member States and, by extension, the whole of the EU is a very important factor for their well-being. This security can be achieved through cooperation and confidence-building between states. Unfortunately, this report supports military missions and tries to give them effectiveness and benefits that do not exist. In addition, it insists on a close and fully identified relationship with NATO at all levels. The ultimate aim of the report is to develop the EU militarily so that it can intervene (in full coordination with NATO and the US). The report also calls on the Member States to increase military spending to 2% of GDP, at the same time that, in the midst of an economic crisis, neoliberal policies of harsh austerity are being promoted and many funds, absolutely essential for social development - e.g. education - are being cut. We oppose the report and call, inter alia, for the disarmament (chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear) of the EU. There should be no military funding from the EU budget. Conflicts must be resolved with civilian, peaceful approaches and there must be a clear strict separation of the EU from NATO.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 There is confusion between military and non-military missions and military assistance and direct action operations. The existing treaties do not allow the implementation of what the report says. Member States cannot implement the commitments proposed, bearing in mind that not all EU states and NATO members are. It is wrong to believe that economic instruments and diplomacy are capable in themselves of achieving an outcome. There is no adequate infrastructure for the collection and sharing of equipment as there is panspermia of materials, interoperability problems but above all different national needs, priorities and aspirations.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this report because I agree with its assessment of the results of the common defence and security policy so far with strong but well-supported criticism. A key question for the future of the European Union is also the response to the new security challenges highlighted in the report, in particular with regard to Ukraine and the Mediterranean. I share the concerns that the implementation of the EiT defence policy decisions of 2013 is incomplete, virtually lagging behind, with serious shortcomings in the functioning and financing of THEG Missions, while the Union's security policy environment has become more risky than before.  For my part, I particularly welcome the fact that the report is intended to give High Representative Mogherini a prominent role in the much more effective and coordinated implementation of the COB than before, and proposes to strengthen her mandates and governing powers in this regard. In considering the merits of this report, I also considered it important that the authors also call for a specific EU strategy to address new types of security challenges.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the current geopolitical situation, and in particular in view of the growing instability in the Southern and Eastern Neighbourhood of the European Union, a debate is needed on security solutions in Europe. Indeed, the time has come for the Member States of the European Union to answer the question of whether NATO is a sufficient response to new security challenges or whether additional action is needed within the European Union. In my opinion, we should seek to increase, of course, in full complementarity with NATO's actions, the capabilities of the European Union and the Member States, both in terms of territorial defence and in other important areas, such as cybersecurity. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which recommends close COOPERATION between the EU and NATO in this regard.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union was born as a peaceful market. I voted against this report, which outlines an unacceptable steering towards military protagonism; I voted in favour of the amendments which have tried to give you the opposite sign. Moreover, the EU's military protagonism is being outlined as complementary to that of NATO. In view of this, third countries can interpret (or live) the EU's trade policies as a segment of geopolitical interests under the United States of America, and can therefore look with suspicion at the strengthening of trade and relations with the Union.  On the other hand, a clear separation between the EU itself and NATO would be appropriate and appropriate to the EU's economic interests. Finally, it is a serious mistake to call – as the report does – for the industrial base of European defence to be strengthened and for the Member States to spend at least 2% of GDP on defence. This means looking for a way out of the current economic crisis in strengthening the war industry that is inevitably linked to state orders: while European citizens are suffering from the crisis and austerity and poverty is spreading, it is unacceptable for Europe to spend time rearming itself.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the text. The Union and its Member States must urgently adapt to these new security challenges, including effectively using the tools of the CSDP and more in line with the Union's foreign policy instruments, humanitarian aid and development policy, by coordinating national actions more closely and, where appropriate, by implementing new mechanisms for expressing European solidarity with pragmatism and flexibility. The boundaries between external security and internal security are increasingly blurred. I therefore call for greater coherence between foreign and domestic policy instruments and for more cooperation and coordination between Member States, particularly in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, as well as in the areas of cyber security and immigration, under the aegis of the VP/HR.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report, which notes that the EU is surrounded by crisis and conflict like never before. Furthermore, it expresses its frustration that the EU still does not have a common strategy on how to deal with new challenges that challenge the SECURITY of the EU. It also highlights the structural deficit linked to missions and operations under the Common Security and Defence Policy. It also calls for the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon to be exploited, in particular Articles 41, 42 and 46 of the TREATY on the EU and Article 222 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. The report welcomes the framework of the common cyber defence policy and at the same time recalls the uncontrolled cuts to defence budgets. It must reach at least 2% of GDP.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against it as the report calls for strengthening the role of the CSDP, with an emphasis on improving cooperation mechanisms and adapting them to security threats and challenges. One of the key ideas of the report is the development of the so-called "Military Industrial Complex", which includes tax incentives as part of the plan (drone development, among other things). The economic crisis is interpreted as an excuse to change the ATHENA mechanism, paving the way for possible funding directly through budgets. Moreover, alignment with NATO (as stipulated in the Lisbon Treaty) appears as one of the report's biggest political challenges

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to persuade the Community authorities to reform or relaunch the common security and defence policy at the June 2015 summit. The report highlights the deterioration of the security environment (US rebalancing in Asia, the Middle East, Ukraine) and the emergence of "new threats" such as cybersecurity, organised crime or terrorism. It should be noted that the December 2013 summit was a failure for the supporters of European defence. This report must also be put in the context of the last NATO summit and the constant demand of the Americans for the alliance countries to spend 2% of their GDP on defence. The report's requests focus on funding operations, training staff, sharing resources and developing a common strategy on the various major threats. I voted against this text because of its blatant desire to communitize the foreign and defence policies of the Member States, one of the last surviving areas of sovereignty.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against it as the report calls for strengthening the role of the CSDP, emphasizing improving cooperation mechanisms and adapting them to security threats and challenges. One of the key ideas of the report is the development of the so-called "Military Industrial Complex", which includes tax incentives as part of the plan (drone development, among other things). The economic crisis is interpreted as an excuse to change the ATHENA mechanism, paving the way for possible funding directly through budgets. Moreover, alignment with NATO (as stipulated in the Lisbon Treaty) appears as one of the report's biggest political challenges.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. On the basis of the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the common foreign and security policy, we can see that much more effort is needed to implement the ambitions expressed during the 2013 summit. This report is supported mainly because it helps to conduct a constructive analysis on the subject in question.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The report put to the vote contains aspects which have made me value it in a negative way. For the rapporteur, the situation in Ukraine is a "security challenge", ignoring the fact that this is a political problem in which we are playing a relationship of sound cooperation with our most important neighbour, Russia.  The security-oriented approach is also seen in the call for increased military spending by States. On the other hand, it is striking that the Union's "strategic autonomy" in security and defence materials is called upon, while calling for complementarity with NATO. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The same EU that promoted destabilisation, chaos and underdevelopment in the places of origin, intensifying migratory pressure, is now washing its blood-smitiable hands with cosmetic measures, and also deeply inhumane. Launching warships in the Mediterranean, in addition to extensive air and land military means, and violating international law, the sovereignty and territorial integrity of sovereign states to destroy the boats that bring migrants to Europe reveal the true nature of this EU, whose economic and military interests overlap everything and everyone. The European Refugee Council and other organisations have already warned: this militaristic action could lead to even more victims, either by killing migrants who are on the downed boats or by seeking even more risky solutions to reach Europe.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I reject the need to develop the Common Security and Defence Policy towards a common offensive-oriented army that will carry out operations abroad in the EU.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution of 21 May 2015 on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). Defence is, and should remain, a matter for the Member States. Parliament has no powers in this policy area and can therefore only produce hot air. This does not stop the majority from even calling for a pre-financing mechanism to allow the EU to do military things that it cannot do with money that it does not have. It can hardly be more absurd. At least the report notes with a degree of self-awareness that the CSDP suffers from "structural deficits known for years". This should be taken as an opportunity to completely stamp them in and, above all, not to undertake any further military action.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Danjean on the implementation of the common security and defence policy, which rightly points out that the EU is not in a position at the moment to resolutely address the growing threats currently prevailing at its borders. We need systematic and long-term defence cooperation if we are to play an essential role on the international stage.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Of course, I support security and defence policy and believe that we need to work together and invest appropriately in defence policy. But this must not happen in the context of building parallel structures to weaken NATO, which is the basis of a common defense policy. In general, we should avoid any defence activity beyond NATO, which is why I could not support this report in this text.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking advantage of the unstable situation of neighbouring regions, as justification for the process of militarisation and strengthening of the EU's associated security policies, the report ardours the effective responsibility of the EU and several Member States in the processes of destabilisation of countries, financing and support for extremist groups, terrorists and authoritarian regimes, the effective underdevelopment of those countries, the policies of aggression and interference.  In its objectives, the European standardisation of security measures on the most diverse fronts, intervention within NATO's policies and objectives, a tool at the service of US imperialist policy, European federalisation of its foreign policy, in particular through the role of the VP/AR which we do not recognise and reject, the enhancement of the ATHENA mechanism, a way to the decision of militarisation outside the control of the Member States and Parliament.  It promotes the strengthening, financial incentives and tax benefits of the European war industry, in the logic of consolidating a common European defence market, with advances in cybersecurity and increased surveillance.  Contrary to what is said, the strengthening of a military and war Europe will never make a contribution to security and peace in the world. We voted against it.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I could not agree more that we need to thoroughly rethink our common security and defence policy, especially when it comes to resource management. A lot can – and should – be done to improve the efficiency and cost effectiveness of CSDP missions by looking into how Member States can pool and share resources, capabilities and assets, which would in turn allow us to have the faster, more flexible CSDP missions that are needed to underpin a strong and effective foreign policy. Better resource management, however, crucially means that we should look into how we can be complementary to what is already being done elsewhere – such as NATO – rather than duplicating it. I do not agree that there is a need for EU tax incentives for cooperation and pooling of capabilities, given that the case for increased cooperation is strong enough by itself and does not need tax measures that might in turn reduce incentives… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ar dtús ba mhaith liom a rá sna cúig bliana roimhe seo nach raibh mórán cainte againn faoi chúrsaí slándála agus cosanta. Ach de bharr na rudaí a tharla san Úcráin agus an t-ionsaí a rinne an Rúis ar an dtír sin, tá a lán tíortha tar éis teacht ar athrú aigne agus tá siad ag déanamh athbhreithniú ar an scéal. Is amhlaidh dúinne chomh maith san Aontas.  Dá bhrí sin, bhí mé sásta vótáil leis an ngrúpa ins na vótaí go léir, taobh amuigh de cheann amháin; is é sin ar mhír 3, an dara cuid den vótáil. Staonamar ar an vóta sin mar go labhraíonn sé faoi mhíleatachas soiléir agus mar gur tír neodrach í Éire b’fhearr dúinn a bheith neodrach freisin ins an vóta sin agus staonamar.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as considering that in the face of the global context we need more integrated defence cooperation in the face of the global context, in which resources and capacities are shared.  The report also calls for the ATHENA mechanism to be more budgeted and regrets that the actual proportion of the common costs covered by that mechanism remains very low and that the high proportion of expenditure and responsibilities for military operations at national level prevents some of the Member States from actively participating in CSDP operations. The report calls for more flexible and faster implementation of CSDP missions and operations, and stresses the importance of greater cooperation between military operations and civilian missions.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The report put to the vote is a clear call for the expansion of the military missions of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The text laments the low investment in missions and calls for increases in military spending. It also raises the possibility for the Union to have a budget to finance the early stages of the missions. On the other hand, the call for increase and efficiency in spending is not without political guidance. The text makes it clear that the Union must be a "genuine player in defence in the context of NATO" and should be complementary to it. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report is a logical follow-up to the Danjean report and aims to strengthen the common security and defence policy by increasing its financial and human resources. This report goes further than the above on the implementation of the PSDC since it "calls for the Union's role in defence within the NATO framework to be strengthened", i.e. the Union is simply replacing the Member States. In addition, the report calls for the pooling of resources, when expenditure would remain at the expense of the states. Then it stresses that by withdrawing individualised funding for military or defence operational expenditure, Member States will eventually be stripped of their independence. They will no longer be able to choose whether or not to participate in missions since, according to the "principle of solidarity", no state could signify its refusal. I therefore naturally voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I am opposed to the common security and defence policy in principle: the UK is a member of NATO, and this arrangement works very well for ensuring national security. The tone of this report pushes us ever closer to a fully-fledged EU army and indeed proposes tax incentives for companies cooperating with it. I therefore voted against this.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because I am in favour of greater coherence between foreign and domestic policy instruments and for more cooperation and coordination between Member States, particularly in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, as well as in the areas of cybersecurity and immigration. This is a first step towards a European army...

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Whenever the launch of a PSDC operation is decided, we see the same problems, the debates go on forever to find out who will provide what. This prevents the rapid deployment of PSDC missions and these are often modest because Member States are reluctant to provide a lot of men and equipment. In fact, these problems stem primarily from the current way of funding the CSDP. Currently, only 10% of the costs are financed collectively under the Athena mechanism and about 90% of the expenditure is borne by the Member States according to the principle of attributing expenses to the author, i.e. the State which provides equipment and men also pays the bill.  If we want to have true European solidarity and if we want to have an effective CSDP, it is essential to consider an expansion of the costs covered by the Athena mechanism by including the expenses associated with the deployment of PSDC operations and missions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The report by Eduard Kukan and Indrek Tarand on the financing of the common security policy cannot in any way benefit from my support, because of my opposition to the common foreign and security policy. I recall briefly that this policy of pooling the foreign and security policy of the Member States is ineffective, even counterproductive, in addition to seriously undermining the sovereignty of those States. On this particular report, which is supposed to provide funding for the CFSP, my opposition is similar. Not only must States retain full control of their defences, but must also retain the absolute necessity of deciding on the allocation of the resources they intend to allocate to those same means. I am outraged by the European Union's repeated desire to control member states' budgets. States are sovereign in this matter as in all other matters. For these reasons, I am voting against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from the proposed text because I find the report too crushed on NATO's positions on the financing of the common security and defence policy. Some passages are acceptable, but as many seem to me to be contrasting and not very acceptable.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against all three reports on the common defence and security policy. They are all characterised by militaristic thinking, require strong rearmament and underline the link with NATO. In addition, the ATHENA mechanism is needed to finance the EU's military missions, and it is argued that eu battle groups are involved in all types of crisis management.  The EU has been claimed to be a peace project, but it is not at all apparent from the current reports, which are instead characterised by an attempt to build a military power for a federal Europe. As an advocate of détente and peace, I would like the EU and its Member States to emphasise civilly peaceful strategies for conflict resolution instead. That is why I have voted against these three reports

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as considering that in the face of the global context we need more integrated defence cooperation, sharing resources and capacities.  The report also calls for the ATHENA mechanism to be more budgeted and regrets that the actual proportion of the common costs covered by that mechanism remains very low and that the high proportion of expenditure and responsibilities for military operations at national level prevents some of the Member States from actively participating in CSDP operations. The report calls for more flexible and faster implementation of CSDP missions and operations, and stresses the importance of greater cooperation between military operations and civilian missions.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the need to reconsider the financing of Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) missions and operations and to make better and more cost-effective use of budgetary appropriations, while ensuring proper democratic control over all mission operations, both civilian and military, at the level of the EU institutions. The European Parliament welcomes the specific measures and pragmatic decisions recently presented by the Commission under the applicable financial rules framework in order to shorten the financial procedures relating to civil missions in the CSDP. However, Parliament calls on the Commission to address the existing weaknesses in the system, to develop a specific template for the financial rules for civilian CSDP missions and to adapt existing guidelines to their needs in order to facilitate the rapid, flexible and efficient conduct of missions, while ensuring sound financial management of the EU and adequate protection of the Union's financial interests. It is necessary to ensure that transparency and accountability are essential requirements in order to ensure not only the democratic control of eu missions, but also their proper functioning and credibility. The European Parliament attaches great importance to controlling the budgetary integration of the various CSDP missions and operations.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I welcome the concrete actions and solutions recently put in place by the Commission within the current financial rules framework. These measures aim to shorten procedures for civilian missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy.  In circumstances of an increasingly volatile global situation, but also of events in the Union's immediate neighbourhood, I believe that strengthening the common security and defence policy is necessary to make it a more effective policy instrument and guarantee the security of EU citizens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report seeks to address the lack of European solidarity in external military interventions. For example, the intervention of the French army in Mali was not supported financially and materially by the Germans. However, the success of the operations will have a positive impact on the fight against terrorism for all Member States. It is to this contradiction that the Union seeks to respond in order to conceal its lack of credibility in this matter. That is why, instead of giving Member States full control over their defence budgetary policy, the report seeks to replace the common European security policy with intergovernmental diplomacy. The aim will now be to encourage, through fiscal and budgetary arrangements, the pooling of the military capabilities of each Member State. To do so, the report stresses the need to deepen the Europeanisation of the Union's external policies by making full use of the legal possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when we are increasingly facing various threats from outside, the European Union's security and defence policy requires a reassessment with a view to strengthening crisis response and response capabilities. The most recent example, the migrant crisis in the Mediterranean, draws attention to limited capacity and highlights the lack of coordinated action by the Member States. Operation Triton involving no fewer than 20 Member States revealed the weaknesses facing the Union in the security of the external borders. In order to deal with terrorist threats, which have been increasingly common in recent times, concrete measures are needed to increase the effectiveness, visibility and impact of the PSAC. New threats such as cyber attacks, border vulnerabilities and communications security must be considered. Strengthening planning and rapid response capacity for the coordinated deployment of missions is achieved through more comprehensive defence investments and more efficient management of existing means. Member States must also work towards the development of the European defence industry by intensifying the collaboration of research in the civilian and military fields.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Overall the report is too "crushed" on NATO positions and Mogherini's disappointing capabilities. In particular, given the increasingly challenging security environment inside and outside the Union, characterised by new risks and threats that no Member State can cope with on its own, a strengthening of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) is required to make it a more effective strategic instrument and a guarantee for the security of EU citizens; The Union must also strengthen security at its external borders. I abstained from the proposed text.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as considering that in the face of the global context we need more integrated defence cooperation in the face of the global context, in which resources and capacities are shared.  The report also calls for the ATHENA mechanism to be more budgeted and regrets that the actual proportion of the common costs covered by that mechanism remains very low and that the high proportion of expenditure and responsibilities for military operations at national level prevents some of the Member States from actively participating in CSDP operations. The report calls for more flexible and faster implementation of CSDP missions and operations, and stresses the importance of greater cooperation between military operations and civilian missions.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The current international context calls for more cooperation between Member States in the field of defence. It also means more rigour in the financing of the common security and defence policy. The budget that Member States give to defence is not large enough for the European Union to be a guarantor of security in its neighbourhood. I voted in favour of the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) in order to deplore the very modest nature of CSDP interventions, especially military interventions, which consist mainly of small military training missions, rather than substantial European contributions to peacekeeping and respect. I am convinced that the EU cannot afford to focus exclusively on post-crisis instruments or instruments accompanying the exit from the crisis, but should instead be able to intervene on the whole spectrum of crisis management.  I call on the High Representative and the Member States to unleash the full potential of the Treaty of Lisbon in order to increase the effectiveness and success of CSDP missions and operations. Finally, I believe it is necessary for the next European Defence Council to take concrete measures to strengthen the Union's defence capabilities in a complementary way to NATO, to support and consolidate the European Defence Agency and to provide support for a common industrial and technological base.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The drive to ever closer union is a major concern for us and many of our constituents. We are against the centralisation of powers in Brussels and the transfer of sovereignty from the Member States to EU level. Foreign and defence policy has so far remained the prerogative of Member States, with less far reaching EU interference than in other areas. Sections of this report called for increases in, or support of, EU foreign, security and defence policy, which is something we do not support.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote against depends on a number of fundamental issues: I believe that any increase in military expenditure is a serious danger to peace and I do not think it is right to burden the pockets of European citizens, already exhausted by the economic crisis, with military expenditure. Finally, I am convinced that crisis situations must be addressed by a multilateral and diplomatic approach, not a military one.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is only the logical follow-up to Mr Danjean's report on the PSDC, which is set with a view to strengthening it and its financial and human resources. The report by Eduard Kukan and Indrek Tarand also acts the submission of a possible European defence to NATO, i.e. the United States. In addition, the idea of pooling resources by providing the PSDC with its own budget is being asked. If, in theory, this effort of budgetary rationalisation may seem commendable since it is a question of simplifying the organisational structure around the PSDC, this empowerment would represent a further step towards a European defence, that is to say towards a loss of sovereignty with the disappearance of national defences. Finally, the report favours the disappearance of individualised funding for military or defence operations, which will lead, under the guise of the principle of solidarity, to the withdrawal of member states from their independence since they will no longer have the opportunity to choose which missions they participate in or not.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the measure we have examined on the financing of the common security and defence policy, I consider the considerations set out in the text on the recognition of the importance of CSDP interventions for achieving peace to be important, while encouraging the Member States of the European Union to take a more determined position on conflict prevention, post-conflict reconstruction and the maintenance of sustainable peace in conflict-affected areas. For these reasons and others set out in the mechanism, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Security and defence policies remain essentially the competence of the Member States. Despite joint operations and a growing need for greater cooperation, justified by a political map that increasingly imposes concerted European action, the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy remains too flawed. On the one hand, around EUR 190 billion is currently spent by all Member States annually on defence. The results achieved, because not coordinated, are often lower than desirable, or duplication. On the other hand, the financing of joint CSDP operations not only does not stimulate member states' participation but lacks greater transparency, flexibility and effectiveness. For all this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the financing of the common defence and security policy. Indeed, I believe that, in the face of cuts in the defence budget, a rethink of the way in which financing is financed and the items of expenditure in CSDP operations is essential in order to increase cost efficiency. I also express some misgivings about the disparity in the EU's commitment to peace and crisis management operations around the world, of which we are major financiers, compared to civilian missions and CSDP military operations, which account for only a small part of all funding and which are mainly limited to small-scale military training missions.  Finally, I hope that a specific model for financial rules will soon develop, which will facilitate a more flexible and efficient performance of missions, while ensuring sound management of resources and adequate protection of the Union's financial interests.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
