text: in writing. ‒ Delegating the budget to the Civilian Operations Commander (who forms part of the European External Action Service) would remove the oversight that the Council currently has over the Common Foreign and Security Policy budget. The Council politically prioritises the use of this budget through the Political and Security Committee, and this is effected through the budgetary scrutiny and oversight mandate of Foreign Relations Counsellors. A transfer of any part of this budget line would constitute a lessening of the Council’s role. This is a fundamental point about budgetary control and scrutiny. From the other side, Malta is more in favour of an inclusive collective approach to keep the Common Security and Defence Policy a single policy without creating a two-tier European action. Regarding these issues I abstained, but on the report as a whole I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kukan-Tarand report on the financing of the Union's CSDP missions in no way meets the trends expressed so far by the EFDD Group and the M5S. The efforts in terms of coordination, financing and effectiveness of THE EU military missions, to which the report calls, do not consider that the CFSP and the ESDP can only be conceived in the light of the Eu ropean Union's natural propensity for soft power, the peaceful resolution of disputes and the fight against the primary causes of instability: poverty and social exclusion.  I voted against the proposals and the very structure of the report. Without an army, the European Union should not even consider implementing its own military policy. The issues deplored in the report (the scarcity of financial resources, the lack of efficiency and effectiveness of decisions, the difficulties in including military missions in the UNION budget) simply run counter to the EU legal framework, which is not prepared for decision-making or the implementation of military measures, especially in the absence of a CFSP and a CSDP that have not yet been integrated and in view of the lack of real political union.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The report put to the vote is a clear call for the expansion of the military missions of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The text laments the low investment in missions and calls for increases in military spending. It also raises the possibility for the Union to have a budget to finance the early stages of the missions. On the other hand, the call for increase and efficiency in spending is not without political guidance. The text makes it clear that the Union must be a "genuine player in defence in the context of NATO" and should be complementary to it. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report with the following reservation: I am more in favour of an inclusive collection approach to keep CSDP a single policy without creating a two-tier European action.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report aims to express the European Parliament's concerns about the lack of funding for the common security and defence policy and calls, in particular, for more flexibility and coherence in the implementation of this policy. Considering that if Europe wishes to make progress in this strategic area and to respond to the current challenges, it is necessary to propose budgetary commitments that live up to our ambitions. In addition, there is a need to strengthen the coherence and complementarity of the common security and defence policy with national defence policies, in order to reduce duplication and lack of financial transparency in missions and operations. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In the face of public deficits, the pooling of Member States' resources is a better response than the un concerted reduction of defence budgets. Moreover, when Member States wish to engage together civilly and/or militarily, they must be able to implement means of close cooperation. These means exist in the Lisbon Treaty. I therefore call on Federica Mogherini, Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative, to encourage heads of state and government to take full advantage of the treaty's provisions. With flexible funding and decision-making, missions and operations within the framework of the common security and defence policy can be deployed quickly and effectively, which is all the more urgent today in view of the security challenges we face in Europe.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The Union faces new challenges that are difficult to grasp because of different natures: security such as terrorism, but also humanitarian and development-related challenges such as the management of migration flows. Our defence policy must be able to respond to that. To do this, Member States need to show more solidarity by pooling their resources and coordinating their foreign policies more closely. Tools to unlock funds more quickly for interventions must also be able to be mobilized.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to express the European Parliament's concerns about a decline in the amount of resources available in the case of THEGP funding. The report calls for a more flexible, coherent funding system. It also sets out the scope of the problems to be solved, such as duplication, lack of transparency and lack of flexibility in the various procedural rules and mechanisms. Furthermore, the opaqueness of financial instruments for missions and operations. The report highlights the objective of cost-effectiveness and efficiency gains. It also initiates the reform of the Athena Mechanism and the KBVP military operations. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I support the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy. The funding of European civil and military missions must be adapted to new needs, for greater efficiency, more solidarity between Member States and more commitments through concrete actions that are perceptible to citizens.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The aim of the report is to express the European Parliament's concerns that there has been a decline in the amount of resources available in the case of THEGP funding. The report calls for a more flexible, coherent funding system. It also sets out the scope of the problems to be solved, such as duplication, lack of transparency and lack of flexibility in the various procedural rules and mechanisms. Furthermore, the opaqueness of financial instruments for missions and operations. The report highlights the objective of cost-effectiveness and efficiency gains. It also initiates the reform of the Athena Mechanism and the KBVP military operations. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ As we reflect on further attempts to make defence powers a pawn in Europe’s integrationist agenda, I would like to draw attention to positive developments toward safeguarding communities in my constituency, Northern Ireland, from terrorist and criminal threats. Despite prolonged and self-interested efforts by nationalists and republican politicians in Northern Ireland to block the full operation of the UK National Crime Agency, I am happy to report that it has now been rolled out fully in our Province. No longer will organised crime gangs be allowed off the hook. These new powers will provide crucial support to tackle fuel laundering, illicit trade, trafficking, other forms of organised crime and terrorist activity in our region of the United Kingdom. This is what national security should be about – local and national agencies with tailored skills and a unique insight working together to combat threats to national security.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy. States must retain their prerogatives in this area. For this, it is obvious that they must also freely choose the budgets they wish to allocate to it.  Far from adopting this principle, the Union prefers to focus on pooling resources. However, this report demonstrates the ineffectiveness of the Union's action. I would like to remind you that French citizens are particularly attached to the preservation of these policies, guarding the wishes of a European defence project. Indeed, these reports are not the sole purpose of their statement but are steps towards a succession of ever more risky proposals.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – I voted against the report on the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy because I believe that defence and national security are a priority of the Member States and not a common Union priority.  At a time when we are surrounded by conflict – in the southeast Islamic State and the growing conflict between Iran and Saudi Arabia, in the south of Europe we have disintegrated countries, numerous terrorist groups and a refugee influx, and in the northeast – a military conflict on the territory of Ukraine, we must have a more secure and responsible policy.  I believe that national security is a priority of the national state and it has to decide for itself how much money and how it will use them to ensure its national integrity and sovereignty. My view is that the CSDP should not overlap its functions with those of THE UNITED STATES.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The financing of the CFR and the ATHENA mechanism, is a luxury for Europe of the economic crisis. Member States cannot contribute simultaneously to two defence organisations (EU-NATO). Since consultations on CFSP funding do not bear fruit and there is no stable CFR, any initiative to finance military or non-military missions is a utopia.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to express the European Parliament's concerns that there has been a decline in the amount of resources available for the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The report calls for a more flexible, coherent funding system. It also sets out the scope of the problems to be solved, such as duplication, lack of transparency and lack of flexibility in the various procedural rules and mechanisms. Furthermore, the opaqueness of financial instruments for missions and operations. The report highlights the objective of cost-effectiveness and efficiency gains. It also initiates the reform of the Athena Mechanism and military operations in the common security and defence policy. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kukan-Tarand report on the financing of the Union's common security and defence policy missions does not reflect the political priorities of the M5S. The common foreign and security policy should be designed taking into account the role that the Union has always played: a preference for soft power. We must aim for a peaceful solution to disputes aimed above all at combating the causes of instability, rather than the consequences, namely the fight against poverty and social exclusion and the promotion of human rights, democracy and the rule of law as expressed by the TEU.  I do not understand how, if we do not have an army, we can think of implementing a military policy. This contravenes the EU legal framework, which does not provide for the implementation of military measures, especially in the presence of a common foreign and security policy and a common security and defence policy that are not yet integrated, given that there is no real political union.  One figure stands out: EUR 190 billion is spent within the EU on defence. Given the rampant social impacts of austerity in the Member States and given that such huge resources could fuel both European recovery and the resolution of instability at its root, by addressing social emergencies in crisis theatres, this spending is madness. I voted against.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Budget cuts in the defence sector and existing duplications require a reformulation of the financing of CSDP missions and operations, which requires better, more cost-effective use of appropriations, as well as adequate democratic control at EU institutions level of all missions and operations, both civilian and military. I would remind you that the EU and the Member States are major backers of the various peace and crisis management operations around the world, and that csdp's civilian and military missions and operations represent a small share of global funding and have even decreased in recent years. According to the report, civilian missions were affected by the widespread insufficiency of payment appropriations, which forced the Commission to postpone the payment of EUR 22 million for 2015 as a mitigating measure.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the grounds that we urgently need more integrated defence cooperation, in which resources and capacities are shared.  The report also calls for the ATHENA mechanism to be more budgeted and regrets that the actual proportion of the common costs covered by that mechanism remains very low and that the high proportion of expenditure and responsibilities for military operations at national level prevents some of the Member States from actively participating in CSDP operations. The report calls for more flexible and faster implementation of CSDP missions and operations, and stresses the importance of greater cooperation between military operations and civilian missions.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The report regrets the modest nature of the military interventions of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). From here, it is all said about the vision and values that inspire it. The report calls for faster and more flexible CSDP missions, and regrets the little contribution of Member States' budgets to the CSDP. It calls for concrete proposals to be drawn up on the reform of CSDP mission and operations financing schemes and that concrete measures should be taken to strengthen the EU's defence capabilities in complementarity with NATO. Calls for enhanced defence cooperation, the meeting and sharing of resources, capacities and resources, i.e. supports and calls for an extension of eligible costs under the ATHENA mechanism, extending its scope for the financing of EU military missions. The reality shows an increasingly warring EU, involved in almost all scenarios of interference, destabilisation and military intervention, an activity that needs funding, and which here is proposed to be increased. This report looks for ways around the EU Treaty itself, which provides that the EU budget cannot be used for expenditure arising from operations that have military or defence implications.  Obviously we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The events that have taken place this year clearly show that the European Union must work towards being able to cope much more quickly and quickly with increasing challenges both on and off its territory in response to new security risks and threats. Budget cuts in defence spending and existing doublings require a reassessment of funding for CSDP missions and operations. The modest nature of CSDP interventions, especially military ones, which unfortunately represent only small military training missions instead of a substantial European contribution to peacekeeping and enforcement. The European Union must be able to accelerate and make CSDP missions more flexible and to deepen civil-military cooperation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report also does not take account of the substantial differences between Member States and aims to impose a single line for all countries.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy. The financing of the CFR and the ATHENA mechanism are a luxury for Europe of the economic crisis. Member States cannot contribute simultaneously to two defence organisations (EU-NATO). Since consultations on CFSP funding do not bear fruit and there is no stable CFR, any initiative to finance military or non-military missions is a utopia.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has to assume its role at global level not only from the economic and political point of view, but as well from the security point of view. That comes particularly at a moment when the level of security challenges for EU have increased and, consequently, strengthening the CSDP is more than ever a must. A new method is necessary to be adopted as regards the financing of the CSDP missions and operations in order to increase their efficiency. The priority stays in developing a financial mechanism for the deployment of the EU civilian missions and military operations in a faster and more flexible way, while having the full logistical and financial support in order to fulfil the objectives they are entrusted with. That is why, among others, we need to alleviate today’s very bureaucratic system of procurement. The permanent CSDP Warehouse should quickly be upgraded by enlarging its scope and by improving the availability of stored equipment, and enlarge, as well, the diversity of it.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to express the European Parliament's concerns about a decline in the amount of resources available in the case of THEGP funding. The report calls for a more flexible, coherent funding system. It also sets out the range of problems to be solved, such as duplication, lack of transparency and lack of flexibility in the various procedural rules and mechanisms. Furthermore, the opaqueness of financial instruments for missions and operations. The report highlights the objective of cost-effectiveness and efficiency gains. It also initiates the reform of the Athena Mechanism and the KBVP military operations. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. U2012 Political instability pushes the Union's external borders, both in the east and south. Activating cooperation mechanisms at European internal level to reduce costs, coordinate defence policies and deepen integration are paths that need to be paved together. Likeever, as partners within NATO, we must co-oppose the framework of international security and thus comply with the pacts we have adopted. Because of this responsibility and the belief that a stronger, safer and better defended Europe will play a key role in global security, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as considering that in the face of the global context we need more integrated defence cooperation, sharing resources and capacities.  The report also calls for a larger budget for the ATHENA mechanism and regrets that the actual proportion of common costs covered by that mechanism remains very low. It also regrets that the high proportion of expenditure and responsibilities for military operations at national level prevents some of the Member States from being able to participate actively in CSDP operations. The report calls for more flexible and faster implementation of CSDP missions and operations, and stresses the importance of greater cooperation between military operations and civilian missions.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. In the face of the global context, I am in favour of more than ever needing more integrated defence cooperation, in which resources and capacities are shared.  It also requests that the ATHENA mechanism be given a larger budget and regrets that the actual proportion of the common costs covered by that mechanism remains very low and that the high proportion of expenditure and responsibilities for military operations at national level prevents some of the Member States from actively participating in CSDP operations. It has also been relevant in my vote, the fact that it calls for more flexible missions and operations of the CSDP to be implemented more quickly, and stresses the importance of greater cooperation between military operations and civilian missions.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Writing. The MEMBERS of the SPD in the European Parliament have today voted against the Kukan/Tarand report because we do not want to support the mechanisms proposed here to finance the CSDP. The EU budget is chronically underfunded. The Council of the EU is opposed to adequate funding for important EU objectives. The EU's payment crisis has not been resolved. It also continues to jeopardise the EU's foreign policy instruments, such as humanitarian aid. Against this background, we cannot be responsible for offering the Council of the EU even the pro-rata financing of a policy without the European budget being approved with additional resources and without the democratic control of this policy by the EP.  We are concerned that the Kukan/Tarand report will allow the Council to finance CSDP missions, even if they do not have the support of the European Parliament.  This proposal therefore reduces the EP's control over the European budget. We reject this.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because Europe needs to rethink its security and defence policy. The new migration agenda has reserved an important paragraph for the role that this policy also plays in managing immigration. We must now redraw the boundaries between political areas, and I would even go so far as to say provocatively that they must be removed. Foreign policy, development cooperation policy and immigration policy must have a common plan. Where security and defence policy does not mean armaments, but above all civilian missions, it must also be strengthened through adequate funding.  We cannot think of a common defence policy without common funding. What Union is a Union with the principle of 'everyone takes responsibility for their own costs'? Given that security and defence policy is there, is provided for in the Treaties and is most necessary, all States must participate in its financing and efforts must be joint and coordinated.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy. This report finds that Member States are not meeting the Helsinki targets set in 1999. These objectives included the ability to deploy a European ground force of 50,000 to 60,000 troops, based on the resources available to it by each country. In addition, air and naval forces were to complement this land force.  This report also notes the decrease in the funding of civilian missions under the PSCD in recent years. This decrease has even forced the Commission to defer EUR 22 million in payments over the year 2015. However, in view of the European Union's belligerent and disastrous foreign policy in Africa, the Middle East and even on the European continent, in Ukraine, it is to be welcomed that the Helsinki objectives are not being achieved.  With the current leadership, giving the European Union military means would, in a way, be to let children play with guns.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report which calls for strengthening the CSDP so that the EU has a much more active role in defence. The report also regrets the EU's low defence budget (EUR 190 billion per year). It is true that the Lisbon Treaty has expanded or even opened up new possibilities for the development of the CFSP and ESDP under other formulas, although the militarisation of the EU has been one of its main axes. We believe that the EU cannot be a military force but a force for peace and for the development of peoples.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a EP resolution on the financing of the common security and defence policy because the increasingly difficult security situation inside and outside the Union, characterised by new threats and threats that no Member State can deal with alone, requires strengthening the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) and ensuring that it is a more effective policy instrument, a genuine guarantee for the security of EU citizens and the promotion of European interests and values. The European Union must therefore improve the protection of its external borders, reconsider the financing of CSDP missions and operations and make better and more cost-effective use of budgetary appropriations, while ensuring proper democratic control over all mission operations, both civilian and military, at the level of the EU institutions and ensuring transparency and accountability of funding. At the next European Council on defence, concrete measures must be adopted to increase the EU's defence capabilities and complement NATO forces, to support and consolidate the European Defence Agency and to strengthen the common industrial and technology base.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as considering that in the face of the global context we need more integrated defence cooperation in the face of the global context, in which resources and capacities are shared.  The report also calls for the ATHENA mechanism to be more budgeted and regrets that the actual proportion of the common costs covered by that mechanism remains very low and that the high proportion of expenditure and responsibilities for military operations at the national level prevents some member States from actively participating in Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) operations. In addition, the report calls for more flexible and faster implementation of CSDP missions and operations, and stresses the importance of greater cooperation between military operations and civilian missions.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as our common security and defence policy is an important principle that binds Member States together. However, we should recognise that some Member States have different positions on military policy and therefore caution should be employed when harmonising certain aspects of defence policy.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to express the European Parliament's concerns that there has been a decline in the amount of resources available for the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The document calls for a more flexible and coherent financing system. It also sets out the issues to be resolved; such as duplication, lack of transparency, lack of flexibility in the area of different procedural rules and mechanisms. Furthermore, it points to the opaqueness of financial instruments for missions and operations. The report highlights the objective of cost-effectiveness and efficiency gains. It also initiates the reform of military operations under the Athena Mechanism and the Common Security and Defence Policy. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report which calls for strengthening the CSDP so that the EU has a much more active role in defence. The report also regrets the EU's low defence budget (EUR 190 billion per year). It is true that the Lisbon Treaty has expanded or even opened up new possibilities for the development of the CFSP and ESDP under other formulas, although the militarisation of the EU has been one of its main axes. We believe that the EU cannot be a military force but a force for peace and for the development of peoples.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Common Security and Defence Policy Financing Report (OSDP), as the EU environment in terms of security is increasingly complex, and there are new risks and threats that no Member State can face on its own. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the Common Security and Defence Policy (OSDP) with a view to strengthening the security of citizens. Close coordination and cooperation in defence between Member States and at EU level is needed, as well as pooling and sharing resources, capacities and resources. I welcome these initiatives to reduce costs and increase efficiency. Greater consistency and complementarity between the various instruments is needed to achieve economies of scale and the best possible impact of EU spending. I support the pursuit of a higher level of military-civilian synergy when necessary. I agree that transparency and accountability are key requirements not only for democratic oversight, but also for the proper functioning and credibility of eu-flagged missions. I support the Commission's call on the Commission to support member states' efforts to operationally implement European Council decisions to improve defence capabilities, while taking into account the budgetary constraints faced by some Countries.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report is a logical follow-up to the Danjean report and aims to strengthen the common security and defence policy by increasing its financial and human resources. This text goes further than the report on the implementation of the CSDP as it "calls for the EU's defence role in NATO to be strengthened"; in other words, that the Union should therefore replace the Member States. In addition, the report calls for the pooling of resources, when expenditure remains the responsibility of the states. Finally, the report stresses that by withdrawing individualised funding for military or defence operational expenditure, Member States will eventually be stripped of their independence. They will no longer be able to choose to participate in missions or not since, according to the "principle of solidarity", no state will be able to signify its refusal. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Kukan and Tarand on the financing of the common defence and security policy. The report makes several proposals on cost savings and increased efficiency, such as the lack of transparency in the choice of private companies in the protection of civilian personnel in conflict zones, and also calls for more coherence and synergy between military and civilians in a conflict zone in order to maximize costs. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy (PSDC). No Member State can face the security instability at the Union's doorstep on its own. It is therefore necessary to make the common security and defence policy an effective strategic instrument that can guarantee the safety of European citizens and promote European interests and values.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. More coordination and pooling of resources within the European Defence Agency are perfectly reasonable proposals. I fully support the objective of increasing the compatibility of military equipment and member states' operational capacities, i.e. to have synergy effects. However, I do not think that transfer and centralisation at European level is a good thing, since it is no longer the Member States themselves, but the Commission and the European Parliament who have a strong say. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I support initiatives that could improve the efficiency and cost effectiveness of CSDP missions. The report, however, offers ideas which could interfere in what should be Member State competence.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to express the European Parliament's concerns about a decline in the amount of resources available in the case of THEGP funding. The report calls for a more flexible, coherent funding system. It also sets out the scope of the problems to be solved, such as duplication, lack of transparency and lack of flexibility in the various procedural rules and mechanisms. Furthermore, the opaqueness of financial instruments for missions and operations. The report highlights the objective of cost-effectiveness and efficiency gains. It also initiates the reform of the Athena Mechanism and the KBVP military operations. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Keep in mind that, in accordance with Article 41(2) of the Treaty on European Union, expenditure resulting from military or defence-related actions should not burden the Union budget. It is therefore necessary to strengthen full parliamentary control over funds and to strictly separate civilian and military missions. The proposal cannot be supported because taxpayers' money cannot be spent for opaque, illicit and uncontrollable purposes.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I accepted this proposal, voting in favour, as the aim of the report is to voice Parliament's concerns about the deficit in the CSDP financing system. Specifically, there is a call for more flexibility and coherence in funding and some shortcomings in relation to the lack of transparency in the financial allocatements concerning missions. In addition, the report calls for a review of the 'Athena' mechanism, in order to ensure that procedures allow the Eu ropean Union to be more efficient in the use of civilian missions and military operations.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I voted against the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy. Like the Danjean report on the implementation of this policy, this report aims to pool Member States' resources to lead to the creation of a single European army. One thinks one dreams when one reads the first paragraph of the report in particular, which "deplores the modest nature of the interventions under the PSDC, in particular military operations, which are essentially small-scale military training missions rather than being major contributions from Europe to the maintenance and imposition of peace; is convinced that the European Union cannot simply focus exclusively on post-crisis or crisis-exit instruments, but must, on the contrary, be able to intervene on the whole spectrum of crisis management."  The European Union, which is not even able to control its own external borders, now has the ambition to make "major contributions" to the imposition of peace throughout the world. Ridiculous doesn't kill.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, in the logic of the Danjean report, it wants to pool resources to enable the creation of a European army.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report on the impact of developments in the European defence market on security and defence capacities in Europe falls within the competence of both the JURI Commission and the IMCO Commission. It highlights the need for a single defence market through the reduction of processes and locks that avoid duplication, which generate distortions in the market. One of the essential elements in favour of European independence in security and defence is to be able to have a European industry in the highly competitive sector based on R&I. However, market fragmentation makes collaboration between Member States limited and research fragmented. It also points to the need to establish prior planning for strategic investment in procurement and material renewals between Member States. Like the Spanish Socialist Delegation as a whole, I considered it necessary to vote in favour of its approval.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution, which also contains paragraph 28, in which Parliament is 'astonished that there are still no mechanisms at European level for tax incentives for cooperation and mutual sharing [within the framework of the common defence and security policy]' and 'considers that these exemptions [from VAT] must be systematic and should be extended to infrastructure and specific capacity-building programmes' and 'calls for the development of any other incentive mechanisms that could support capacity cooperation between Europeans." It therefore calls on the Commission to do more on the common defence and security policy, apparently with a view to building a European army, as High Representative Mogherini says. I do not agree that the European Union should have its own security and defence policy, let alone its own army. As a defence alliance in Europe, NATO serves member states well, and it is neither necessary nor desirable to dub or compete with the European defence alliance.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support a report whose main purpose is to warn about shortcomings in the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy of the European Union. The Union should play a major role in international conflicts and be able to respond to the security challenges of today. Finance should not be an obstacle to the task of ensuring peace and security, especially in the countries of our neighbourhood where conflicts are increasingly common. Missions are an essential factor in the performance of this task and procedures should be defined and simplified so that they can act more transparently and efficiently. In this context, an annual assessment of the overall costs of Member States' security and defence policies should be prepared, a joint resource and equipment management centre should be established, better cooperation between Member States should be encouraged and mission budget management and public procurement monitored. Another activity is military operations that member states do not finance from the European Union budget but from the Athena mechanism. The problem is that the percentage of participation of the mechanism in financing military operations remains low, thus demotivating Member States to participate in conflict prevention and peacekeeping operations. The report identifies with concern that Member States have not achieved the security and defence policy targets set in 1999 in Helsinki despite the joint annual defence budget being around €190 billion.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support this report because there are millions of poor people living in the EU. Poverty is our enemy, not some kind of military threat. Spending extra huge money on military activities in the EU is unacceptable when one in three young people in the EU is unemployed!

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – An effective and effective common security and defence policy requires clear, unambiguous, comprehensible and transparent financing conditions and coordination of the practices of the European Union and its Member States. The same requirements must also be imposed on the control of the financing of the common security and defence policy. The European Union must be able to ensure the protection of its territories and the safety of its population.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy because it promotes the image and subsequent action of a militaristic European Union that seeks its increasing participation and its Member States in EU military and non-military operations while funding from national budgets.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. We voted against this report. The aim of this report is to strengthen the Common Security and Defence Policy (PSDC) by pooling its human and financial resources. On paper, this seems to be positive, since the CSDP would have its own budget and resources. In reality, it is a question of withdrawing individualised funding from Member States and therefore their independence since they will no longer have the opportunity to choose which missions they wish to participate in. We are against that idea.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. I voted against because this report advocates strengthening the Common Security and Defence Policy and regrets that the European defence budget, currently EUR 190 million/year, is low, with which I am at total disagreement. The European project was born from the idea of peace and was built to ensure this idea of peace and development of peoples, not to be a military power.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution because I believed it moved into areas that should be Member States’ competence.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report regrets the modest nature of military interventions within the framework of the Common Security and Defence Policy (PSDC), calls for faster and more flexible missions and calls for civil-military cooperation in research. It also calls for the systematic participation of all States in the so-called "Athena" financial mechanism, which provides funding for the common costs of Member States' military operations (except Denmark) but also research on nuclear, radiological, biological and chemical weapons.  Finally, he called for closer cooperation with NATO when Mr Danjean's report instead calls for greater empowerment. I do not have to choose between the plague and cholera, between the NATO bellicose army or its reproduction at European level to intervene in Ukraine and sow trouble at our borders or elsewhere. I counter this report as that of the UMP Member, and I denounce the irresponsibility of the Greens for letting a Baltic rapporteur of the most bellicose take charge of this issue.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report is a logical follow-up to the Danjean report and aims to strengthen the common security and defence policy by increasing its financial and human resources. This text goes further than the report on the implementation of the CSDP as it "calls for the EU's defence role in NATO to be strengthened"; in other words, that the Union should therefore replace the Member States. In addition, the report calls for the pooling of resources, when expenditure remains the responsibility of the states. Finally, the report stresses that by withdrawing individualised funding for military or defence operational expenditure, Member States will eventually be stripped of their independence. They will no longer be able to choose to participate in missions or not since, according to the "principle of solidarity", no state will be able to signify its refusal. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The growing challenges of the security climate within and outside the Union, characterised by new risks and threats that no Member State is able to face in isolation, require strengthening the CSDP to make it a more effective policy instrument and an effective guarantee of the security of EU citizens and the promotion of European interests and values. The Union must strengthen security at its external borders. Budget cuts in the defence sector and existing duplication slate dwells require a reformulation of the financing of CSDP missions and operations, which requires better, more cost-effective use of appropriations, as well as adequate democratic control at EU institutions level of all missions and operations, both civilian and military.  We all need to make a financial effort to continue to strengthen our CSDP. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it highlights the need for increased democratic scrutiny over the way that the budget for different Common Security and Defence Policy missions and operations is allocated. It is important that the European Parliament be involved in these decisions to increase the transparency and accountability of these missions.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Europe faces many challenges to its security, both inside and outside the Union. At a time when budgetary constraints are also affecting the defence sector, it is necessary to respond to these challenges in a coordinated manner in order to make the best use of available financial resources. This optimization can only be done through increasing dialogue and extensive coordination between all stakeholders. In terms of defence, the solution for the future is 'more Europe'. If Member States were to act more integratedally, their collective budget, which currently stands at EUR 190 billion, would decrease considerably. According to the European Parliament's study on the cost of non-Europe 2014-2019, the potential efficiency gain of better coordination at European level in security and defence could reach 26 billion per year.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ With the level of instability at EU borders, the EU should take responsibility for security and defence by using the Common Security and Defence Policy tools more effectively so as to counter terrorism, fight organised crime, strengthen cyber-defence and cope with migration. The funding of EU civilian missions and military operations must be adapted to new needs, and the CSDP needs proper funding. Therefore, I voted in favour of the final resolution by Eduard Kukan (EPP, SK) and Indrek Tarand (Greens/EFA, ET), even though I do not support some of the paragraphs in the text, and in particular the one on budgetary control and scrutiny, regarding the CFSP.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Common Security and Defence Policy is one of the pillars of the European Union's foreign policy. Within this scope are inserted the Civil Missions and Military Operations that have as main objective the prevention of conflicts and their management. Since 2003, the Union has launched more than 30 missions.  Despite the measures introduced by the European Commission, problems remain directly affecting the effectiveness of these operations. The constant reduction in Member States' military budgets leads to delays in the provision of essential equipment and services. On the other hand, the slowness in the decision-making process in the Council calls into question the security and objectives of the Common Security Policy.  I support this report because I believe that there should be greater transparency and accountability, but also more coherence and complementarity between the Union and the Member States. I believe that the principle of solidarity must be applied and that all Member States must support these missions even when they do not participate directly. Long-term financing of military and civilian missions should therefore be established.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report is moved by the weak mutualisation and solidarity of EU countries in defence.  But the modest nature of military operations under the common security and defence policy is only a reflection of the deep differences of interest that exist between the various Member States. The idea of a federalised European army is therefore a dream that only Europeanist minds can believe to be prescient. The divisions over the war in Iraq or even the intervention in Libya bear witness to this.  Moreover, this mutualisation is motivated by cuts in national defence budgets: it is to be asked whether Brussels is not imposing austerity to promote the European army and thus satisfy the attitude of the belligerent Mr Juncker, whose ideas have not thawed since the end of the Cold War. It is also outrageous that this report proposes to finance military interventions on the EU budget when this is clearly prohibited by Article 41, paragraph 2, of the Treaty on the Eruopean Union. In the face of these glories, france's share of the defence budget must be reduced to 2% of GDP and targeted and temporary bilateral cooperation should be encouraged instead. So I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ We need to provide a renewed focus on where the common security and defence policy (CSDP) can best contribute to global security, by using a comprehensive approach to tackling conflict and by complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence. We support initiatives that could improve the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of CSDP actions. However, we do not agree with proposals asking for an increase in common funding for military actions, duplicating of the work of NATO, or interfering in what should be Member State or industry-driven activity. I therefore voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the financing of the European common security and defence policy. This text stresses the need for the Union to urgently adapt to the new security challenges that have emerged at its borders and in its immediate vicinity. The measures contained in the resolution include the establishment of permanent financial procedures for cooperation between the Commission, the EEAS, the European Defence Agency, the European Space Agency and the Member States. The aim is to ensure that the Union becomes a decisive and united player in the face of each of these threats.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report, which has become necessary as the increasingly challenging security environment for the Union, characterised by new risks and threats that no Member State can cope with on its own, requires a strengthening of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) to make it a more effective strategic instrument and a guarantee of the security of EU citizens and the promotion of European interests and values.  We also stress that the annual budget remains too small to meet all the planning, conduct and support tasks, especially at a time when more than one mission is being launched almost simultaneously, but that at the same time it is essential to consider which and how many would be the potential savings for the EU and for the individual national budgets that would result from the promotion of synergies at UNION level in the military sector. , including transport, training and medical care. The Treaty of Lisbon, in fact, lays down new provisions for the EU on the CSDP, which are still unexplored. The Council could therefore use Article 44 TEU, which allows a group of Member States to proceed with the implementation of a CSDP mission in order to develop faster decision-making.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The idea of a common defence policy for Europe dates back to 1948 when the UK, France, and the Benelux signed the Treaty of Brussels. CSDP was on the agenda of the December 2013 European Council meeting when the heads of states discussed how to enhance defence capabilities, strengthen the defence industry and improve the effectiveness, visibility and impact of the CSDP. Now, this report will bring new concrete measures, pragmatic solutions, cost savings/efficiency-increasing initiatives, transparency and accountability. As shadow rapporteur, I have voted for this report calling for a strengthened cooperation mechanism between Member States.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. The report advocates a need to develop a European market for defence equipment and services. While at times it attempts to justify this by referring to Member State and EU security it is clear its concern is for the European military industry itself. The report states that, ‘the EU 28 Member States are still the world’s number two when it comes to both defence spending and arms exports; believes that this fact shows that the EU Member States and the Union still play a key role in global arms sales and defence procurement.’ The report also calls for EU funding opportunities for defence related projects which I oppose. We have seen the terrible effects of the military industrial complex elsewhere, and its role in perpetuating conflict. I am opposed to the militarisation of the EU and the use of Irish or EU taxpayers’ money for the EU military industry.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this very important budgetary text due to the need we have in the European Union for Member States to start listening to the recommendations found within. We have, collectively, one of the worldʼs largest defence expenditure budgets, yet individually our Member States are badly underfinanced in terms of the Helsinki Headline Goals. We have significant potential and we are wasting it by refusing to cooperate, by having joint programmes only in the least sensitive areas and by allowing nationalistic, limited mindsets to prevail in our defence ministries. The European Union needs to start planning and spending money in a comprehensively complementary way. We need to stop duplication or even investing in obsolete capacities and to start using our financial resources, which are quite ample if we look at the total figure, in a realistic way.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. In principle, a permanent method of financing as well as joint market research, industrial research, space research and development policies is important and useful. On the other hand, however, they are inflating the EU apparatus and the budget. That is why I abstained on this point.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. U2012 EU external action funding is capital to meet EU objectives. That is why we regret the downward trend in defence budgets in recent years as a result of the financial crisis. It is true that we must control that budgets and expenditures must be efficient; We therefore pressure the High Representative to exercise leadership in EU external action and to encourage debate on concrete measures to finance and modulate expenditure.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the security environment is showing increasingly challenging challenges inside and outside the Union, being characterised by new risks and threats that no Member State can cope with on its own, a strengthening of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) is required to make it a more effective strategic instrument and a genuine guarantee of the security of the citizens of the European Union and the promotion of European interests and values.  In view of the fact that the Union must strengthen security at its external borders, which is in any case provided for adequate democratic control at the level of the Union's institutions over all missions and operations, be they civilian or military, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the joint security and defence policy funding report because of the importance of this topic in today's European Union environment. The main purpose of the report is to raise the concerns of the European Parliament before the European Council in June and to warn of the shortcomings of funding for the Common Security and Defence Policy system. The annual joint funding of all Member States is around €190 billion, but this remains insufficient to fulfil the task of security insurers in its environment.  The report calls for more flexible and coherent funding, cites major identified problems such as duplications, lack of transparency, lack of flexibility in rules and mechanisms, lack of transparency in financial allocations related to missions and operations. The report highlights the need to save funds and initiatives that increase efficiency, coherence and complementarity, transparency and accountability.  It calls for reform of the Athens Mechanisms, the financing of joint and security and defence policy military operations, towards lines of increasing the common expenditure catalogue which currently remains very low and is not an incentive for member states to contribute.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. It makes perfect sense that those who advocate a common defence policy should want to put in place the means to finance it. It makes just as much sense that those who oppose such a betrayal of the sovereignty of the peoples would forcefully refuse to finance its implementation. It is therefore in full coherence with my previous vote that I also vote against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support colleagues Kukan and Taranda's report on the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The EU and the Member States are the biggest investors in financing various peacekeeping and crisis management operations around the world, and that civilian and military missions and operations under the CAP represent only a very small part of the total funding. The importance of these UCDP interventions in terms of peacemaking is exceptional, which is why Member States should take a clearer stance towards conflict prevention, post-conflict reconstruction and sustainable peace in conflict zones.  The nature of the interventions under the ZSDP remains very modest, especially those of the military, which are mainly small-scale military training missions, rather than a significant European contribution to peacekeeping and enforcement. Recent crises along 15 000 kilometres of European borders are the best indicator and call to change this, as this report calls for, and therefore I support it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ A number of problems and challenges are identified in the European security environment, the boundaries between external and internal security are becoming less visible. The EU has a clear interest in taking on the strategic responsibilities of European security and solving security problems outside the continent, so strengthening the role in the context of the Berlin Plus agreement must be stronger.  I support this report, but I express concern that despite the joint annual defence budget of around €190 billion, we are failing to meet our main Helsinki targets. We can't let ourselves still talk about missed opportunities. Good financial resource management, more flexible and efficient mission implementation are conditio sine qua non. It is necessary to examine certain financial aspects of military missions and operations, the Athena mechanism was used for 5 military operations, the share of joint expenditure is only 10%. The Lisbon Treaty provides for the implementation of tasks by a group of states which is unused. Military-civilian synergies are needed that will speed up the decision-making process and allow for faster reaction and greater efficiency.  I welcome the call to connect internal security stakeholders with external defence stakeholders regarding the consolidation of financial rules and other forms of cooperation. The High Representative should take the lead in the ZSOP with the aim of better coordination and better cooperation. Multiple sources of funding need to grow from problems to advantage because we need to talk about successful implementation, not untapped potential.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent threats that the EU faces almost daily require a strengthening of the common security and defence policy to make it a real instrument of protection and guarantee for EU citizens and to implement actions that no Member State could afford by its own means alone.  I agree with what is said in the report, which I voted in favour of: in all CSDP operations and missions, be they civilian or military, there must be better and more efficient use of the financial allocations, especially as a result of budget cuts in defence spending. There must always be structured cooperation with regard to the missions and operations of the CSDP, with total transparency on expenditure so that the credibility of the actions taken is not tarnished. It will be up to the EP to monitor how the various operations and missions of the CSDP are budgeted for.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The security of the Union, both internal and external, is now a crucial issue. Threats are multiplying, and the Union must be able to defend its territory and protect its citizens.  With this in mind, I voted in favour of the resolution on the financing of the common security and defence policy. I stress the importance of promoting concrete measures and pragmatic solutions, thus enabling the Union to have a real impact.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. We are concerned that European states are spending less and less on defence, despite the need to increase their investments in order to respond to new threats. And within these reduced budgets, missions under the common security and defence policy represent only a small part.  The legislative instruments at our disposal are also not sufficient to enable us to use these limited resources effectively and cost-effectively. Unfortunately, it is the European taxpayers who are paying the final bill for this incoherent management. The economic crisis is often cited as a reason for this insufficient funding. However, we should see the crisis as a catalyst for European defence, given the potential savings that would result from deep cooperation between Member States. In the scenario of a fully integrated European defence system, the total budget would amount to EUR 62.9 billion instead of the EUR 193 billion currently spent by the 28 states. An economy of scale for an improved response capacity, however, is how the European Union could have more influence on the international stage.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The discussion of the report on the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy is an opportunity to recover some provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon that have not yet been explored. I am aware that it is necessary to strengthen the Defence Capabilities of the European Union, but it is also necessary to take into account the budgetary constraints that some Member States are facing. We know that the European Union and the Member States must take on themselves as peacekeepers. However, I believe that the European Union cannot but be at the forefront of solving global problems, while keeping an eye on the cultural, social and political changes that are taking place in the world and which concern all of us.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as considering that in the face of the global context we need more integrated defence cooperation in the face of the global context, in which resources and capacities are shared.  The report also calls for the ATHENA mechanism to be more budgeted and regrets that the actual proportion of the common costs covered by that mechanism remains very low and that the high proportion of expenditure and responsibilities for military operations at national level prevents some of the Member States from actively participating in CSDP operations. The report calls for more flexible and faster implementation of CSDP missions and operations, and stresses the importance of greater cooperation between military operations and civilian missions.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the multiple cuts in the defence budget require a rethinking of its funding. Indeed, it must be noted that, despite a combined annual budget for European defence of around EUR 190 billion, Member States are still unable to meet the targets set in Helsinki in 1999 (i.e., deploy, in sixty days and over a period of at least one year, a rapid reaction force, if necessary, of the importance of an army corps , for the earth component in the range of 50,000 to 60,000 men, based on the resources available to it by each country).  I hope that the June European Council on this topic will be an opportunity to conduct an in-depth debate and to formulate concrete proposals for reforming the financial arrangements of the missions and operations under the CSDP. In addition, concrete measures will need to be taken to strengthen the EU's defence capabilities in addition to NATO, for the European Defence Agency to be further consolidated and for a more sustained common industrial and technological base.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy, which gives voice to Parliament's concerns on the eve of the June European Council about the deficit in the CSDP funding system. It calls for more flexibility and coherence in funding and identifies the lack of transparency in financial allocatements concerning missions and operations as one of the main problems. I also agree with the call for a review of the Athena mechanism to ensure that procedures and rules allow the Eu ropean Union to be more flexible and efficient in the deployment of EU civilian missions and military operations.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted against this report which calls for strengthening the CSDP so that the EU has a much more active role in defence. The report also regrets the EU's low defence budget (EUR 190 billion per year). It is true that the Lisbon Treaty has expanded or even opened up new possibilities for the development of the CFSP and ESDP under other formulas, although the militarisation of the EU has been one of its main axes. We believe that the EU cannot be a military force but a force for peace and for the development of peoples.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ I wish to explain that I abstained on the final vote of this report due to the following: where in this text, security cooperation and joint action by the EU as a whole, in collaboration or in tandem with NATO, is contemplated and endorsed, I am not in agreement, for so long as it is clear that such references do not include or cover neutral states that are members of the EU, unless these autonomously decide to be so associated, and this not least with particular reference to Malta, which as a neutral country, is specifically barred by its Constitution from participating in the programmes of a military alliance.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to express the European Parliament's concerns about a decline in the amount of resources available in the case of THEGP funding. The report calls for a more flexible, coherent funding system. It also sets out the scope of the problems to be solved, such as duplication, lack of transparency and lack of flexibility in the various procedural rules and mechanisms. Furthermore, the opaqueness of financial instruments for missions and operations. The report highlights the objective of cost-effectiveness and efficiency gains. It also initiates the reform of the Athena Mechanism and the KBVP military operations.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The report put to the vote is a clear call for the expansion of the military missions of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The text laments the low investment in missions and calls for increases in military spending. It also raises the possibility for the Union to have a budget to finance the early stages of the missions. On the other hand, the call for increase and efficiency in spending is not without political guidance. The text makes it clear that the Union must be a "genuine player in defence in the context of NATO" and should be complementary to it. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We need to provide a renewed focus on where the CSDP can best contribute to global security, by using a comprehensive approach to tackling conflict and by complementing NATO, which is the cornerstone of European defence. We support initiatives that could improve the efficiency and cost effectiveness of CSDP actions. However, we do not agree with proposals asking for an increase of common funding for military actions, duplicating of the work of NATO, or interfering in what should be Member State or industry—driven activity. We therefore voted against.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report. I do not believe that setting up the funding presented in the report is beneficial for the EU.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Member States are important funders of various peace and crisis management operations worldwide. Civilian and military missions and common security and defence policy operations represent a very small part of all funding, and the importance of a common and defence policy for peace is significant. As the EU budget for the CFSP is insufficient to finance it, the European Defence and Security Council must formulate concrete proposals at the next meeting to reform the financing of common security and defence policy missions and operations so that they are more efficient and successful. On the other hand, Member States must fulfil their commitments to support and consolidate the European Defence Agency and to promote a common industrial and technological base.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 As the EU's security situation is complex and faces new challenges and risks, it is essential to strengthen the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) so that it becomes a more effective policy instrument and a genuine guarantee of the security of EU citizens. It is also important that the management of funds is efficient and transparent.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ While I support initiatives which could improve the efficiency and cost—effectiveness of CSDP missions, this report offers ideas which could interfere in what should be Member State competence. Therefore, I abstained on this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I voted in favour of the common security and defence policy funding report and I consider the issue of financing missions and operations to be essential. I regret that the discussion on this topic initiated by the Council in December 2013 has so far not led to concrete proposals, and I call for the systematic use of the Athena mechanism to finance THE CAP operations and the costs of sending missions, in particular as regards the use of EU battle groups, the infrastructure to accommodate combat forces, the costs associated with establishing entry points to the scene of operations and, where appropriate, , food and fuel safety supplies. The financing of missions and operations under the CAP should be reconsidered so that budgetary resources are used in a better and more cost-effective manner with appropriate democratic oversight of all civilian and military missions and operations at the level of the EU institutions. I also welcome the measures put in place by the Commission within the current financial rules framework to shorten financial procedures for civilian missions under the CAP. In addition, I welcome the fact that possible savings of around €16 million have been identified, which could allow further missions to be financed if needed in the near future.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The vote on the report comes at a time when we are facing various crises and conflicts, including in our vicinity. The European Union and the Member States significantly finance various peacekeeping operations around the world. I do not think that anyone can argue that the intervention of a common security and defence policy is important for achieving peace. I also supported the report because it calls on the Member States to adopt a more forceful position towards conflict prevention, post-conflict reconstruction and the maintenance of lasting peace in conflict zones.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately the report calls for an increase in funds for the implementation of the CFR's objectives for further staticisation of the EU, a position with which we strongly disagree. In addition, the report promotes the strengthening of the increase in interventions, the inclusion of preventive actions in the EU strategy and the strengthening of the EU's association with NATO, positions that also find us vertically opposed.     As the European United Left, we are against militaristic notions that always turn against the people. We believe that the EU has no right to intervene within any country, for the interests of its own powerful. On the contrary, we believe that funding should be directed towards strengthening social development to serve the needs of the people. For these reasons we voted against the report and tabled a minority proposal which, among other things, calls for the radical disarmament (chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear) of the EU but also globally. No military funding from the EU budget, civilian peaceful approaches to conflict resolution and a strict separation of the EU from NATO.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The financing of the CFR and the ATHENA mechanism is a luxury for Europe of the economic crisis. Member States cannot contribute simultaneously to two defence organisations (EU-NATO). Since consultations on CFSP funding do not bear fruit and there is no stable CFR for any initiative to finance military or non-military missions, it is a utopia.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, taking into account that it provides a thorough analysis and data to support the shortcomings in the financing of the EU's common security and defence policy, while also indicating the areas and directions for possible corrections. I agree that, as with regard to the implementation of the CCP as a whole, supporting the Union's joint defence efforts is essential for effective functioning in order to develop and ensure coherence and complementarity with the EU's external relations aspirations and other policies in the future, with a central and strengthened role for the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. My decision was based on the fact that the authors point out the savings and cost-effectiveness potential of creating synergy between military and civilian assets.  Similarly, I consider it important to ensure that the requirements of transparency and accountability are more consistently enforced, in line with the view of the report's authors, and that common security and defence policy cooperation is substantially advanced, in particular the experience of organisational and financing gaps and errors identified in the implementation of joint military operations under Athena.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report. It is at odds with the peaceful vocation which marked Europe after the horrors of the two world wars and the commitment not to repeat the mistakes of the past. Instead, the EU should urgently realise that the show of muscularity is useless and even counterproductive in conflict management, the lasting solution of which is only possible through a strictly peaceful and multilateral approach. On the other hand, the supposed importance of muscularity is underlined in this report, which in no way outlines what is essential, namely the clear demarcation between civilian missions and possible military missions, and thus opens the way to a dangerous ambiguity in the way in which the EU's presence manifests itself in conflict zones. The prospect of the EU budget being weighed down by chapters related to military expenditure, such as those for the creation of battle groups, for the financing of the military and technological defence base or for the extension of the Athena mechanism, is also dangerous. It means taking away additional resources, through taxation, from citizens and taxpayers already exhausted by an economic crisis managed by austerity, and using them for purposes that have nothing to do with increasing prosperity.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Defence policy is one of the most important instruments of the European Union in an international and regional context marked by an increase in instability and a high level of threats to national security of several members of the European Union. I believe that the plea for a more pronounced dimension of the common security and defence policy is welcome – the objectives of this policy are unattainable if the resources made available are not adequate. I also believe that there is a need to increase the level of cooperation between the civilian and military space. The instrumental nature of the common security and defence policy is best served by close cooperation between the two levels. At the same time, it is important that the actions under taken under this policy correspond to the current security concerns of the Member States – a faster and more flexible approach is beneficial. This change, however, depends, crucially, on the allocation of additional financial resources and I support in this context the extension of eligible costs under the ATHENA mechanism.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text, I agree with the rapporteur's observation that despite a combined annual defence budget of around EUR 190 billion, Member States are still not in a position to meet the overall Helsinki targets of 1999.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against it as the report calls for strengthening the role of the CSDP, with an emphasis on improving cooperation mechanisms and adapting them to security threats and challenges. One of the key ideas of the report is the development of the so-called "Military Industrial Complex", which includes tax incentives as part of the plan (drone development, among other things). The economic crisis is interpreted as an excuse to change the ATHENA mechanism, paving the way for possible funding directly through budgets. Moreover, alignment with NATO (as stipulated in the Lisbon Treaty) appears as one of the report's biggest political challenges.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against this report which calls for strengthening the CSDP so that the EU has a much more active role in defence. The report also regrets the EU's low defence budget (EUR 190 billion per year). It is true that the Lisbon Treaty has expanded or even opened up new possibilities for the development of the CFSP and ESDP under other formulas, although the militarisation of the EU has been one of its main axes. We believe that the EU cannot be a military force but a force for peace and for the development of peoples.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because although it has several negative elements, it integrates some of the green amendments and shares the same group analysis: The main problem with a split defence market in Europe is that national defence budgets are not being reduced. Fragmentation, inefficiency, lack of transparency, corruption, mismanagement, and the absence of clear and strict internal market rules remain the general rule.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing.
