We are talking about a report that has to be voted on in favour, as it aims to draw attention to the necessary reforms to be carried out in the financing of the common security and defence policy to avoid duplication, bureaucratic rigidities and at the same time increase efficiency and savings through the implementation of efficient tools.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), because I consider it unacceptable and irresponsible to use EU financial resources to enhance the EU's military dimension, described as a strategic tool to strengthen the EU's role in the prevention and management of international crises. The report, having expressed great concern about the budget cuts that have affected the defence sector in recent years, calls for more money to be allocated to CSDP policies, strengthening the mechanisms for the automatic financing of military missions. In particular, there is a call for further expansion of common expenditure related to military cooperation through the Athena mechanism, which is currently insufficient to cover the costs of military operations. Consideration should also be given to attracting funding from third countries or international organisations, including NATO, which also recommends closer cooperation. Over and above the strong reservations about the approach to foreign policy supported by this report, I believe that, in the context of the serious economic crisis still facing European citizens, it is absurd and a sign of serious irresponsibility to allocate vital resources to militarism, which could be used to combat unemployment, poverty and social exclusion, the roots of instability inside and outside Europe.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The report put to the vote is a clear call for the expansion of the military missions of the Common Security and Defence Policy. The text laments the low investment in missions and calls for increases in military spending. It also raises the possibility for the Union to have a budget to finance the early stages of the missions. On the other hand, the call for increase and efficiency in spending is not without political guidance. The text makes it clear that the Union must be a "genuine player in defence in the context of NATO" and should be complementary to it. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy, which only strengthens and encourages ever-increasing militarisation of the European Union.  I reject this PSDC (common security and defence policy) which is pushing the EU towards an increasingly militarised vision and therefore more and more military operations, when it should focus on political dialogue and peace processes with all its weight in the balance. This vision requires colossal budgetary capacity at the expense of other policies.  The GUE/NGL denounced the automatic financial participation of each Member State in THE Union's military missions as the questioning of the purely civilian nature of these missions, knowing that today the civil and military aspects are increasingly intertwined and confused. The GUE/NGL also condemned the use and development of armed drones and the illegal practice of targeted extrajudicial executions.  I reject this leak forward, to which a majority of the European Parliament is unfortunately in favour for reasons as varied as they are ambiguous.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. This report shrefully omits the effective responsibility of this Europe and its powers in the processes of destabilisation of countries, in financing and supporting extremist groups, terrorists and authoritarian regimes, in the effective underdevelopment of those countries, in the policies of aggression and interference.  Its objectives include european standardisation of security measures on the most diverse fronts, intervention within NATO's policies and objectives, a tool at the service of US imperialist policy, European federalisation of its foreign policy, in particular through the role of the VP/AR which we do not recognise and reject, the enhancement of the ATHENA mechanism, a way to decision militarisation outside the control of the Member States and Parliament.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not vote in favour of the resolution on the financing of the common security and defence policy. Defence is, and should remain, a matter for the Member States. This applies in particular to their financing. Security and defence policy can be organised multilaterally, but funding does not require permanent institutions (especially not at EU level). However, the resolution seeks to create the resolution, as it advocates the 'establishment of a common service centre and a system for the integrated management of resources'. Even a small understanding of the scale of the EU bureaucracy is sufficient to see this as the construction of another bottomless barrel.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the financing of the common security and defence policy. It is a fact that there is still no correlation of reasons and projects in this area. No Member State can face today's challenges on its own. That is why it is necessary to strengthen the CFR: to make it a more effective policy instrument and a real guarantee for the security of EU citizens.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 An alarming figure appears in the report voted on today: as much as EUR 190 billion is spent within the EU on defence. Given the rampant social impacts of austerity in the Member States and given that such huge resources could fuel both the European recovery and the resolution of instability at its root, by addressing social emergencies in theatres of crisis, this expenditure seems absolutely insane.  The EU cannot consider implementing its own military policy, nor should it try to do so. The scarcity of financial resources, the lack of efficiency and effectiveness of decisions and the difficulties of including military missions in the Union budget simply run counter to the European legal framework, which is not prepared for the decision or implementation of military measures, especially in the presence of a CFSP and a CSDP that have not yet been integrated and in the light of a lack of real political union.  Increasing the defence budget, which would be poured into 'Petersberg tasks', also seems to contradict the union's integration objectives: the leadership would always fall within the hands of the most militarily gifted EU States, alienating the possibility of expressing the Union's unique position, if not legitimising the assimilation of weak to strong voices. For all these reasons, I voted against.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The report deplores the modest nature of the common security and defence policy (CSDP) military interventions, rather than "substantial European contributions to the maintenance and imposition of peace", calls for faster and more flexible CSDP missions, and regrets the little contribution of Member States' budgets to the CSDP, and advocates civil-military cooperation. It calls for concrete proposals to be drawn up on the reform of CSDP mission and operations financing schemes, and also considered that concrete measures should be taken to strengthen the EU's defence capabilities in complementarity with NATO. Calls for enhanced defence cooperation, the meeting and sharing of resources, capacities and resources, i.e. supports and calls for an extension of eligible costs under the ATHENA mechanism, extending its scope for the financing of EU military missions. Through the same mechanism, ATHENA calls for the financing of the deployment of EU tactical groupings, in addition to proposing the creation of a fund for military operations.  The reality shows an increasingly militaristic EU, involved in almost all scenarios of interference, destabilisation and military intervention, activities that need funding, which is proposed to be increased here, a prospect which we reject and which we have once again rejected.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I abstained on this report given that I have concerns over the effectiveness of measures proposed in it for the EU Common Security and Defence Policy which are similar to the ones I have already expressed in other reports. But I do want to underscore that it raises a number of critical issues that I would like to see thoroughly addressed when the EU Heads of Government meet during the June summit on defence. A core issue for me is the cyber area, which already today is crucial for ensuring our security, yet it is still too often considered as a threat in the distant future. As a result, we are collectively far behind the curve on making strategic use of cyberspace to defend the rights and interests of our citizens on the global scene. The US, year after year, identifies cyber-attacks as the most serious threat to national security, but in Europe it is hardly on the radar.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab If we want to care about our common security – and there are things that nations can only implement effectively together – we should act unanimously in the North Atlantic Pact, where a majority, the vast majority, but not all of our countries are allied. However, what a properly common policy we can talk about if, seven years after the Russian aggression against Georgia, our Georgian friends are still outside the structures of the Pact, and for these seven years we have not been on the issue of a unanimous presence in the Pact. We should create common institutions, common competences, for a common policy in order to strengthen it, but certainly not to create semblance of politics and paralyse the initiative of our countries. Thank you very much.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of it because the report: It points out that Directive 2009/81/EC on procedures for the award of works, supply and service contracts in the fields of defence and security and Directive 2009/43/EC on transfers of defence-related products are correctly applied to maximise the available rules of the internal market. It points to the need to eliminate compensation in the security and defence sector altogether for distorting competition in the internal market, ensuring the same conditions for all suppliers in access to public contracts and awards, paying particular attention to SMEs. It urges the US to continue its allies. MM to urgently improve the transparency of public procurement in these areas. It calls for the use of the tools referred to in the above-mentioned Directives to maximise resources through procurement through purchasing plants and to ensure that SMEs have an understanding of the supply chain.  The report also highlights the need for a single defence market through the reduction of processes and locks that avoid duplication, which create distortions in the market.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The report on security and defence capabilities in Europe has been presented from an perspective that does not contribute to stability on the continent and its environment. Thus, in addition to "lamenting defence cuts," he notes that military cooperation with Russia (which still occurs in some respects such as satellite launches) undermines the EU's autonomy and independence. At the same time, however, the text stresses that the EU's work within NATO is important to ensure security and stability in Europe and to increase the economic efficiency of missions. On the other hand, the report frequently confuses the European Union as an organisation with Europe as a continent, projecting it as the only legitimate player in geographical space. This is not a secondary aspect, as it implies the denial of the interests of other parties with which we have to live. Good coexistence with our neighbors must be our priority.  That is why I voted against this report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. The report advocates a need to develop a European market for defence equipment and services. While at times it attempts to justify this by referring to Member State and EU security, it is clear its concern is for the European military industry itself. The report states that, ‘the EU 28 Member States are still the world’s number two when it comes to both defence spending and arms exports; believes that this fact shows that the EU Member States and the Union still play a key role in global arms sales and defence procurement.’ The report also calls for EU funding opportunities for defence—related projects, which I oppose. We have seen the terrible effects of the military industrial complex elsewhere, and its role in perpetuating conflict. I am opposed to the militarisation of the EU and the use of Irish or EU taxpayers’ money for the EU military industry. For these reasons I voted against.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report is part of the focus of the forth april's summit on European defence. In particular, it underlines the threat that Russia would pose and calls for an end to the external dependence of defence industries, which is growing year after year. The integrated defence market is also highlighted. But why would we want to limit scientific cooperation on defence to the European Union alone? In this regard, temporary, bilateral or multilateral, and fixed-term partnerships, which can be cancelled at any time, must be the solution. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I am opposed to the common security and defence policy in principle: the UK is a member of NATO and this arrangement works very well for ensuring national security. The tone of this report pushes us ever closer to a fully-fledged EU army and indeed proposes tax incentives for companies cooperating with it. I therefore voted against this.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. In favour of a European army, I agree with the conclusions of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. For years, European defence budgets have seen significant reductions. While in 1997 Member States spent an average of 2.1% of their GNI on defence, this figure was only 1.7% in 2007. Since the economic crisis of 2008 and the resulting austerity policies, this situation has worsened further. Moreover, cuts to defence budgets are made without consultation between Member States.  This lack of coordination puts the Union at risk because it means relinquishing crucial strategic capabilities for the CSDP. Finally, the fall in European defence budgets is pushing European defence industries to increase their exports to third countries. As a result, the European defence industry is becoming increasingly dependent on the outside world, transferring sensitive technologies and promoting armed conflict in other parts of the world. For all these reasons, and if we want to safeguard Europe's strategic independence, we must strengthen European cooperation in the field of defence and we must also fully exploit the rules of the internal market and create a single defence market.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Gomes report on Europe's defence capabilities follows the same logic as the Danjean report and that of Eduard Kukan and Indrek Tarand, which ultimately aim to pool the defences of the Member States of the European Union. Constant in my positions, I categorically reject any idea of mutualization, not out of ideology but out of pragmatism and efficiency. It is unthinkable to imagine an integrated European defence market in the short, medium or even long term. This federalist logic should be rejected in bulk as in detail, because it is clear that the existence of such a market would hinder the decision-making capacities of the Member States and their most basic sovereignty. France, like the other Member States, cannot be limited to such a geographically restrictive view of its interests. As such, scientific cooperation in this area must be subject to temporary and reversible partnerships, not mandatory and imposed technology transfers against the will of States. Therefore, of course, I am voting against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although there are passages in the text that we can support, there are just as many unclear passages that do not take into account the real situation in which individual Member States find themselves; That is why I abstained.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against all three reports on the common defence and security policy. They are all characterised by militaristic thinking, require strong rearmament and underline the link with NATO. In addition, the ATHENA mechanism is needed to finance the EU's military missions, and it is argued that eu battle groups are involved in all types of crisis management.  The EU has been claimed to be a peace project, but it is not at all apparent from the current reports, which are instead characterised by an attempt to build a military power for a federal Europe. As an advocate of détente and peace, I would like the EU and its Member States to emphasise civilly peaceful strategies for conflict resolution instead. That is why I have voted against these three reports

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of it because the report: It points out that Directive 2009/81/EC on procedures for the award of works, supply and service contracts in the fields of defence and security and Directive 2009/43/EC on transfers of defence-related products are correctly applied to maximise the available rules of the internal market; Points to the need to eliminate compensation in the security and defence sector altogether for distorting competition in the internal market, ensuring the same conditions for all suppliers in access to public contracts and awards, paying particular attention to SMEs; It urges the US to continue its allies. MM to urgently improve the transparency of public procurement in these areas; calls for the use of the tools referred to in the above-mentioned Directives to maximize resources through procurement through procurement facilities and to ensure that SMEs have an understanding of the supply chain.  The report also highlights the need for a single defence market through the reduction of processes and locks that avoid duplication, which create distortions in the market.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which discusses security and defence capabilities in Europe. The European Parliament expresses its deep concern at the escalating armed conflict in the EU's immediate neighbourhood, low-intensity crises, hybrid warfare and proxy war, state instability, instability and widespread human rights violations, as well as the threat of terrorism within the EU. Security conditions are facing increasingly complex and greater challenges, and the European defence sector is at risk of being dependent on external factors. Cross-cutting security and defence challenges, such as the uncoordinated defence budget of the Member States, the constant fragmentation of the market, despite new market rules, the increasing dependence of the defence industry on eu external exports and growing foreign investment in the European defence sector in some countries, must be addressed. It must also be noted that the EU has recently been increasingly exposed to risks and challenges in the computer space, which poses a serious threat to the security of both individual Member States and the EU as a whole. Such threats should be properly assessed and action taken at EU level to provide for technical and other security measures in the Member States.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The fact is that EU Member States remain in second place in the world when it comes to defence sector costs and arms exports. This shows that Member States and the Union still play a key role in the global arms and defence procurement trade. Nevertheless, there is a clear need for better harmonisation of national defence planning procedures and in this regard I welcome the fact that the Council has adopted a Framework for a Policy on Systematic and Long-Term Defence Cooperation. In conclusion, I call on the Commission to clearly identify and mobilise EU funding and instruments aimed at faciliting the establishment of a European Common Market for the defence industry.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. The report advocates a need to develop a European market for defence equipment and services. While at times it attempts to justify this by referring to Member State and EU security, it is clear its concern is for the European military industry itself. The report states that, ‘the EU 28 Member States are still the world’s number two when it comes to both defence spending and arms exports; believes that this fact shows that the EU Member States and the Union still play a key role in global arms sales and defence procurement.’ The report also calls for EU funding opportunities for defence—related projects, which I oppose. We have seen the terrible effects of the military industrial complex elsewhere, and its role in perpetuating conflict. I am opposed to the militarisation of the EU and the use of Irish or EU taxpayer’s money for the EU military industry.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I think it is necessary for the Union and the States to ensure that security and defence capacity is ensured and, at the same time, the defence industry is properly supported, as a key sector of the economy both in volume and in terms of capacity for innovation.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report anticipates the next European Defence Summit scheduled for June. He rightly points out the various threats facing Europe: hybrid wars, terrorism and increasing external dependence on the "European" defence industries. The report takes the pretext of the occurrence of common threats, in order to push the Union to strengthen the development of an integrated European defence market. It is worth reminding the technocrats in Brussels that such a market is simply unthinkable. Indeed, scientific and military cooperation between several States is by nature reversible, since it depends on the temporary framework of bilateral or multilateral relations between them. This is why Member States must not limit themselves to "European" partnerships and develop military cooperation with third countries, such as Russia. Opposed to the principle of the creation of a European army under the aegis of NATO, I voted against this text which is part of the parentage of the two previous reports.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In an environment characterised by a significant increase in the number of armed conflicts, low-intensity crises, hybrid or intermediate warfare, failed states or frequent human rights violations in the immediate neighbourhood of the European Union, as well as the threat of terrorism inside and outside the EU, a coordinated and unified approach at Union level is necessary. Particular attention should be paid to the impact of certain projects on the autonomy and independence of the European Union, and Member States should prioritise military or defence industries and provide incentives for their development, to the extent that European Union law permits. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the success of the peacekeeping and security missions in the PSAC depends on the establishment of a European defence market in order to eliminate overlaps and reduce red tape.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. This report, too, is too 'crushed' on the imposition of a single line for all Member States. It is considered that an internal market based on common rules is necessary for the development of European defence technology competition and industrial base (EDITB) and that it is crucial to ensure the necessary capabilities and, therefore, the security of EU citizens.  The approach is wrong: the means are already there and they are those of the Member States, if the EU then fails to take a position on the relevant defence issues and confines itself to basing its foreign and defence policy on the choices made by NATO and the USA, it will serve no purpose to constitute yet another bureaucratic creature. It seems to me that the aim of this report is to give further benefits to the large industrial groups in the defence sector, perhaps outside Europe.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The report on the impact of developments in the European defence market on common security and defence capabilities highlights the need to coordinate Member States' defence market-related economic policies. Even if the area of defence remains mainly the competence of the Member States, in order for the single market to function optimally, European countries must cooperate and remove trade barriers in this area. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. The report has highlighted that, in order to be truly effective, peacekeeping and security missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) must be able to respond quickly and immediately. In order to achieve these objectives, a fundamental aspect is the presence of a genuine European defence market.  However, the European defence market is too fragmented, leading to a growing dependence of European defence industry on non-EU exports. I therefore believe that the Member States should do more to achieve a more integrated European market, which would make it possible to limit the duplication of defence programmes and research activities and to increase European competitiveness in this area. I therefore hope that the June Council, as the report points out, will be able to take concrete measures and provide specific guidelines in this regard.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report because we do not support the formation of EU military capabilities and reject EU interference in the defence, security and foreign affairs policy of Member States. The split vote on Article 1 calls for the Member States to meet defence treaty obligations. Although UKIP would ensure that the UK at least meets the 2% NATO target, this further interference of the EU in domestic policy sets a dangerous precedent for further powers to be transferred to EU level.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, while presenting several aspects on which I cannot agree, also highlights some important issues such as better optimisation of expenditure, the search for synergies and cooperation between states and a more careful and profitable management of the cost-benefit ratio with taxpayers' money. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which has no other purpose than the creation of a single European defence market. In the same vein as the reports of Mr Danjean and Mr Kukan, it is a question of using the security and economic issues currently facing Member States to advocate the pooling of resources. The idea is simple: a European defence market will provide the European Federal Army with equipment. The report also urges the Commission to take punitive measures against Member States, which have been accused of failing or mis applying the 2009 defence directives. It is therefore a question of "mater" the recalcitrant states to sell their sovereignty and the interests of their national industries. Finally, once again, strategic partnerships with Russia are being singled out; this is, of course, an attack on France, whose rulers have already submitted to the idea of cancelling the sale of the Mistral. On all fronts, the European Union seeks to disarm nations, but patriots will continue to fight to preserve the strategic interests of their countries.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is a priority not to underestimate the wave of armed conflicts and wars as well as the increasingly worrying threat of terrorism inside and outside the EU. I welcome the fact that the Union is addressing the current situation through a coordinated and unified approach, making sure that the articulation of budgetary policies is more geared towards strategic choices that relate in particular to the review of the defence procurement package.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the impact of developments in european security and defence capability markets in Europe, sharing what it says and convinced that, to the increasingly serious and numerous threats made by terrorist groups to the European Union as a whole, it is necessary to respond in a unified way by pooling civil and military resources and coordinating interventions.    In particular, in order to ensure an adequate level of security and defence in the face of spending cuts due to the economic crisis, it is essential to make the most of the synergies potentially resulting from cooperation between Member States. In this context, the construction of an internal market for properly functioning, competitive and efficient defence products would make a significant contribution to achieving the objectives of the CSDP, including by promoting research and technological innovation, which are prerequisites for the modernisation of the European defence industry.  It should also be noted that increased cooperation between Member States would certainly help to avoid duplication of defence equipment efforts and programmes, which have hitherto been conducted independently of each Member State, further reducing the costs of this policy and ensuring a faster and more incisive response to internal and external challenges and threats.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The report on security and defence capabilities in Europe has been presented from an perspective that does not contribute to stability on the continent and its environment. Thus, in addition to "lamenting defence cuts," he notes that military cooperation with Russia (which still occurs in some respects such as satellite launches) undermines the EU's autonomy and independence. At the same time, however, the text stresses that the EU's work within NATO is important to ensure security and stability in Europe and to increase the economic efficiency of missions. On the other hand, the report frequently confuses the European Union as an organisation with Europe as a continent, projecting it as the only legitimate player in geographical space. This is not a secondary aspect, as it implies the denial of the interests of other parties with which we have to live. Good coexistence with our neighbors must be our priority. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which challenges the Member States in the run-up to the European Defence Summit in June 2015. Beyond the adoption of policy frameworks for defence cooperation, States must take concrete action through enhanced cooperation. These are particularly relevant in the case of the defence equipment market. It also points to the opportunities for defence industries, particularly SMEs, to finance their projects with European funds. Finally, I support the rapporteur's request to draw up a common position on the use of armed drones. I remain convinced that defence is also a European issue.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report presents the main developments in the European defence market and its consequences on security and defence in Europe. I note with concern that the report shows in particular that recent developments could call into question European autonomy as a result of the various budget cuts. Considering that the rapporteur's assessment calls for a common strategy, strengthening regulatory coordination and deepening the internal market in the defence industries, with a view to preserving European autonomy, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I agree with the report on security and defence capabilities in Europe. I think it is essential to work towards the creation of a genuine European single defence market, based on common rules.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. It develops a series of recommendations aimed at concluding an integrated defence deal. More senseless than the others, they must fill the dependence of European states on defence and security. However, we know that the Union seeks to take irreversible and binding decisions. That is why I voted against this report, in order to express my strong and wholesale rejection of these excesses.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR believes defence policy must always remain a matter of national sovereignty. We do not agree with the suggestion that defence spending should be co-ordinated and we continue to resist moves that may undermine NATO and weaken our links with international defence partners, especially the US. We do recognise the importance of having an innovative and expanding defence industry, but we believe this should be brought about by efforts by individual governments to meet the recommended 2% of GNI spend.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report on the impact of changes in European defence markets on security and defence capacity in Europe, because I believe that defence and national security are a priority of the Member States and not a common Union priority.  At a time when we are surrounded by conflict, in the southeast Islamic State and the growing conflict between Iran and Saudi Arabia, in the south of Europe we have disintegrated countries, numerous terrorist groups and a refugee influx, and in the northeast a military conflict on the territory of Ukraine, we need to have an increasingly serious and more responsible defense and national security policy.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Within the framework of national sovereignty, concepts interwoven with accountability for defence arms exports, control of national POs for military expenditure, abolition of compensatory benefits, etc. are incompatible. In particular, the defence package aimed at supporting the competitiveness of the European defence sector will in future lead to the establishment of a monopoly by countries with defence industries.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. It is not relevant or desirable to establish an EU army, but it is important to look at the security and economic benefits we can achieve with increased cooperation and coordination between Member States.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analyses the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. The decrease in European demand due to budget cuts, increasing external dependencies, the potential of internal market rules and the revision of the defence procurement package are some of the topics covered in the document. The European Parliament asks the Commission to monitor the implementation of the two internal market directives in the field of the acquisition and transfers of defence equipment and equipment and to require member states to comply with these rules.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The right-wing majority in the European Parliament supports the European Union's policies of aggression and militarisation, masked in its so-called security policies, resigning from its effective responsibilities in the processes of destabilisation of the countries of Eastern Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, in particular through the financing and support of extremist groups, terrorists and authoritarian regimes in the effective underdevelopment of those countries.  As a route for the consolidation of defence policies, the report advocates valuing and realising the European defence market – the war industry – as an indispensable tool for strengthening the EU's war-mongering capacity. In its objectives, there is continued the European standardisation of security measures on the most diverse fronts, intervention in the framework of NATO's policies and objectives, a tool at the service of US imperialist policy, and the European federalisation of its foreign policy, in particular through the role of the VP/AR which we do not recognise and reject. It strengthens the support and enhancement of research for the security industry, strengthening, financial incentives and tax benefits to the European war industry, in the logic of consolidating a common European defence market, with advances in cybersecurity and increased surveillance. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Legislation on the European defence market was introduced as early as 2009. Recently, however, the Member States of the European Union have faced significant security threats and are therefore introducing new legislation into their national legal systems that is based on transparency and addresses the specificities of the defence sector. Adequate capabilities and supplies of equipment, the strategic autonomy of the European Union are extremely important factors for the security of the citizens of the Member States. We need to focus on strong consolidation, cost-effectiveness and transparency in european defence markets, because the threats to European security have taken on unprecedented proportions. This situation is certainly not benefiting from a significant reduction in investment in science, research and technology in the defence sector.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 My vote is against the report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. Within the framework of national sovereignty, concepts interwoven with accountability for defence arms exports, control of national POs for military expenditure, abolition of compensatory benefits, etc. are not consistent. In particular, the defence package aimed at supporting the competitiveness of the European defence sector will in future lead to the establishment of a monopoly by countries with defence industries.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since it aims at building an innovative and competitive European industry and making the best possible use of the security and defence budget. I agree on the idea that the Commission and the Member States must take defence procurement into account when negotiating international trade agreements. Moreover, I support the idea that the Commission should step up its efforts to achieve a level playing field in European defence markets in order to fight protectionist practices by Member States by promoting cross-border cooperation and better access to defence industry supply chains.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Gomes's report, because I think it is very important that the Member States finally properly and fully transmed the Directive on defence procurement into their legal order, because only by reducing the diversity of public procurement rules in the defence sector can we sufficiently strengthen the single internal market. I, too, regret that previous efforts to unite demand have not improved the situation of demand fragmentation, so rearranging priorities is one of our main tasks.  I believe that a European defence review process should be launched and that coordination of national defence planning processes at EU level should be implemented in the future.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. U2012 The aerospace industry and those related to safety and defence are sectors that have had high added value from the outset, and which are crucial and of strategic interest to the Union. We must not forget that, for example, the Internet, which has led to great advances in the civilian world, was developed as a military project. I voted favourably, then, because Europe must deepen its integration into the framework of security and defence in order to be better prepared for the challenges we are already facing today.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe because it focuses on the fundamental issue of greater cooperation between Member States in this area.  I believe that there is a need for greater convergence of national and European defence and security policies, especially in order to deal with the new and more modern threats from cyberspace and new technologies.  It is important, especially through better implementation of the Horizon 2020 and COSME programmes, that SMEs are facilitated in seizing funding opportunities for the development of European security and defence projects. In this regard, I am concerned that European companies in this sector are being forced to find new market space abroad, with the result that know-how, production and intellectual property are transferred to other countries.  I support the call for the Commission to step up its efforts for greater cross-border cooperation, so as to avoid the implementation of protectionist practices by some Member States, and to support technological innovation, which is the key to a modern and state-of-the-art defence and security industry.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against the Gomes report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. The report highlights new threats such as cyber-terrorism, terrorism and hybrid wars in Eastern Europe. It also highlights industrial cooperation between some Member States and Russia, particularly in the space, scientific and military fields, cooperations seen as a form of dependency. If the partial and Russophobic nature of this finding is already a problem in itself, the solutions advocated are no better. These include fostering an integrated defence market and combating Member States' protectionist defence practices. In other words, this report wants to extend European integration to the defence market, so that the European Union can further reduce the sovereignty of the Member States and have more latitude to pursue its disastrous foreign policy.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against ana Gomes' report. The report begins by emphasizing that the reduction of defence budgets weakens the defence potential of Member States. It also refers to regional instability to justify the call for coordination and increase of European defence budgets. In this regard, it explicitly states that current security threats are common throughout the EU as a whole and must be addressed in a united and coordinated manner, pooling and sharing both civilian and military resources. We vote against it because we believe that the EU cannot be a force of war, but a force for peace.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my S&D colleagues, supported this report as it proposes initiatives that could improve the efficiency and cost—effectiveness of CSDP missions. There are, however, proposals within the text that I am concerned about, including calls to expand common costs for financing military missions and supporting EU tax incentives for cooperation and pooling of capabilities.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe, as adequate capacity and equipment supply are crucial in terms of security between the European Union and its neighbouring countries. In addition, the success of peacekeeping and security missions under the CSDP depends to a large extent on the ability to respond quickly and promptly, and the main objective is therefore to create a real European defence market, avoiding duplication and reducing bureaucratic obstacles.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe there is a need to assess our security capabilities and determine where we could modernise the ways in which we arrange our security policy. Our defence capabilities should take account of the concerns of all Member States.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against ana Gomes' report. The report begins by emphasizing that the reduction of defence budgets weakens the defence potential of Member States. It also refers to regional instability to justify the call for coordination and increase of European defence budgets. In this regard, it explicitly states that current security threats are common throughout the EU as a whole and must be addressed in a united and coordinated manner, pooling and sharing both civilian and military resources. We vote against it because we believe that the EU cannot be a force of war, but a force for peace.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Impact of Changes in European Defence Markets on Security and Defence Capabilities in Europe, as changes in defence markets call into question Europe's autonomy in this regard. It is particularly important to pay attention to this issue given the complex security issues in the EU environment. There is a serious problem of dependence on external markets, as European defence markets are not sufficiently unified, economical and transparent, and there is a mismatch between cuts in defence budgets in most Member States, weakening the defence potential of Member States and the EU and uneasing the level of preparedness to guarantee national and European security. There is a problem of reducing investment in research and technology in the defence sectors of all Member States, as well as joint investments in research and technology in the defence sector through European cooperation. It is necessary to use taxpayers' resources efficiently and to progress in establishing a European market for defence equipment and to develop a competitive technological and industrial base of the European defence sector (EDTIB), capable of achieving synergies through increased cross-border coordination and providing the necessary capacity for ASD.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report is part of the focus of the forth april's summit on European defence. This text particularly underlines the threat that Russia would pose and calls for an end to the external dependence of defence industries, which is increasing year after year. The integrated defence market is also being put forward, which is the opposite of common sense: scientific cooperation on defence should not be limited to the Union, let alone be part of a constant policy. In this regard, temporary, bilateral or multilateral partnerships, and fixed-term partnerships, which can be cancelled at any time, must be the solution: the friend of the day before can, overnight, become a potential enemy.  Thus, the technocrats of the European Union wish to push integration into their Union even further in defiance of the sovereignty of the Member States, to whom they want to remove all foreign and defence policies. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ana Gomes' report on the evolution of European defence markets. This report points to the decline in state spending in their defence budgets and the lack of coordination of states on this issue. It is also concerned about the decline in state investment in European defence companies and a greater reliance on non-European companies in this sector. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. At a time when the European Union is facing unprecedented multiple and direct threats, we need to structure a European defence market, the only one capable of guaranteeing the dependence of the European defence sector and encouraging better cost pooling.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from voting, although the proposed creation of a European defence market to eliminate duplication and reduce administrative work makes sense from an Austrian point of view. However, a lack of consolidation, cost-effectiveness, and transparency in defense markets means that external dependencies, such as large military alliances, could continue to increase. I am abstaining in the light of Austria's neutrality.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I support improving the competitiveness of the defence industry, stimulating innovation and growth. The report, however, offers ideas which could interfere in what should be Member State competence.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The EU military industry is splitting itself a significant slice of one of the world's largest and dirtiest businesses. While the report hypocritically advocates defence and security, it is in fact the provision of a tool for unscrupulously manly wars on Earth.  By the way, the material supports a policy that goes against a Europe of nations, which is contrary to the original EU mind, to the interests of our citizens and to my position.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The report expresses Parliament's concern at the widespread cuts in the defence budget in most Member States. The lack of coordination can put the functioning of these policies at risk, leading to the renunciation of strategic means and the loss of opportunities that could be offered by better synergy of defence policies. It also expresses concern at developments in the European defence market, which are increasingly seeing room for external dependencies in this sector, at a time when security conditions are becoming increasingly demanding. For these reasons, I support this report, aware of the real need for decisive action.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it wants to create an integrated defence market. However, I believe that in defence, a state must retain the power to form temporary partnerships with whom it wants, concluded within a freely negotiated bilateral or multilateral framework. I also condemn the interference advocated by this text in the negotiations by the States of their public defence contracts.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. The report's aim is to strengthen the financial and human resources of the common security and defence policy. Again, we find the will to abandon all forms of sovereignty for the Member States by obeying the NATO that would lead the various operations. The financial mutualisation desired by this project would accentuate the creation of a European defence, which would mean the loss of our sovereignty in this area. The Commission wants to abolish individualised funding, which clearly means the end of the independence of Member States that will be unable or unable to participate freely in military actions.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report on the impact of developments in the European defence market on security and defence capacities in Europe falls within the competence of both the JURI Commission and the IMCO Commission. It highlights the need for a single defence market through the reduction of processes and locks that avoid duplication, which generate distortions in the market. One of the essential elements in favour of European independence in security and defence is to be able to have a European industry in the highly competitive sector based on R&I. However, market fragmentation makes collaboration between Member States limited and research fragmented. It also points to the need to establish prior planning for strategic investment in procurement and material renewals between Member States. Like the Spanish Socialist Delegation as a whole, I considered it necessary to vote in favour of its approval.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution, which also contains paragraph 13, in which Parliament 'calls for cooperation and merger and joint use of initiatives to be considered as a priority area', 'calls on the European Commission to put forward a proposal , [...] how tax incentives could contribute to achieving these objectives', 'considers that The European Defence Agency's projects should be exempt from VAT' and 'expects to include measures to promote cooperative purchases of defence equipment and the provision of appropriate support.' It therefore calls on the Commission to do more on the common defence and security policy, apparently with a view to building a European army, as High Representative Mogherini says. I do not agree that the European Union should have its own security and defence policy, let alone its own army. As a defence alliance in Europe, NATO serves member states well, and it is neither necessary nor desirable to dub or compete with the European defence alliance.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report concerning the impact of developments in European defence markets on the security and defence capabilities in Europe (2015/2037((INI)).  Recent events in Europe show an increasing need to strengthen the defence potential of all 28 Member States. Security is an issue which concerns us all and this is why security threats need to be addressed in a transparent and coordinated fashion.  Defence spending at EU level is EUR 190 billion – an enormous amount of money. The defence budgets are being spent in a very inefficient way due to delays and incoordination. This money is tax payers’ money. Not having a common defence market implies the risk of corruption in public procurement. This is why I support a common security defence framework in order to enable the Union to deal efficiently with security threats, ensure EU competition and at the same time to protect the money of the citizens.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The current situation shows that Member States are mainly cutting defence budgets as a result of the crisis, thus uneasying their readiness to participate in missions and military operations to ensure peace. Member States' cooperation on the use of existing capacities is also weak and public procurement processes are opaque. On the other hand, armed attacks, crises like in the Republic of Macedonia, hybrid wars and great instability and violations of human rights and freedoms are occurring in our neighbourhood and affecting the Union as a whole, so we need to address them with a common approach. Establishing a competitive and integrated military industry would result in greater military capacity for Member States, but would also have a positive economic impact. The development of the military industry should focus not only on military equipment, but also on various technology that could help both Member States and third countries fight digital threats. Military technology should serve primarily as a means of prevention and help third countries increase security capacity. In order to create a more effective common security and defence policy of the Member States, I supported the Gomez Report, which proposes a number of changes that would strengthen the military capabilities of the Union, as well as the military industry.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not vote in favour, I abstained. So did a number of my fellow Socialists from Germany and Austria. We need to think about peace and job creation first and foremost.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe because it promotes the image and subsequent action of a militaristic European Union that seeks to increasingly involve itself and its Member States in EU military and non-military operations while funding from national budgets.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution because I believed it moved into areas that should be Member States’ competence.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I believe that the European Structural and Investment Funds as well as the COSME or Horizon 2020 programmes should not finance the defence industry, much less should advocate budget cuts with the aim of increasing the defence sector budget.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on security and defence capabilities in Europe, as I believe that the approach of this report is quite correct, but that the drafting has not yet reached a final stage and needs to be improved. The failures in the area of consolidation, cost-efficiency and transparency in European defence markets mean that the external dependence of the European defence sector on NATO could continue to increase.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In line with the warmongering of reports on European defence, this text promotes "the gradual establishment of a European market for defence equipment". The main aim is to avoid cooperation with Russia in sensitive areas such as satellite launches, Soyuz rockets or strategic airlift. Moreover, the text claims to "fight against the protectionist practices of the Member States" in order to further limit the sovereignty of States in defence. There is no question of taking charge of the defence of irresponsible belligerents. I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report is part of the focus of the forth april's summit on European defence. This text particularly underlines the threat that Russia would pose and calls for an end to the external dependence of defence industries, which is increasing year after year. The integrated defence market is also being put forward, which is the opposite of common sense: scientific cooperation on defence should not be limited to the Union, let alone be part of a constant policy. In this regard, temporary, bilateral or multilateral partnerships, and fixed-term partnerships, which can be cancelled at any time, must be the solution: the friend of the day before can, overnight, become a potential enemy. Thus, the technocrats of the European Union wish to push integration into their Union even further in defiance of the sovereignty of the Member States, to whom they want to remove all foreign and defence policies. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report calls on the EU Member States to fully and correctly implement the two European Directives on the acquisition of defence material and intra-Community transfers of military material and calls for greater coordination of defence policies of the 28.  The decrease in European demand due to budget cuts, increasing external dependencies, the potential of internal market rules and the revision of the defence procurement package are some of the topics covered in this document.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report raises concerns over the spread of armed conflict in the EU’s immediate neighbourhood as well as the threat of terrorist attacks inside and outside the Union. The reduced potential for Member States to effectively respond to these threats because of the decline in funding allocated to defence and security is of concern. The report suggests that a competitive and modern European industrial defence strategy may aid in increasing the Union’s defence capabilities and benefit related economic sectors. I therefore chose to support this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. There is no community of destiny without common defence. There can be no foreign policy without a union defence policy commensurate with its economic capacity. Europe needs a common security and defence policy more than ever to respond optimally to the many challenges to its security. At a time when the European defence market is fragmented and some states are adopting protectionist attitudes, a coordinated response is needed. In this regard, the aid and compensation provided by national governments to their industries must be abolished. A unified European defence market would lead to substantial savings in spending and would push European companies to modernisation and innovation. That is why I fully support any initiative to promote the establishment of a single European defence market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on security and defence capabilities in Europe, which calls on the European Commission and Member States to do more to create a genuine EU defence market. I agree with the rapporteur that an efficient single market, based on common rules, is vital for the development of a competitive European Defence Technological and Industrial Base, which in turn is crucial to secure the capabilities needed for the security of EU citizens.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The efficiency of the Common Security and Defence Policy, in particular civilian missions and military operations, depends to a large extent on a genuine European defence market that can eliminate duplication and bureaucracy. This idea was defended by the European Council, which supports the establishment of a Union-wide security of supply regime.  At a time of multiple threats and regional conflicts, the Union's security needs a strategy, which involves the creation of a European market for defence equipment and services.  I am in favour of this report and stress the need for increased cooperation and coordination between Member States in the articulation of defence budgetary policies and the coordination of equipment procurement options.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on 'Europe's defence capabilities' is in line with the previous Danjean and Kukan and Tarand reports on the mutualisation of the defences of eu Member States on the grounds that it would avoid duplication, reduce costs and improve management. But why stop this mutualisation on a Europe-wide scale, and not start it on a world scale (and more...)?  What would have been done with the pooled elements during the war in Iraq, when more than 80% of the EU countries had taken a stand for G. Bush? 20% of the Charles de Gaulle would have stayed in France, the rest joining the Americans? What would have been done in Libya, where the German government has repeatedly expressed its reluctance (and rightly so)?  This would hamper Member States' capacity for action. The divergent interests of the Member States show the inanity of such a project which can only satisfy the "best" ally of Brussels: the United States.  Let us first propose targeted and temporary bilateral agreements (thus reversible), especially in the technological field, and not in a mandatory way. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the impact of changing defence markets on the security and defence capabilities of the European Union. This text recalls our growing dependence on exports outside the European Union and the increase in foreign investment in the European defence sector in some countries. This could lead to a lack of transparency and the transfer of control of strategic industries, resources and technologies at the national and European level.  This resolution calls for enhanced cooperation by Member States and the development of an effective and independent European defence industrial and technological base. It is about ensuring Europe's ability to protect its citizens, interests and values.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report, which has become necessary given that investment in defence research and technology in all Member States, as well as joint investment in defence research and technology in European cooperation, has declined at an alarming rate in recent years, and considering that the success of peacekeeping and security missions under the CSDP depend to a large extent on their ability to respond quickly and The need to create a genuine European defence market, in order to eliminate duplication and reduce bureaucracy, is therefore a fundamental aspect.  We are also concerned about the risks of external dependencies in the European defence sector at a time when security conditions are becoming increasingly complex and demanding, in particular the combined effect of the lack of coordination of Member States' defence budgets, the persistent fragmentation of the market despite the new rules of the internal market, the growing dependence of the defence industry on non-EU exports and the increase in foreign investment in the European defence sector in certain countries.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Taking into consideration the current political threats at the EU’s eastern borders, the alarming decrease of development in the defence market due to budget cuts, and growing external dependencies, I have voted for this report in order to re—establish European autonomy through increased cooperation and co—ordination between Member States.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for Ms Gomesʼ report as it highlights the very real risk of fragmentation in the European defence market at a point where we might need it more than in the past 20 years. With rising violent extremism, failed states, instability in our neighbourhood and armed aggression against our partner countries, we cannot afford that each Member State decides unilaterally to cut defence budgets, abandon defence research and development or, perhaps even worse, duplicate the capabilities of other Member States which they could share together, saving a great deal of money. We cannot afford either for many states to keep buying or reconditioning obsolete technologies from outside the European markets, and I believe the 2009 defence package should be a main priority for implementation in all the Member States which have not yet done so.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The drastic cuts in defence can certainly be seen as a threat to security in Europe. It is also to be welcomed that the defence industry should be promoted from the resources of the Horizon 2020 programme. However, the report lacks crucial points such as cost-efficiency and transparency in European defence markets – this means that external dependencies in the European defence sector can continue to increase. That is why I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. "U2012 One of the most important manifestations to have in the EU's external action is progress towards an internal defence market. With the crisis and the cuts that have accompanied it, they have made the European defence industry increasingly dependent on exports. We need to increase responsiveness and greater integration to reduce costs. We need to stop and end the widespread and uncoordinated cuts made to the defence budget of most Member States.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 The current security threats are relevant to the EU as a whole and this issue should be dealt with in a unified and coordinated manner. However, it is essential that the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity are respected in these extremely complex issues. The sovereignty of the Member States must not be violated or restricted. In order to ensure security and stability in Europe and neighbouring countries, particular attention should be paid to certain projects relating to the eu's autonomy and independence.  Consolidating the defence industry must create a level playing field for all countries. The European defence equipment market cannot be created in breach of the legitimate expectations of the Member States. Full transparency must be ensured and duplication of efforts must be avoided. Priority should be given to cooperation and aggregation and sharing initiatives. It is essential to ensure resource efficiency. Particular attention and support should be given to viable small and medium-sized enterprises and innovation centres in order to facilitate their establishment on European and international markets.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Whereas the new legislation on the European defence market was introduced with the 2009 defence package and all 28 Member States transposed the new provisions into their national legal systems; that the crux of this new legislation is the introduction of a regulatory framework based on transparency, non-discrimination and competition that addresses the specificities of the defence sector; that The Member States have agreed on the need to develop a European market in defence equipment and services; that the European Council has also called for the establishment of a security of supply regime at Union level; that the adequacy of equipment capacity and supply, as well as a strategic autonomy of the EU, are of fundamental importance for the security of the Union and its neighbourhood, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The European Union meets on its southern and eastern borders with numerous challenges such as migration, political instability, rebellion, pent-up and even open wars. Most of the causes are unfortunate events that either destabilise the economy of our countries or represent a dangerous humanitarian situation that we cannot and must not ignore, arise due to instability in neighboring countries or instability caused by the policies of other forces that are being led towards our neighbors. The European Union can contribute to peace and stability through a clear foreign policy supported by a strong economic and security and defence policy. Unfortunately, the fact is that without a recognized military force, one cannot be a serious political player on the global front. European defence policy is linked to the membership of most Member States in the North Atlantic Alliance. Nato Member States' obligation is to contribute to a common defence policy, according to known financial criteria. A clear common security and defence policy focused on achievable objectives and supported by adequate and secure funding can help overall economic growth, but also the seriousness of European foreign and economic policy globally, and I supported this report.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report highlights the threats (hybrid wars in the eastern neighbourhood, terrorism) and mentions the risk of increased external dependence on "European" defence industries as a result of the crisis and vis-à-vis Russia, with which states maintain trade and scientific relations in the military field.  To address these threats, the text makes a series of recommendations to enable the emergence of an integrated defence market (common position on exports, control of dual-use civil/military technologies). It also addresses the issues of funding (e.g. linking or not to horizon 2020) and management methods (pool and sharing). It calls for combating protectionist practices in the field of defence. Like the previous texts, it is therefore part of the federalist logic of establishing a common European army. Refusing to endanger France's independence in defence and the defence industry, I obviously vote against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Gomez's report, which correctly highlights concerns about the increasing number of armed conflicts, the outbreak of low intensity crises, hybrid warfare and warfare through intermediaries, the failure of states, instability and numerous cases of human rights violations in the EU's immediate neighbourhood, and the threat of terrorism inside and outside the EU. At the same time, Member States are unevenly changing and largely downplaying defence spending. I agree with the rapporteur, who stresses that a highly competitive, modern and united Strategy of the European Defence Industry is essential for developing Europe's defence capabilities and delivering a positive indirect impact on related economic sectors and prioritising cooperation, pooling and joint initiatives and providing incentives to this end. The establishment of a single defence market would ensure full transparency and prevent the easuing of efforts leading to market distortions. The success of THE COSP peacekeeping and security missions depends largely on rapid response capabilities and that greater integration is essential for streamlining procedures and cutting costs.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. I support this Report but I must raise concerns about the pervasive cuts in defence budgets in most Member States which puts the Union at risk by giving up strategic resources and capacity and the opportunities that a coherent defence policy and merger would bring. The emergence of armed conflicts, hybrid warfare, instability and cases of human rights violations in the EU's immediate neighbourhood and the threat of terrorism within the EU are a worrying fact. Security threats are common to the EU as a whole and should be addressed in a single and coherent manner, pooling civilian and military means. The European defence sector is becoming increasingly dependent on external markets, which combined with deduct defence budgets is a worrying piece of concern. Insufficiently generous defence budgets need to be replaced by better cooperation between Member States, including by designing policies on defence budgets and harmonising strategic choices relating to the procurement of military equipment. European defence companies are increasingly making up for lower revenues in Europe through exports outside the EU, which means transferring sensitive technology and intellectual property rights to future competitors and moving production outside the EU. The security of supply mechanism should include an effective system of control over strategic assets and supplies from third countries in order to identify existing and potential shortcomings. Ensuring security of supply between Member States is a fundamental element of creating a united European defence market.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the face of the increasing reduction in Member States' defence budgets and the proliferation of armed conflicts and international crises, the Union must be able to properly and effectively mobilise its resources in order to play a key role on the international stage and contribute to the global balance. In this context, Parliament adopted a motion for a resolution on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe.  I am pleased to have voted in favour of this text. This proposal highlights the importance of strengthening the capacity and competitiveness of our European defence industry through the development of an industrial strategy. We must use the current capabilities at the Eu's disposal to strengthen our European security and defence policy.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. A more influential Europe needs a strong and active common security and defence policy, which in turn requires a more competitive and effective defence and security sector. In reality, the defence industry remains too fragmented in Europe, with significant state aid in several countries, leading to a difficult internal competition situation. European companies are faced with large American groups, which benefit from a much larger market. At present, European countries share only one-fifth of their equipment purchases and, even worse, they achieve only one-eighth of their joint research and technology effort. In this gloomy context, where the economic crisis also plays its part, we must take greater advantage of the means already put in place to promote a genuine continental market and improve the competitiveness of our businesses. This is how Europe will achieve its strategic autonomy, and our common security and defence policy will gain credibility and visibility. This is the role that our citizens expect of us, as well as our key allies in the world.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. A common security and defence policy is essential in a Europe that wants to be united. In this area too, we have to speak with one voice. A common defence policy will serve not only to strengthen Europe's defence capacity (reducing dependence on third countries) but also to foster technological innovation and also to make substantial savings, avoiding sometimes redundant expenditures. This is a controversial area. At a time of economic crisis, investing in a defence industry may seem misplaced; however, they will be investments that Member States will not be able to make on an individual basis. It is only a question of coordinating these spending at European level, increasing cooperation and capacity and equipment sharing, while at the same time fostering a modern, integrated and competitive European defence industry.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This report I voted on underlines that, at present, the Union does not yet have all the resources necessary to make a decisive contribution to the prevention or management of international crises and to the affirmation of its autonomy and strategic interests. In particular, the report highlights the structural shortcomings suffered by missions and operations under the common security and defence policy, including the slowness and rigidity of the decision-making process. The report also called for the creation of a pre-financing mechanism to help Member States wishing to participate in operations to bear the costs; it is considered that these operations are an important element of the Eu's overall approach and contribution to international security, but it is noted, at the same time, that since 2009 missions have been deployed to improve the visibility of the Union's response to crises, not as strategic actions following extensive analysis and planning. The European Council in June will be devoted to defence. I hope this will be an opportunity to take a big step forward!

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which expresses Parliament's concern at the widespread, and largely uncoordinated, cuts in the defence budget in most Member States.
