I am of the opinion that this lack of coordination jeopardises the security of the European Union, leading to the renunciation of strategic means and capabilities and by missing out on the opportunities that could be offered by coordinating defence policies and by grouping and sharing the means of defence with regard to the realisation of the EU's strategic autonomy, the security of its supplies and the defence of its citizens and interests.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted against the report proposed by Ana Gomes. The report begins by emphasizing that the reduction of defence budgets weakens the defence potential of Member States. It also refers to regional instability to justify the call for coordination and increase of European defence budgets. In this regard, it explicitly states that current security threats are common throughout the EU as a whole and must be addressed in a united and coordinated manner, pooling and sharing both civilian and military resources. We vote against it because we believe that the EU cannot be a force of war, but a force for peace.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on this resolution is subject to the reservation below: where in this text, security cooperation and joint action by the EU as a whole, in collaboration or in tandem with NATO, is contemplated and endorsed, I am not in agreement, for so long as it is clear that such references do not include or cover neutral states that are members of the EU, unless these autonomously decide to be so associated, and this not least with particular reference to Malta, which as a neutral country, is specifically barred by its Constitution from participating in the programmes of a military alliance.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Gomes's report and I also thank you for including my comments, which respond to the recent negative experience with the storage of military equipment in the Czech Republic. Last year, two citizens lost their lives as a result of uncontrolled explosions in the area of the ammunition depot in Vrbětice, hundreds of people had to temporarily stay away from their homes, and the repair of damage after the operation of a private entity cost tens of millions of crowns from the public budget. This tragedy confirmed the importance of regular inspections of all defence and security equipment by the responsible authorities, including proper registration. I also welcome the fact that the report stresses that the provision of maximum protection and security for civilians must be taken into account when awarding defence and security equipment contracts. I believe that the Member States will also identify with this call from the European Parliament.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The report on security and defence capabilities in Europe has been presented from an perspective that does not contribute to stability on the continent and its environment. Thus, in addition to "lamenting defence cuts," he notes that military cooperation with Russia (which still occurs in some respects such as satellite launches) undermines the EU's autonomy and independence. At the same time, however, the text stresses that the EU's work within NATO is important to ensure security and stability in Europe and to increase the economic efficiency of missions. On the other hand, the report frequently confuses the European Union as an organisation with Europe as a continent, projecting it as the only legitimate player in geographical space. This is not a secondary aspect, as it implies the denial of the interests of other parties with which we have to live. Good coexistence with our neighbors must be our priority.  That is why I voted against this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. Cooperation between strategic partners is essential for European security of supply, and hence encourages the Commission and the Member States to take defence procurement into account when negotiating international trade agreements.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report. When assessing security and defence capabilities in Europe, I believe that this is a subject in which more national sovereignty of individual Member States should prevail, as is presented by the ECR faction of which I am a member.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because it very clearly defined developments in the defence markets that threaten European autonomy. Current security threats are common across the EU and should be addressed in a coherent and coordinated manner by pooling and sharing civilian and military resources. In this context, it is very important that resources are not wasted, that synergies are created in the creation of a European defence equipment market and an industrial base through increased cross-border coordination for security and defence capabilities. I also share the fact that the single market in defence has a highly competitive industrial base based on innovation and technology, which can also achieve synergies through closer cross-border cooperation. Member States should make greater use of joint purchases through central purchasing bodies when purchasing equipment for security and defence capabilities, as provided for in the European Directive.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – I supported the report on security and defence capabilities in Europe because it addresses important topics that are very sensitive in the area of the common security policy in Europe. The biggest problems we face in the area of security and defence are, above all, market fragmentation, inefficiency, poor transparency, corruption, mismanagement and a lack of clear and strict internal market rules. Therefore, many dilemmas and suspicions of EU citizens are not superfluous. Especially at a time not only of economic crisis, but also crisis hotspots that create rivers of refugees on the outskirts of Europe. When terrorism is the subject of many summits, calls for more and more defence resources are not surprising. But are they really? The fact is that only 0.7% of GDP is thought to be spent by EU countries to eradicate poverty worldwide, while on average 2.0% of GDP is allocated to finance development for defence and weapons. Here we can ask ourselves what are the priorities of European foreign policy. Defence resources are sometimes a bottomless bag, especially since their consumption is opacient and carried out in the name of secret purchases. Only in this way can confidence be restored that the misuse of money on military equipment is indeed in the interests of EU citizens.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to strengthen security and defence capabilities in Europe, it is essential to streamline the use of financial resources, to improve coordination in defence capabilities and, in particular, to respond in a sufficiently timely manner and to channel strategic investments in the purchase and modernisation of defence equipment by Member States in a timely manner.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because I believe that European defence markets need to unite, become more economical and transparent. The European defence sector's dependence on external markets must also be reduced. More frequent conflicts at the European Union border such as the conflicts in Ukraine, Iraq, Syria and Libya, including the latest unrest in Macedonia, point to the necessity of improving the protection of EU residents. In order to achieve these objectives, a modern and unified strategy of the European defence industry, the development of European defence capabilities, the harmonisation of national budgets and plans for defence and the achievement of economies of scale are needed.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of improving the competitiveness of the defence industry, which in turn stimulates innovation and growth. However, this report contains measures which could interfere in what should be Member State competence, and therefore I abstained.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Impact of Change in European Defence Markets on Security and Defence Capabilities in Europe. As a new legislative pact was introduced in 2009 in the european defence market and all 28 Member States transposed these rules into their national legislation, a European market was created for defence equipment and services that are not sufficiently unified, cost-effective and transparent. As a result, the European defence sector's dependence on external markets could increase even further, at this time of direct threats to European security unprecedented since the end of the Cold War. An end to pervasive and largely unmatched cuts to defence budgets in most Member States is necessary due to the increasing number of armed conflicts, outbreaks of low intensity crises, hybrid warfare and intermediary warfare. To fully exploit the potential of the European defence market, a highly competitive industrial base focused on innovation and technology is needed. I also call on the Commission, in order to make the most of their resources, to encourage Member States to implement joint procurement procedures through central procurement authorities, such as the European Defence Agency, as provided for in Directive 2009/81/EC.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the impact of the development of European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe, as I believe that the European Union should put in place a system that allows a rapid and effective response to the various crises in Europe and in our neighbourhood. All this, however, will be made possible by a single European defence market, because, as the report rightly notes, we will eliminate duplication and reduce administrative burdens.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Within the framework of national sovereignty there are no concepts interwoven with accountability of defence arms exports, control of national POs for military expenditure, abolition of compensatory benefits, etc. In particular, the defence package aimed at supporting the competitiveness of the European defence sector will in future lead to the establishment of a monopoly by countries with defence industries.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which adds essential aspects to the two other reports discussed and adopted by the European Parliament on the implementation and financing of the Common European Security and Defence Policy. For my part, I am concerned about the prospect that, for some Member States, the reduction in defence spending and the lack of coordination between Member States could jeopardise European autonomy in the procurement of military equipment and, by this means, defence capabilities. This applies in particular to the current period of proliferating armed conflicts and hybrid wars.  I therefore support the report's approach of looking for answers to procurement and financing tensions due to member states' budget deficits through instruments of closer EU cooperation and coordination. I also consider the need in the report to ensure the highest possible transparency of public procurement in the field of military assets.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. We call on the Commission to consider publishing its Green Paper on Resource Control as soon as possible, originally planned for the end of 2014 in line with its 2014 roadmap, and to carry out an adequate and comprehensive analysis of the consequences of the implementation of the defence package, as well as a consultation with defence industry associations. , Member States, the European Defence Agency and other stakeholders, including organisations active in the areas of conflict prevention, peace and security.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. ‒ Europe has to assume its responsibilities in the field of conflict prevention and crisis management. Unfortunately, right now the CSDP exists mostly in theory. We need to back up these words on paper by real world physical capabilities. The CSDP has suffered chronic underfinancing, which is why it is not surprising that it has not been able to go anywhere near reaching its full potential. Real forces are needed to give the CSDP some meaning and credibility as a policy instrument. Even if the purpose is to refrain from engaging in military conflicts, which it should be, since diplomatic solutions are always preferable, the CSDP will never be taken seriously if there are no forces to back it up.  Since the CSDP is intended to act as a deterrent (to prevent outbreaks of armed conflict) it needs physical military capabilities by definition. The two Mistral class warships that France cannot deliver to Russia due to the latter’s involvement in the war in Ukraine should be bought by the EU in the framework of the CSDP. These ships would contribute to increasing CSDP capabilities in a variety of ways, for example in the Mediterranean, and we would avoid delivering additional weapons to a potential aggressor.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against ana Gomes' report. The report begins by emphasizing that the reduction of defence budgets weakens the defence potential of Member States. It also refers to regional instability to justify the call for coordination and increase of European defence budgets. In this regard, it explicitly states that current security threats are common throughout the EU as a whole and must be addressed in a united and coordinated manner, pooling and sharing both civilian and military resources. We vote against it therefore as we believe that the EU cannot be a force of war, but a force for peace

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report is in line with the June defence summit. It highlights the threats (hybrid wars in the eastern neighbourhood, terrorism) and also the risk of increased external dependence on "European" defence industries due to the crisis and in particular to Russia, with which states maintain trade and scientific relations in the military field.  To address these threats, the report makes a series of recommendations to enable the emergence of an integrated defence market (export control control control of dual-use civilian/military technologies). It also addresses the issues of financing and management methods. It calls for combating protectionist practices in the field of defence.  It should be noted that any integrated defence market is unthinkable. Scientific cooperation in this area cannot be limited to Europe or the subject of a constant policy but temporary and easily reversible partnerships, without the transfer of technologies imposed and concluded in a bilateral or multilateral framework. I'm voting against it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against the report proposed by Ana Gomes. The report begins by emphasizing that the reduction of defence budgets weakens the defence potential of Member States. It also refers to regional instability to justify the call for coordination and increase of European defence budgets. In this regard, it explicitly states that current security threats are common throughout the EU as a whole and must be addressed in a united and coordinated manner, pooling and sharing both civilian and military resources. We vote against it because we believe that the EU cannot be a force of war, but a force for peace.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning security and defence capabilities in Europe, since security is, and will continue being, one of the key priorities of the EU.  I strongly believe that all Member States should correctly implement defence package directives, in order to better spend their taxpayers’ money on defence equipment.  Also, I would like to underline the importance of our continent’s role as a security provider, which should be deployed to a great extent.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. – We are talking about a report highlighting the challenges and challenges of security and defence in Europe. In the face of a situation of scarcity of economic resources such as that suffered by the continent following the economic crisis, there needs to be greater coordination and cooperation in the field of security and defence, as well as a more effective use of resources in this area. It is therefore appropriate to vote in favour of a report which puts all these matters on the table.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The report on security and defence capabilities in Europe has been presented from an perspective that does not contribute to stability on the continent and its environment. Thus, in addition to "lamenting defence cuts," he notes that military cooperation with Russia (which still occurs in some respects such as satellite launches) undermines the EU's autonomy and independence. At the same time, however, the text stresses that the EU's work within NATO is important to ensure security and stability in Europe and to increase the economic efficiency of missions. On the other hand, the report frequently confuses the European Union as an organisation with Europe as a continent, projecting it as the only legitimate player in geographical space. This is not a secondary aspect, as it implies the denial of the interests of other parties with which we have to live. Good coexistence with our neighbors must be our priority.  That is why I voted against this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Dominate in the European Parliament the policies of aggression and militarisation of the European Union, masked in their security policies. Proving this nature are the effective responsibilities in the destabilisation processes of the countries of Eastern Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, notably through the financing and support of extremist groups, terrorists and authoritarian regimes, and in the effective underdevelopment of those countries. The report reinforces the enhancement of the European defence market and the need for it to be effectively consummated as an indispensable tool for strengthening the EU's bellicose capacity. Its objectives include european standardisation of security measures on the most diverse fronts, intervention within NATO's policies and objectives, a tool at the service of US imperialist policy, and european federalisation of its foreign policy, notably through the role of the VP/AR which we do not recognise and reject.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on security and defence capabilities in Europe, as I believe that the approach of this report is quite correct, but that the drafting has not yet reached a final stage and needs to be improved. The failures in the area of consolidation, cost-efficiency and transparency in European defence markets mean that the external dependence of the European defence sector on NATO could continue to increase.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the common security and defence policy. The security situation in the European Union's eastern and southern neighbourhood is still fragile and uncertain due to a number of long-term and emerging new conflicts. It is important to continue to work towards more efficient provision of funds for civilian missions and to simplify decision-making procedures and implementing arrangements. At the same time, we must not forget to exercise as much caution as possible with regard to preparatory actions concerning defence, whether it is management, co-financing or participation rules. Member States should be fully involved in the decision-making process in order to avoid bureaucratic problems while at the same time guaranteeing that the programmes meet strategic needs.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe. Developments in defence markets are putting European autonomy at risk, while continued budget cuts make further European cooperation imperative.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The majority of the right and social democracy in the European Parliament corroborates the policies of aggression and militarisation of the European Union, masked in its security policies, resigning from its effective responsibilities in the processes of destabilisation of the countries of Eastern Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, in particular through financing and support for extremist groups, terrorists and authoritarian regimes, in the effective underdevelopment of those countries.  As a means of consolidating defence policies, the report broadly reinforces the enhancement of the European defence market as an indispensable tool for strengthening the EU's warlike capacity. In its objectives, the European standardisation of security measures on the most diverse fronts, intervention in the framework of NATO's policies and objectives, a tool at the service of US imperialist policy, the European federalisation of its foreign policy, in particular through the role of the VP/AR, which we do not recognise and reject, are pursued. It strengthens the support and enhancement of research for the security industry, the strengthening, financial incentives and tax benefits of the European war industry, the logic of consolidating a common European defence market, with advances in cybersecurity and increased surveillance. We voted against it.
